electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: High frequency (50-100 Hz), short pulse duration (50-150 µs), sensory-level intensity (to patient comfort, no muscle contraction).
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes around the painful area of the shoulder, targeting the dermatome or a specific trigger point. Utilize a quadripolar or bipolar setup.
electrotherapy.goal: Provide symptomatic pain relief by stimulating sensory nerves to block pain signals (gate control theory) or stimulate endorphin release.
electrotherapy.image_description: A patient with two small adhesive TENS electrodes placed on their upper shoulder and upper arm, connected to a portable TENS unit.

phase_1.name: Acute/Protection Phase (Pain & Inflammation Control)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, protect the healing tissue, maintain passive range of motion, prevent stiffness, and activate scapular stabilizers gently.

exercises.name: Pendulum Swings (Codman's Exercises)
exercises.instructions: Lean forward, supporting your non-affected arm on a table. Let the affected arm hang freely. Gently swing the arm in small circles (clockwise and counter-clockwise), front-to-back, and side-to-side. Keep shoulder relaxed.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 sets of 10-20 repetitions in each direction, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A person leaning forward with one hand on a table, allowing their other arm to hang loosely and swing in small circles below their shoulder.

exercises.name: Passive/Assisted Shoulder Flexion/Abduction
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back. Use your unaffected arm to gently lift the affected arm overhead (flexion) or out to the side (abduction) within a pain-free range. Alternatively, use a pulley system for assisted motion.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A person lying supine on a mat, using their non-affected hand to gently assist their affected arm in lifting it overhead or out to the side.

exercises.name: Gentle Scapular Retractions
exercises.instructions: Sit or stand upright. Gently squeeze your shoulder blades together and slightly down, without shrugging your shoulders. Hold for 3-5 seconds and relax.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A person sitting upright, gently pulling their shoulder blades together and down, demonstrating good posture.

phase_2.name: Subacute/Intermediate Phase (Restoration of Motion & Initial Strengthening)
phase_2.goal: Gradually restore full pain-free active range of motion, begin light rotator cuff and scapular strengthening, improve neuromuscular control, and prepare for functional activities.

exercises.name: Isometric Rotator Cuff Exercises
exercises.instructions: With your elbow bent at 90 degrees and tucked at your side, press your palm into a wall/door frame for external rotation, or the back of your hand for internal rotation. For abduction, press the side of your arm into a wall. Hold for 5-10 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions for each direction, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A person standing sideways to a wall, pressing the palm of their hand into the wall with their elbow bent and tucked, performing an isometric external rotation.

exercises.name: Theraband External/Internal Rotation (Light Resistance)
exercises.instructions: Anchor a light resistance band. Keep your elbow bent at 90 degrees and tucked to your side. Slowly rotate your arm outwards (external rotation) and then inwards (internal rotation) against the band's resistance. Maintain control throughout the movement.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: A person performing external rotation with a light resistance band, anchored to a door, with their elbow bent at 90 degrees and tucked at their side.

exercises.name: Wall Slides / Scapular Wall Angels
exercises.instructions: Stand facing a wall with your forearms and hands against the wall, elbows bent. Slowly slide your forearms up the wall, raising your arms overhead, focusing on upward rotation of your shoulder blades. Keep your back flat against the wall if possible, or maintain good posture.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: A person standing with their back against a wall, forearms and hands also against the wall, slowly sliding their arms upwards.

phase_3.name: Strengthening & Return to Activity Phase (Progressive Loading & Functional Integration)
phase_3.goal: Progressively increase rotator cuff and scapular strength, improve power, enhance endurance, develop dynamic stability, and gradually return to full functional and sport-specific activities.

exercises.name: Progressive Resisted Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Utilize progressively stronger resistance bands. Perform exercises for external rotation, internal rotation, abduction, and scaption (shoulder flexion in the plane of the scapula, approximately 30 degrees forward of the frontal plane). Focus on controlled, smooth movements.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions for each direction, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A person standing with a resistance band, performing a scaption exercise, raising their arm diagonally forward and up with control.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Exercises (Front Raises, Lateral Raises, Bent-over Rows)
exercises.instructions: Using light to moderate dumbbells, perform controlled front raises (flexion to shoulder height), lateral raises (abduction to shoulder height), and bent-over rows to strengthen the shoulder girdle and upper back muscles. Maintain good form and avoid pain.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A person performing a dumbbell lateral raise, lifting light dumbbells out to the sides to shoulder height, with good posture.

exercises.name: Push-ups (Modified to Full)
exercises.instructions: Start with wall push-ups, then progress to incline push-ups (hands on a counter or bench), and finally to floor push-ups. Focus on maintaining a stable scapula and core throughout the movement.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-15 repetitions, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A person performing a standard floor push-up, demonstrating full body alignment and control.

exercises.name: Dynamic Stability / Rhythmic Stabilizations
exercises.instructions: Patient holds their arm in a specific position (e.g., 90 degrees abduction and 90 degrees external rotation). The therapist applies gentle, multidirectional manual resistance, and the patient resists the movement to maintain the position. Progress to perturbations.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 seconds holds with resistance, 1-2 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A therapist applying gentle resistance to a patient's outstretched arm in multiple directions, while the patient stabilizes their shoulder joint.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves a thorough history, physical examination including observation, palpation, active and passive range of motion, strength testing, and special tests (e.g., Neer's, Hawkins-Kennedy, Empty Can test) to identify rotator cuff pathology. Imaging (X-ray to rule out bony pathology, MRI to visualize soft tissues) may be used to confirm diagnosis and rule out tears or other structural issues.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques may include soft tissue mobilization or massage to the rotator cuff muscles, periscapular muscles, and surrounding tissues to reduce muscle guarding and improve circulation. Joint mobilizations (grades I-IV) may be performed to the glenohumeral joint, acromioclavicular joint, and sternoclavicular joint to address any mobility restrictions. Trigger point release may be applied to areas of muscle hypertonicity.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that exacerbate pain, especially overhead movements. Progress exercises gradually, ensuring pain-free range of motion and strengthening. Monitor for signs of increased inflammation or pain. Educate patients on proper posture, body mechanics, and activity modification. Avoid heavy lifting or repetitive movements that stress the rotator cuff during the acute and subacute phases. Ensure proper warm-up and cool-down for all exercise sessions.

scientific_reference: Kisner, C., & Colby, L. A. (2017). Therapeutic Exercise: Foundations and Techniques (7th ed.). F.A. Davis Company.

clinical_presentation.definition: Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome (PFPS) is characterized by pain around or behind the patella (kneecap), often aggravated by activities that load the patellofemoral joint, such as squatting, stair climbing (especially descent), running, jumping, and prolonged sitting. It is a multifactorial condition associated with biomechanical imbalances, muscle weakness (e.g., quadriceps, gluteal muscles), altered patellar tracking, and overuse.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Close-up of a person's knee, with a hand gently touching the area around the patella, indicating anterior knee pain. The background might suggest activities like running or climbing stairs.

electrotherapy.parameters: High-frequency (conventional) TENS: Frequency 80-120 Hz, Pulse Duration 50-100 μs, comfortable sensory level intensity, applied for 30-60 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes are typically placed around the patella, avoiding direct placement over the patella itself, or on trigger points in the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) or other quadriceps muscles.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain modulation, reduction of perceived pain intensity to facilitate exercise and functional activity.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing electrode placement for TENS around the patella, illustrating electrode pads on the medial and lateral aspects of the knee.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency 30-50 Hz, Pulse Duration 200-400 μs, On/Off ratio 1:5 (e.g., 6 seconds on, 30 seconds off), ramp time 1-2 seconds, intensity set to achieve a visible and tolerable muscle contraction. 10-15 contractions per session.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: One electrode placed over the motor point of the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) muscle belly, and the other electrode placed more proximally over the main quadriceps bulk.
electrotherapy.goal: Improve quadriceps (specifically VMO) activation and strength, aid in muscle re-education for better patellar tracking.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing electrode placement for NMES on the medial quadriceps/VMO for muscle activation, illustrating electrode pads on the medial thigh.

phase_1.name: Acute Pain Management & Activation
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, initiate gentle quadriceps and gluteal activation without exacerbating pain, improve core stability.

exercises.name: Quad Sets
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with the affected leg straight. Push the back of your knee down into the bed/floor by tightening your thigh muscle (quadriceps). Ensure your patella moves slightly superiorly. Hold for 5-10 seconds, then relax completely.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, demonstrating isometric quadriceps contraction by pressing the knee down onto a flat surface.

exercises.name: Gluteal Squeezes
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back or sit upright. Squeeze your buttocks together as if trying to hold something between them. Focus on engaging the gluteal muscles. Hold for 5-10 seconds, then relax.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, demonstrating a gluteal contraction.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raises (SLR) - Pain-free Range
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with the unaffected knee bent and foot flat. Straighten the affected leg, tighten your quadriceps, and slowly lift the leg approximately 6-12 inches off the floor, keeping the knee straight. Lower slowly and with control. Ensure no pain during movement.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times per day, within pain-free limits.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, performing a straight leg raise with the knee extended, lifting the leg a few inches off the ground.

phase_2.name: Intermediate Strengthening & Neuromuscular Control
phase_2.goal: Progress strength of quadriceps and hip musculature (abductors, external rotators), improve patellar tracking, and enhance neuromuscular control with functional movements.

exercises.name: Wall Slides (Partial Squats)
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart and a few inches away from the wall. Slowly slide down the wall into a partial squat, ensuring your knees do not go past your toes and are aligned over your second toe. Go only as far as comfortable (e.g., 0-45 degrees knee flexion). Push back up slowly.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a wall slide, back against a wall, in a partial squat position with knees bent.

exercises.name: Clamshells (with/without resistance band)
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with knees bent at approximately 90 degrees, one leg stacked on top of the other, and hips slightly flexed. Keep your feet together and lift your top knee up towards the ceiling, rotating at the hip. Do not let your pelvis roll backward. Lower slowly and with control.
exercises.dosage: 15-20 repetitions, 2-3 sets per side, 3-4 times per week (add resistance band for progression).
exercises.image_description: Person lying on their side with bent knees, performing a clamshell exercise, lifting the top knee.

exercises.name: Mini-Squats/Sit-to-Stands
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Slowly squat down as if sitting in a chair, keeping your chest up and knees aligned over your second toe. Go only to a comfortable depth (e.g., 0-60 degrees knee flexion). Push back up to standing. Use a chair for support initially if needed.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a mini-squat, demonstrating good form with knees behind toes and chest up.

exercises.name: Step-ups (Low Step)
exercises.instructions: Stand facing a low step (e.g., 4-6 inches high). Step up onto the step with the affected leg, driving through the heel, then slowly and controlled step down with the other leg. Maintain good knee alignment (knee over second toe) throughout the movement.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions per leg, 2-3 sets, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person stepping up onto a low step, demonstrating proper knee alignment over the foot.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration & Return to Activity
phase_3.goal: Restore full strength, power, agility, and endurance. Progress to activity or sport-specific demands, improving dynamic stability and shock absorption.

exercises.name: Single Leg Squats (Supported/Unsupported)
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, keeping your core engaged. Slowly squat down as if sitting in a chair, keeping your knee aligned over your second toe. Go only as deep as comfortable and controlled. Use a chair or wall for support initially if needed.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions per leg, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a single-leg squat, possibly holding onto a stable support for balance.

exercises.name: Lunges (Forward and Lateral)
exercises.instructions: Forward Lunge: Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at approximately 90 degrees. Ensure your front knee is behind your toes. Push back to the starting position. Lateral Lunge: Step to the side with one leg, bending the knee of the stepping leg while keeping the other leg straight. Push back to the starting position.
exercises.dosage: 10-12 repetitions per leg (each direction), 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a forward lunge with correct form, showing both knees at 90 degrees.

exercises.name: Plyometric Drills (Low-level hops/jumps)
exercises.instructions: Begin with low-impact drills such as two-foot hops forward/backward/side-to-side, or small box jumps (e.g., 6-12 inches). Focus on soft landings, maintaining knee alignment, and controlled eccentric absorption. Progress gradually to single-leg hops or higher jumps as tolerated.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 sets of 8-12 repetitions/hops, 1-2 times per week, ensuring pain-free execution.
exercises.image_description: Person performing bilateral low box jumps, focusing on controlled landing.

exercises.name: Agility Drills (Cone Drills/Shuttle Runs)
exercises.instructions: Set up cones in a T-pattern, zig-zag, or figure-eight. Perform quick changes of direction, focusing on controlled deceleration, acceleration, and proper knee alignment. Gradually increase speed and complexity as tolerated.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 sets of 5-10 repetitions/patterns, 1-2 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing agility drills on a sports field, weaving through cones.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis of PFPS typically involves a detailed patient history (insidious onset of anterior knee pain, aggravation with activity, prolonged sitting) and a comprehensive physical examination. Key assessment findings may include tenderness along the patellar facets, positive patellar compression or grind test (though non-specific), VMO weakness or delayed activation, gluteal muscle weakness (abductors/external rotators), tightness in hamstrings, quadriceps, ITB, or gastrocnemius/soleus, and altered lower extremity biomechanics (e.g., excessive foot pronation, dynamic knee valgus during functional tasks). Differential diagnosis should rule out other knee pathologies.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Patellar mobilizations (e.g., medial glide, superior/inferior glides) to improve patellar mobility and reduce local stiffness. Soft tissue mobilization or release techniques for tight structures such as the lateral retinaculum, iliotibial band (ITB), quadriceps, hip flexors, and calf muscles. Joint mobilizations for restricted joints in the kinetic chain (e.g., hip, ankle, tibiofemoral) if indicated.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that significantly increase or reproduce pain. Emphasize a gradual progression of exercise intensity and load, guided by the patient's symptoms. Monitor for compensatory movements or poor biomechanics during exercises and functional activities. Educate the patient on activity modification, proper footwear, and ergonomic considerations. Persistent or worsening pain warrants re-evaluation of the diagnosis and treatment plan. Ensure proper warm-up and cool-down for all exercise sessions.

scientific_reference: Clinical Practice Guidelines for Patellofemoral Pain Syndrome, as published in journals such as the Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy (JOSPT) or the British Journal of Sports Medicine (BJSM).

clinical_presentation.definition: Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (AIDP), an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system. It is characterized by rapidly progressive, typically ascending, symmetrical muscle weakness, often starting in the legs and progressing to the arms and facial muscles. Sensory symptoms (numbness, tingling, pain) are common, and deep tendon reflexes are usually diminished or absent. In severe cases, it can lead to respiratory muscle paralysis requiring mechanical ventilation and autonomic dysfunction.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diverse patient (e.g., male, 40s) in a hospital bed with a physical therapist gently assisting with passive range of motion in their leg, demonstrating muscle weakness. The patient appears to be alert but dependent on assistance, with medical equipment visible in the background.

electrotherapy.parameters: Biphasic pulsed current; Frequency: 35-50 Hz; Pulse Duration: 200-300 μs; On/Off Time: 1:3 to 1:5 ratio (e.g., 10s on, 30s off); Ramp Up/Down: 1-2s; Amplitude: To visible contraction without pain or excessive fatigue.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over the motor points of weak, recovering muscles (e.g., quadriceps, tibialis anterior, wrist extensors) to facilitate motor unit recruitment. Ensure skin integrity.
electrotherapy.goal: To facilitate muscle contraction, prevent disuse atrophy, improve motor recruitment patterns, and aid in strengthening as volitional control returns. Used cautiously in later stages of recovery once denervation/reinnervation processes are established and muscles show some response.
electrotherapy.image_description: A close-up of a physical therapist applying two surface electrodes to the quadriceps muscle of a patient's leg, demonstrating proper placement for NMES. The patient's leg is resting on a plinth.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: High frequency (80-150 Hz), short pulse duration (50-100 μs), sensory level intensity. Burst/Acupuncture-like TENS: Low frequency (2-10 Hz), longer pulse duration (150-250 μs), motor level intensity (tolerable twitch).
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over areas of neuropathic pain or along peripheral nerve distributions. Avoid placement over carotid sinus or open wounds.
electrotherapy.goal: To modulate and reduce neuropathic pain, which is common in GBS patients, thereby improving comfort and participation in therapy.
electrotherapy.image_description: A patient with electrodes placed on their lower back or a limb, using a portable TENS unit, illustrating pain management. The patient appears relaxed.

phase_1.name: Acute & Early Recovery Phase (Immobility/Severe Weakness)
phase_1.goal: Prevent secondary complications (contractures, skin breakdown, respiratory issues), maintain joint integrity, initiate very gentle muscle activation if possible, provide respiratory support, and educate patient/family.

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM)
exercises.instructions: Perform slow, gentle, and full PROM to all major joints (shoulders, elbows, wrists, hips, knees, ankles) 2-3 times daily. Support limbs proximally and distally to avoid undue stress on weak muscles or joints.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions per joint, 2-3 sessions per day.
exercises.image_description: A physical therapist gently supporting a patient's arm at the elbow and wrist, performing passive flexion and extension of the elbow while the patient is lying in bed.

exercises.name: Therapeutic Positioning and Splinting
exercises.instructions: Regularly reposition the patient every 2-3 hours to prevent pressure sores and maintain joint alignment. Utilize pillows, foam wedges. Consider static splints (e.g., resting hand splints, ankle-foot orthoses) to prevent contractures (e.g., wrist drop, foot drop) and nerve compression.
exercises.dosage: Continuous positioning with hourly adjustments if possible. Splints worn for prescribed periods, typically on/off schedule.
exercises.image_description: A patient lying in a hospital bed, correctly positioned with pillows supporting their limbs and head, and potentially wearing a soft ankle-foot orthosis.

exercises.name: Respiratory Exercises & Postural Drainage
exercises.instructions: If patient is able, encourage deep breathing exercises, incentive spirometry, and assisted coughing techniques (e.g., chest compressions). For patients with secretion issues, perform postural drainage with percussion and vibration as tolerated.
exercises.dosage: Deep breathing/spirometry: 5-10 repetitions every hour while awake. Postural drainage: 10-15 minutes, 2-4 times daily as needed.
exercises.image_description: A patient in bed using an incentive spirometer, with a physical therapist or nurse supervising and providing instructions.

exercises.name: Gentle Trunk Mobility (Assisted Log Rolling)
exercises.instructions: With assistance, gently log roll the patient side-to-side to facilitate repositioning, aid in respiratory hygiene, and provide early trunk proprioceptive input. Avoid twisting movements.
exercises.dosage: As needed for repositioning, typically every 2-3 hours.
exercises.image_description: Two physical therapists gently assisting a patient to log roll from supine to side-lying in a hospital bed, demonstrating coordinated effort.

phase_2.name: Intermediate Recovery Phase (Emerging Active Movement & Early Strengthening)
phase_2.goal: Progress active muscle strength, improve active range of motion, develop basic trunk stability and sitting/standing balance, and initiate early functional mobility.

exercises.name: Active-Assistive/Active Range of Motion (AAROM/AROM)
exercises.instructions: Progress from gravity-eliminated positions (e.g., powdered board, suspension slings) to against-gravity movements as muscle strength returns (MMT 2/5-3/5). Encourage active initiation of movement with minimal assistance.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per muscle group, 2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: A patient lying supine, using a powdered board to perform active-assistive hip and knee flexion/extension, guided by their own efforts.

exercises.name: Gentle Isometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: For muscles with trace to poor strength (MMT 1/5-2/5) or those beginning to show active movement, perform submaximal isometric contractions against resistance (e.g., therapist's hand or plinth) for 5-10 seconds. Focus on muscle activation without joint movement.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions, 2-3 sets per muscle group, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: A physical therapist placing their hand against a patient's foot, and the patient gently pushing against it to perform an isometric contraction of the dorsiflexors.

exercises.name: Mat Exercises (Rolling, Bridging, Quadruped Rocking)
exercises.instructions: Progress from assisted rolling to independent rolling. Then, introduce assisted bridging, gradually progressing to independent bridging. When appropriate, initiate quadruped rocking (anterior/posterior) to improve core stability and weight-bearing through upper extremities.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per exercise, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: A patient lying supine on a mat, performing a gentle bridging exercise, lifting their hips slightly off the mat.

exercises.name: Sitting Balance Activities
exercises.instructions: Start with supported sitting (e.g., against wall/backrest) and progress to unsupported sitting on the edge of the bed or a mat table. Practice static balance (maintaining position) and dynamic balance (reaching, weight shifts).
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 2-3 sessions per day, gradually increasing duration and challenge.
exercises.image_description: A patient sitting on the edge of a mat table with a physical therapist standing close for safety, performing dynamic reaching exercises to improve sitting balance.

exercises.name: Progressive Resistive Exercises (PREs) - Low Resistance
exercises.instructions: For muscles with MMT >3/5, introduce very light resistance using manual resistance, therabands (lowest resistance), or very light weights (1-2 lbs). Focus on good form and controlled movements. Avoid over-fatigue.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time daily, or every other day depending on fatigue.
exercises.image_description: A patient performing bicep curls with a very light (e.g., 1lb) dumbbell, maintaining good posture while seated.

phase_3.name: Advanced Recovery & Functional Integration Phase (Moderate to Maximal Strength)
phase_3.goal: Maximize muscle strength, endurance, balance, and coordination. Restore functional independence, improve gait quality, and prepare for return to prior activities (work, leisure, community).

exercises.name: Advanced Progressive Resistive Exercises (PREs)
exercises.instructions: Progress to higher resistance with free weights, resistance bands, and exercise machines. Incorporate compound movements and functional patterns (e.g., squats, lunges, step-ups, push/pull exercises). Focus on concentric and eccentric control.
exercises.dosage: 8-15 repetitions, 2-4 sets, 3-4 times per week, ensuring adequate rest days.
exercises.image_description: A patient performing a controlled wall squat with good form, demonstrating increased lower body strength.

exercises.name: Standing Balance & Proprioception Training
exercises.instructions: Progress from static standing balance (tandem stance, single leg stance) to dynamic activities (reaching, catching, unstable surfaces like foam pads or Bosu ball, obstacle courses). Incorporate head turns and dual-task activities.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 minutes, 2-3 times daily, or integrated into strength/gait training.
exercises.image_description: A patient standing on a foam pad, performing single leg stance with a physical therapist nearby for supervision and safety.

exercises.name: Gait Training & Locomotor Activities
exercises.instructions: Progress from parallel bars to walker, then canes, and eventually independent ambulation. Incorporate varied surfaces (ramps, stairs, uneven terrain), speed changes, turning, and obstacle negotiation. Focus on improving gait mechanics, symmetry, and endurance.
exercises.dosage: 15-30 minutes of continuous or interval walking, 2-3 times daily, gradually increasing distance and complexity.
exercises.image_description: A patient walking independently on a slightly uneven outdoor path, demonstrating good balance and gait, with a physical therapist observing a few steps behind.

exercises.name: Coordination & Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Incorporate exercises like ladder drills, cone weaving, throwing and catching, targeted reaching, and fine motor tasks to improve dexterity, coordination, and reaction time for both upper and lower extremities.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 minutes, 1-2 times daily, or as part of a circuit.
exercises.image_description: A patient performing a step-over drill using a low agility ladder on the floor, focusing on foot placement and coordination.

exercises.name: Cardiovascular Endurance Training
exercises.instructions: Initiate low-impact aerobic activities such as stationary cycling, arm ergometry, elliptical training, or walking on a treadmill/outdoors. Monitor heart rate and perceived exertion, focusing on sustained effort without excessive fatigue.
exercises.dosage: 20-40 minutes of moderate intensity, 3-5 times per week, with warm-up and cool-down.
exercises.image_description: A patient seated on a stationary bicycle, pedaling at a comfortable pace, demonstrating light to moderate exertion.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis of GBS is primarily clinical, based on acute progressive ascending weakness, areflexia, and often sensory symptoms. PT assessment includes detailed motor (MMT), sensory, reflex, cranial nerve, and respiratory function evaluations. Functional outcome measures (e.g., FIM, GBS Disability Scale, Berg Balance Scale, 6-Minute Walk Test) are used to track progress. Electrodiagnostic studies (Nerve Conduction Studies, EMG) typically confirm demyelination or axonal involvement.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Gentle manual therapy techniques are employed cautiously. In the acute phase, PROM is crucial to prevent contractures. Soft tissue mobilization (gentle massage, effleurage) can help reduce muscle spasm, improve circulation, and alleviate pain. Joint mobilizations (Grades I-II) may be used to maintain joint play and address stiffness as tolerated, but aggressive techniques are contraindicated due to potential for exacerbating nerve irritation or pain. Peripheral nerve mobilization may be considered in later stages if specific nerve entrapment symptoms are present, always with careful monitoring for adverse reactions.
clinical_notes.precautions: 1. **Over-fatigue**: The most critical precaution. Over-exertion can lead to a significant worsening of weakness and prolonged recovery ('post-exertional fatigue' or 'activity-induced fatigue'). Therapy should be short, frequent, and avoid fatigue. 2. **Respiratory Compromise**: Closely monitor respiratory rate, depth, and effort. Be alert for signs of respiratory muscle weakness, dyspnea, or changes in vocal quality. 3. **Autonomic Dysfunction**: Monitor vital signs (blood pressure, heart rate) for orthostatic hypotension, arrhythmias, or other dysautonomia. 4. **Pain**: Neuropathic pain can be severe; manage with appropriate modalities and positioning. 5. **Skin Integrity**: Due to immobility and potential sensory loss, regularly check for skin breakdown. 6. **Fall Risk**: High risk due to weakness, sensory deficits, and balance impairments. Ensure appropriate supervision and assistive devices. 7. **Joint Integrity**: Protect weak joints from overstretching or injury; use proper body mechanics and supports. 8. **Emotional Support**: GBS can cause significant anxiety and depression; provide psychological support and refer as needed.

scientific_reference: O'Sullivan, S. B., Schmitz, T. J., & Fulk, G. D. (2019). Physical Rehabilitation (7th ed.). F.A. Davis Company. (Chapter on Neurological Disorders: Peripheral Neuropathies)

clinical_presentation.definition: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is a chronic, systemic autoimmune disease primarily affecting the synovial lining of joints, leading to inflammation, pain, stiffness, and eventual joint erosion and deformity. Orthopedically, it commonly manifests as symmetrical polyarthritis, affecting small joints of the hands and feet (MCPs, PIPs, MTPs), wrists, knees, shoulders, and ankles. Symptoms include morning stiffness lasting over 30 minutes, swelling, warmth, tenderness, and progressive loss of joint function. Systemic symptoms like fatigue and malaise are also common.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Stock photo of hands of a person with rheumatoid arthritis, showing visible swelling, redness, and early signs of ulnar deviation or swan-neck deformity in the fingers.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: Frequency 80-120 Hz, Pulse Width 50-100 µs, Intensity to a strong but comfortable tingling sensation. Duration: 30-60 minutes, 1-3 times daily as needed for pain.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over or around the painful joint, ensuring good skin contact and avoiding bony prominences.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain modulation and reduction of perceived pain intensity during acute flares or chronic discomfort.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing TENS electrode placement around an inflamed wrist joint.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency 4000 Hz carrier frequency with a beat frequency of 80-120 Hz for pain relief, or 0-10 Hz for muscle pumping/edema reduction. Intensity to a strong, comfortable sensation without muscle contraction. Duration: 20-30 minutes, 1-2 times daily.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Four electrodes placed in a criss-cross pattern surrounding the affected joint (e.g., knee, shoulder) to allow for current interference within the joint capsule.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain relief, reduction of joint swelling and inflammation through improved local circulation.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing IFC electrode placement in a criss-cross pattern over an inflamed knee joint.

phase_1.name: Pain Management & Joint Protection
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, maintain joint integrity and range of motion, prevent muscle atrophy, and educate on joint protection principles.

exercises.name: Gentle Active Assisted Range of Motion (AAROM) for affected joints
exercises.instructions: Perform slow, controlled movements through the available pain-free range of motion for each affected joint (e.g., wrist flexion/extension, finger abduction/adduction, knee flexion/extension). Support the limb if needed to reduce gravity's effect.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per joint, 2-3 times daily, ensuring no increase in pain or swelling.
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person gently moving their wrist through its range of motion, supported by the other hand.

exercises.name: Pain-free Isometric Muscle Contractions
exercises.instructions: Gently contract muscles around the affected joint without moving the joint itself. Hold for a few seconds. Examples: gently pressing the palm against a table for wrist isometrics, quadriceps setting by pressing the knee down onto a towel.
exercises.dosage: Hold 5 seconds, 5-10 repetitions per muscle group, 1-2 times daily, ensuring no pain.
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing a quadriceps set, pressing the back of the knee down against a rolled towel.

exercises.name: Joint Protection Education & Ergonomics
exercises.instructions: Educate on using larger, stronger joints, avoiding sustained positions, distributing load, using assistive devices, and energy conservation. Provide examples like sliding objects instead of lifting, using two hands for heavy items, modifying grip for utensils.
exercises.dosage: Ongoing education, daily application of principles.
exercises.image_description: Infographic demonstrating principles of joint protection for daily tasks (e.g., opening a jar with two hands).

phase_2.name: Strength & Flexibility Restoration
phase_2.goal: Improve muscle strength and endurance, increase joint flexibility, restore functional range of motion, and improve cardiovascular fitness.

exercises.name: Active Range of Motion (AROM) with light resistance
exercises.instructions: Progress from AAROM to full AROM as tolerated. Introduce light resistance using resistance bands or light weights (0.5-1 kg) for exercises like wrist curls, bicep curls, knee extensions. Focus on controlled movements.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per exercise, 3-4 times per week, gradually increasing resistance as tolerated without pain.
exercises.image_description: Person performing wrist curls with a light dumbbell.

exercises.name: Gentle Stretching
exercises.instructions: Perform static stretches for major muscle groups around affected joints, holding at the point of gentle tension, not pain. Examples: hamstring stretch, shoulder capsule stretches, wrist flexor/extensor stretches.
exercises.dosage: Hold 20-30 seconds, 2-3 repetitions per stretch, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a gentle wrist extensor stretch, pulling fingers back with the opposite hand.

exercises.name: Low-impact Aerobic Exercise
exercises.instructions: Engage in activities like walking, swimming, cycling (stationary bike) to improve cardiovascular fitness and joint mobility without excessive impact. Start with short durations and gradually increase.
exercises.dosage: 15-30 minutes, 3-5 times per week, at a moderate intensity.
exercises.image_description: Person swimming laps in a pool, demonstrating a low-impact exercise.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration & Long-term Management
phase_3.goal: Maximize functional independence, improve muscle strength and power, enhance balance and coordination, prevent further joint damage, and promote long-term self-management.

exercises.name: Progressive Resistance Training
exercises.instructions: Advance resistance using free weights, machines, or increased band tension for compound and isolated movements. Focus on functional strength related to daily activities (e.g., squats, lunges, overhead press, grip strengthening).
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets per exercise, 2-3 times per week, maintaining good form and avoiding joint stress.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a bodyweight squat with good form.

exercises.name: Balance and Proprioception Exercises
exercises.instructions: Incorporate exercises like single-leg stance, tandem walking, heel-to-toe walking, unstable surface training (e.g., wobble board) to improve joint stability and balance.
exercises.dosage: 1-3 sets of 30-60 seconds holds or 10-15 repetitions, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a single-leg stance exercise.

exercises.name: Activity-Specific Functional Training
exercises.instructions: Replicate and practice movements relevant to hobbies or occupational tasks, modifying as needed to protect joints. This could include modified gardening techniques, adapted cooking movements, or specific sports drills with modifications.
exercises.dosage: Integrate into daily life, 3-5 times per week as applicable.
exercises.image_description: Person demonstrating modified grip for gardening tools to protect finger joints.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Physical therapy assessment involves thorough history taking for symptom onset, duration, morning stiffness, and systemic features. Objective examination includes active and passive range of motion, joint palpation for tenderness and swelling (e.g., using a count of swollen/tender joints), muscle strength testing, functional ability scales (e.g., HAQ-DI), and observation of joint deformities (e.g., ulnar drift, swan neck). Collaboration with rheumatologist for serological tests (RF, anti-CCP), inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP), and imaging (X-rays, MRI) is crucial for diagnosis and disease activity monitoring.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Gentle joint mobilizations (grades I-II) may be used to reduce pain and maintain joint play, particularly in non-inflamed joints or during periods of remission. Soft tissue mobilization and myofascial release techniques can address secondary muscle guarding and trigger points. Traction for cervical spine involvement may be cautiously considered. Aggressive mobilization or manipulation is strictly contraindicated during acute inflammatory flares due to risk of exacerbating joint damage.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid over-stressing inflamed joints; respect pain as a guide. Monitor for signs of increased inflammation (pain, swelling, redness, warmth) and adjust exercise intensity accordingly. Ensure proper joint protection techniques are consistently applied in daily activities. Be mindful of systemic fatigue and malaise; incorporate energy conservation strategies. Educate patients on medication adherence and the importance of regular rheumatologist follow-ups. Monitor for potential side effects of medications (e.g., corticosteroid-induced osteopenia).
clinical_notes.scientific_reference: Hurley, M. V., Bearne, L. M., Lamb, S. E., Sheehan, S., Nichols, V., & Newman, S. P. (2007). Exercise for rheumatoid arthritis: a review of the evidence. Rheumatology, 46(Suppl 2), ii3-ii9.

clinical_presentation.definition: Scoliosis is a three-dimensional deviation of the spine, characterized by a lateral curvature (coronal plane), rotation (axial plane), and often a kyphotic or lordotic change (sagittal plane). It can be idiopathic (most common, especially in adolescents), congenital, or neuromuscular. Clinically, it presents as an 'S' or 'C' shaped curve, often with associated rib hump, uneven shoulders, hips, and waist, and trunk asymmetry.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Stock photo of a person's bare back, showing a visible 'S' or 'C' shaped lateral curvature of the spine, with a prominent rib hump on one side and uneven shoulder and hip heights.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 80-120 Hz, Pulse Duration: 50-100 µs, Intensity: Sensory level (strong, comfortable tingling), Duration: 20-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on or around areas of localized pain or muscle spasm, typically along the paraspinal muscles of the convex side or compensatory curves.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain management, reduction of muscle spasm, and symptomatic relief.
electrotherapy.image_description: Close-up of TENS electrodes placed bilaterally on the paraspinal muscles along a painful segment of the spine due to scoliosis.

electrotherapy.type: Neuromuscular Electrical Stimulation (NMES) / Electrical Muscle Stimulation (EMS)
electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 30-50 Hz, Pulse Duration: 200-300 µs, On/Off ratio: 1:3 to 1:5 (e.g., 6s on, 18s off), Ramp up/down: 1-2 sec, Intensity: Visible muscle contraction (tolerable), Duration: 15-20 minutes, 10-15 repetitions
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over specific weak or inhibited muscles to facilitate strengthening and improved motor control, such as the trunk extensors on the convex side, abdominal obliques on the concave side, or deep spinal stabilizers.
electrotherapy.goal: Muscle re-education, strengthening of specific trunk musculature to improve spinal stability, and correction of muscular imbalance.
electrotherapy.image_description: Close-up of NMES electrodes placed over the paraspinal muscles on the convex side of a scoliotic curve to stimulate muscle contraction.

phase_1.name: Initial Awareness & Core Activation
phase_1.goal: Improve postural awareness, initiate diaphragmatic breathing, activate deep core stabilizers, and gently mobilize the spine to reduce stiffness and pain.

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Lie supine with knees bent, one hand on chest, one on abdomen. Breathe deeply, focusing on expanding the abdomen while keeping the chest relatively still. Progress to asymmetrical breathing focusing on expanding the concave side of the rib cage.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 3-5 times daily
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with hands on chest and abdomen, demonstrating diaphragmatic breathing, focusing on abdominal expansion.

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilts
exercises.instructions: Lie supine with knees bent. Gently flatten your lower back into the floor by tilting your pelvis posteriorly, then gently arch your lower back by tilting your pelvis anteriorly. Focus on controlled, small movements.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine performing a gentle pelvic tilt, illustrating the movement of the pelvis.

exercises.name: Transverse Abdominis Activation (Drawing-in maneuver)
exercises.instructions: Lie supine with knees bent. Place fingertips on your lower abdomen just inside your hip bones. Gently draw your belly button towards your spine without moving your pelvis or lower back, feeling the muscles under your fingers contract. Hold briefly.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, hold 5-10 seconds
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with fingers on lower abdomen, demonstrating the drawing-in maneuver for transverse abdominis activation.

exercises.name: Cat-Cow Stretch (Modified)
exercises.instructions: Start on hands and knees. Gently round your back towards the ceiling (cat) and then gently arch your back, dropping your belly towards the floor (cow). Focus on spinal articulation, avoiding excessive lumbar extension. Can be modified to focus on specific segments.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person on hands and knees demonstrating the cat-cow stretch, showing the arched and rounded back positions.

phase_2.name: Strength, Flexibility & Motor Control
phase_2.goal: Improve spinal stability, strengthen specific trunk muscles (especially on the convex side and core), increase flexibility in tight areas (concave side), and enhance motor control for improved posture and balance.

exercises.name: Bird-Dog
exercises.instructions: Start on hands and knees. Keep your core engaged and spine neutral. Slowly extend one arm forward and the opposite leg backward, keeping your hips and shoulders level. Return to start with control. Focus on maintaining trunk stability.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions per side, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person on hands and knees performing the bird-dog exercise, with one arm extended forward and the opposite leg extended backward.

exercises.name: Side Plank (Modified for Scoliosis)
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side, supported by your forearm and knees or feet. Lift your hips off the floor, forming a straight line from head to ankles. Focus on engaging your core. For scoliosis, specific modifications can be made to engage muscles on the concave side more effectively (e.g., placing a bolster under the convex side).
exercises.dosage: Hold 20-45 seconds, 2-3 repetitions per side
exercises.image_description: Person performing a side plank, supported on forearm and feet, maintaining a straight body line. (Consider adding a note about concave side activation).

exercises.name: Thoracic Extension with Foam Roller
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with a foam roller placed horizontally across your mid-back (thoracic spine). Support your head with your hands. Slowly extend your spine over the roller, gently arching your back. Move the roller to different segments of the thoracic spine.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per segment, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person lying on their back with a foam roller under their thoracic spine, gently extending their back over the roller.

exercises.name: Wall Slides (Postural Control)
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, heels about 6 inches away. Keep your head, shoulders, and hips in contact with the wall. Gently slide your arms up the wall, keeping your elbows and wrists in contact, then slide them back down. Focus on maintaining spinal alignment.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person standing with their back against a wall, performing arm slides up and down the wall while maintaining contact.

exercises.name: Asymmetrical Side Bend & Reach (Concave Stretch)
exercises.instructions: Stand or sit. Reach one arm overhead towards the ceiling, and gently side bend towards the convex side of your curve, feeling a stretch on the concave side. Can be modified with a resistance band or pole.
exercises.dosage: Hold 20-30 seconds, 3-5 repetitions per side
exercises.image_description: Person standing, reaching one arm overhead and gently side bending, illustrating a stretch along the trunk's concave side.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration & Advanced Strengthening
phase_3.goal: Integrate improved posture, strength, and motor control into functional daily activities and sports. Advance core stability, balance, and proprioception. Maintain spinal mobility and prevent curve progression.

exercises.name: Schroth-Inspired Rotational Breathing
exercises.instructions: In various positions (e.g., prone, side-lying, sitting), identify areas of rib prominence and depression. Use conscious breathing to expand depressed areas of the rib cage while stabilizing prominent areas, aiming to derotate the spine. Often done with specific postural corrections.
exercises.dosage: Individualized, 15-20 minutes daily
exercises.image_description: Person in a specific therapeutic position (e.g., prone over a bolster) focusing on asymmetrical breathing to correct spinal rotation.

exercises.name: Plank Variations (with Spinal Neutrality Focus)
exercises.instructions: Perform standard plank, side plank, or dynamic planks (e.g., plank with arm/leg lifts), always maintaining a neutral spine and avoiding compensatory movements. Focus on strong core engagement and preventing hip drop or rotation.
exercises.dosage: Hold 45-60 seconds, 3-4 repetitions
exercises.image_description: Person performing a perfect plank position, emphasizing a straight, neutral spine and strong core.

exercises.name: Dead Bug with Progression
exercises.instructions: Lie supine, knees bent at 90 degrees, arms extended towards the ceiling. Slowly lower one arm and the opposite leg towards the floor without allowing your lower back to arch or lift. Keep your core engaged throughout. Progress by using small weights or resistance bands.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions per side, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine performing the dead bug exercise, extending one arm and the opposite leg while maintaining core stability.

exercises.name: Single Leg Balance with Perturbations
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, maintaining an upright posture. Progress by adding external perturbations (e.g., therapist pushes gently), reaching with arms, or performing on an unstable surface (e.g., foam pad). Focus on maintaining core control and spinal alignment.
exercises.dosage: Hold 30-60 seconds per leg, 3-4 repetitions
exercises.image_description: Person standing on one leg on an unstable surface (e.g., foam pad), maintaining balance and good posture.

exercises.name: Functional Movement Training (e.g., Squats, Lunges with controlled trunk)
exercises.instructions: Perform squats or lunges, paying close attention to maintaining a neutral spine and symmetrical movement. Avoid letting the trunk shift or rotate excessively. Incorporate these movements into daily activities.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets
exercises.image_description: Person performing a squat with proper form, showing a neutral spine and symmetrical body alignment.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment includes detailed patient history (family history of scoliosis, age of onset, previous treatments), physical examination (Adam's forward bend test, scoliometer readings for trunk rotation, plumb line assessment, evaluation of leg length discrepancy, postural analysis, muscle length and strength testing, neurological screen), and imaging (full-spine X-rays to determine Cobb angle, Risser sign for skeletal maturity, curve pattern). Diagnosis of scoliosis is typically confirmed with a Cobb angle of 10 degrees or more.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques may include soft tissue mobilization (e.g., myofascial release, deep tissue massage) to address myofascial restrictions and hypertonic muscles on the concave side or compensatory curves. Joint mobilization or manipulation may be considered for hypomobile spinal segments, particularly in the thoracic and lumbar spine, to improve overall spinal mobility and facilitate better postural alignment. Techniques are applied carefully, considering the spinal curvature and patient's tolerance.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid exercises that significantly increase pain or put excessive rotational or compressive forces on the spine, especially with severe curves or during active growth phases. Close monitoring for any neurological symptoms (numbness, tingling, weakness). Patients with significant curve progression or those post-spinal fusion require individualized modifications and careful consultation with the orthopedic surgeon. In adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, adherence to bracing protocols (if prescribed) is crucial. Avoid heavy axial loading or impact activities without proper core stabilization and postural control.
clinical_notes.scientific_reference: Negrini S, Donzelli S, Aulisa AG, et al. 2016 SOSORT guidelines: orthopaedic and rehabilitation treatment of idiopathic scoliosis during growth. Scoliosis Spinal Disord. 2018;13:3.

clinical_presentation.definition: Achilles tendinitis is an overuse injury of the Achilles tendon, the band of tissue that connects calf muscles at the back of the lower leg to your heel bone. It commonly occurs in runners and people who play sports that involve sudden stops and starts. Symptoms include pain and stiffness along the Achilles tendon, especially in the morning or with activity, and tenderness when the tendon is touched. The condition can manifest as either insertional (at the heel bone attachment) or non-insertional (in the middle portion of the tendon).
clinical_presentation.image_description: Close-up of a person's lower leg and foot, showing the Achilles tendon. A red, inflamed area is visible along the tendon, indicating pain and swelling, with a hand gently palpating the area.

electrotherapy.parameters: Continuous mode, 1.0-1.5 W/cm², 3 MHz frequency (for superficial structures), treatment time 5-7 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Directly over the affected segment of the Achilles tendon using a coupling gel, with the sound head moved slowly in small circles or longitudinal strokes.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce local inflammation, promote tissue healing, increase local circulation, and alleviate pain.
electrotherapy.image_description: Physical therapist applying therapeutic ultrasound with a handheld transducer over the posterior aspect of a patient's lower leg, specifically targeting the Achilles tendon, with gel visible.

electrotherapy.parameters: High-frequency TENS: 80-120 Hz, pulse width 50-100 µs, intensity to a strong but comfortable tingling sensation. Low-frequency TENS: 2-10 Hz, pulse width 150-250 µs, intensity to visible muscle twitch.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed proximally and distally along the Achilles tendon, or surrounding the area of maximal pain. For low-frequency, consider motor points of calf muscles.
electrotherapy.goal: To provide symptomatic pain relief by stimulating sensory nerves (high-frequency) or by promoting endorphin release (low-frequency).
electrotherapy.image_description: Close-up of two surface electrodes placed on a patient's Achilles tendon area, connected to a small TENS unit device.

phase_1.name: Acute Pain Management & Gentle Mobility
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, protect the tendon, maintain pain-free ankle range of motion, and activate supporting musculature without aggravating the tendon.

exercises.name: Ankle Alphabet
exercises.instructions: While seated or lying down, slowly move your foot to 'draw' each letter of the alphabet in the air. Focus on controlled, pain-free movements.
exercises.dosage: 1-2 sets of the entire alphabet, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient seated with leg extended, gently moving their foot to spell letters in the air, demonstrating ankle mobility.

exercises.name: Gentle Ankle Dorsiflexion/Plantarflexion
exercises.instructions: While seated, gently move your foot up (toes towards shin) and down (toes away from shin) within a pain-free range. Avoid pushing into pain.
exercises.dosage: 15-20 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient seated, performing controlled up and down movements of their foot at the ankle joint.

exercises.name: Isometric Plantarflexion
exercises.instructions: In a seated position, gently press the ball of your foot into the floor or against a stable object (like a wall) without moving the ankle. Hold the contraction.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions of 30-45 second holds at a low, pain-free intensity (e.g., 20-30% maximum effort), 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient seated, pressing the ball of their foot against the floor with mild effort, showing no visible movement at the ankle.

phase_2.name: Progressive Strengthening & Tendon Loading
phase_2.goal: Gradually increase the load-bearing capacity and strength of the Achilles tendon and calf musculature, focusing on eccentric control.

exercises.name: Eccentric Heel Drops (from step)
exercises.instructions: Stand on the edge of a step with your heels hanging off. Rise up onto the balls of both feet, then slowly lower your heels below the level of the step using ONLY the affected leg. Use support for balance if needed. Start with knees straight, then progress to bent-knee variations.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time per day or every other day. Progress to single leg.
exercises.image_description: Person standing on a step, slowly lowering one heel below the step's edge, demonstrating an eccentric calf raise with straight knee.

exercises.name: Seated Calf Raises
exercises.instructions: While seated, place a weight on your thighs near your knees. Perform controlled calf raises, lifting your heels off the floor. Focus on full range of motion.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 12-15 repetitions, 1 time per day or every other day.
exercises.image_description: Person seated, performing calf raises with a dumbbell placed across their thighs just above the knees.

exercises.name: Standing Calf Raises (Bilateral then Unilateral)
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Slowly rise onto the balls of both feet, hold briefly, then slowly lower. Progress to performing this on one leg. Start with flat ground, then progress to a step for increased range of motion.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 1 time per day or every other day. Start bilateral, progress to unilateral.
exercises.image_description: Person standing, slowly raising onto the balls of both feet, then lowering, demonstrating a bilateral calf raise.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration & Return to Activity
phase_3.goal: Restore full power, agility, and endurance, preparing the individual for previous activity levels and sport-specific demands.

exercises.name: Plyometric Calf Jumps
exercises.instructions: Perform quick, repetitive small jumps or hops, pushing off the balls of your feet. Start with two feet, then progress to single leg. Focus on minimizing ground contact time.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 15-20 repetitions or 30-60 seconds, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing quick, low-amplitude two-footed jumps, emphasizing explosive calf action.

exercises.name: Bounding and Hopping Drills
exercises.instructions: Progress from small hops to larger bounds, focusing on controlled landings and powerful push-offs. Incorporate forward, lateral, and multi-directional hopping patterns.
exercises.dosage: 3-4 sets of 10-15 reps or 20-30 meters, 2 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Athlete performing a series of single-leg hops forward, demonstrating propulsion and landing control.

exercises.name: Sport-Specific Drills (if applicable)
exercises.instructions: Gradually reintroduce activities specific to the patient's sport or desired activity. This may include cutting, sprinting, jumping, and rapid changes of direction. Start with low intensity and volume, progressively increasing.
exercises.dosage: Begin with 50% intensity/volume, increasing by no more than 10-15% per week as tolerated, with pain monitoring.
exercises.image_description: Soccer player performing cone drills with quick changes of direction on a field, demonstrating agility.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves a thorough history (onset, aggravating/alleviating factors, activity levels), physical examination (palpation for tenderness, swelling, crepitus; range of motion assessment; strength testing of calf complex), and possibly imaging (ultrasound for tissue integrity/inflammation, MRI for differential diagnosis or severe cases). Pain on palpation of the tendon, especially 2-6 cm above the calcaneal insertion (non-insertional) or at the insertion (insertional), is a key finding. Differential diagnoses include partial tear, retrocalcaneal bursitis, or Haglund's deformity.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization techniques (e.g., cross-friction massage, instrument-assisted soft tissue mobilization - IASTM) to the calf muscles (gastrocnemius, soleus) and around the Achilles tendon to reduce muscle guarding, improve tissue extensibility, and promote circulation. Joint mobilization to the ankle and subtalar joints to ensure optimal biomechanics and reduce compensatory stresses on the Achilles tendon. Stretching of the gastrocnemius and soleus (held stretch for 30-60 seconds, 3-5 repetitions).
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid sudden increases in activity intensity or duration, especially eccentric loading, early in rehabilitation. Monitor pain levels closely – exercises should be performed without significant pain (e.g., less than 3/10 on a VAS). Ensure proper footwear with adequate heel support and cushioning. Avoid high heels which can shorten the Achilles. Educate the patient on the importance of gradual progression and consistency. In cases of severe pain or suspected partial/complete rupture, immediate referral for medical imaging and specialist consultation is warranted. Corticosteroid injections around the Achilles are generally avoided due to the risk of tendon rupture.

scientific_reference: Alfredson H, Cook J. A treatment algorithm for managing Achilles tendinopathy. British Journal of Sports Medicine. 2007;41(12):849-853. (This refers to the common eccentric loading protocols for Achilles tendinopathy).

clinical_presentation.definition: Fibromyalgia is a chronic condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Researchers believe that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain and spinal cord process painful and nonpainful signals.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A person, appearing fatigued and somewhat uncomfortable, gently touching their neck or lower back, conveying a sense of widespread, chronic pain and tiredness. The setting is calm and somewhat muted, reflecting the often debilitating nature of the condition.

electrotherapy.parameters: High Frequency (Conventional TENS): 50-100 Hz, Pulse Duration: 50-100 µs, Intensity: Sensory level (strong but comfortable tingling), Duration: 30-60 minutes, as needed.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over specific tender points or areas of localized pain (e.g., upper trapezius, low back, gluteal region). Avoid placing over open wounds or irritated skin.
electrotherapy.goal: To provide symptomatic pain relief by stimulating sensory nerves and activating descending inhibitory pain pathways.
electrotherapy.image_description: TENS unit with two electrodes placed on the upper trapezius muscle of a person, demonstrating targeted pain relief application.

phase_1.name: Gentle Introduction to Movement and Pain Management
phase_1.goal: To initiate activity without exacerbating symptoms, improve flexibility, gentle aerobic conditioning, and enhance body awareness and relaxation.

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, one hand on your chest and one on your abdomen. Breathe deeply, focusing on expanding your abdomen while keeping your chest relatively still. Inhale slowly through your nose, exhale slowly through pursed lips.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with one hand on chest and one on abdomen, demonstrating deep breathing.

exercises.name: Gentle Cat-Cow Stretch
exercises.instructions: Start on hands and knees. Inhale as you drop your belly towards the floor and look up (Cow pose). Exhale as you round your spine towards the ceiling, tucking your chin to your chest (Cat pose). Move slowly and gently, coordinating with breath.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions, 1-2 sets, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person in hands and knees position transitioning between Cat and Cow yoga poses.

exercises.name: Walking (Low Intensity)
exercises.instructions: Begin with very short walks on a flat surface. Focus on a comfortable, easy pace. Monitor symptoms closely and stop if pain increases significantly. Pacing is crucial.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 1 time per day, gradually increasing duration by 1-2 minutes per week as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Person walking slowly and comfortably outdoors on a paved path, appearing relaxed.

exercises.name: Gentle Knee-to-Chest Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back. Gently bring one knee towards your chest, holding behind the thigh or on top of the knee. Hold for 15-20 seconds. Repeat with the other leg. Keep the movement slow and controlled.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 repetitions per leg, 1 set, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, gently pulling one knee towards their chest with hands interlaced behind the thigh.

phase_2.name: Gradual Aerobic Conditioning and Core Stability
phase_2.goal: To improve cardiovascular endurance, begin light strengthening, enhance core stability, and continue promoting active coping strategies for pain.

exercises.name: Stationary Cycling / Elliptical
exercises.instructions: Engage in low-impact aerobic activity. Maintain a light resistance and comfortable pace. Monitor heart rate and perceived exertion (aim for RPE 9-11/20). Gradually increase duration.
exercises.dosage: 15-25 minutes, 3-4 times per week, with rest days.
exercises.image_description: Person using a stationary exercise bike or elliptical machine with a calm, focused expression.

exercises.name: Wall Push-ups
exercises.instructions: Stand facing a wall, about arm's length away. Place hands on the wall slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Lean towards the wall, bending elbows, then push back. Keep body straight.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a wall push-up, hands on the wall, body in a straight line.

exercises.name: Chair Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a sturdy chair. Slowly lower yourself as if to sit, then stand back up. Keep knees tracking over toes. Use hands for balance if needed.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a squat movement, lowering themselves towards a chair without fully sitting.

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilts
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent, feet flat. Flatten your lower back into the floor by tilting your pelvis up slightly, engaging abdominal muscles. Hold for a few seconds, then release. Focus on gentle movement.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, demonstrating a subtle pelvic tilt, flattening lower back to the floor.

phase_3.name: Functional Strengthening and Self-Management
phase_3.goal: To optimize functional independence, strength, and endurance; promote long-term self-management, and integrate lifestyle modifications.

exercises.name: Light Resistance Band Rows
exercises.instructions: Sit or stand with a resistance band anchored to a stable object in front of you (e.g., door anchor). Hold ends of the band and pull elbows back, squeezing shoulder blades together. Maintain good posture.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing resistance band rows, sitting or standing, pulling band towards torso.

exercises.name: Single Leg Stance with Support
exercises.instructions: Stand holding onto a wall or sturdy chair for balance. Lift one foot slightly off the floor. Maintain balance for 15-30 seconds. Progress to unsupported as tolerated.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 repetitions per leg, 2 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person standing on one leg, gently holding onto a wall for support, demonstrating balance.

exercises.name: Step-ups (Low Box)
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a low step or sturdy box (4-6 inches high). Step up with one foot, bringing the other foot to meet it, then step down. Alternate leading legs. Focus on controlled movement.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions per leg, 2 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Person performing step-ups onto a low box or step, demonstrating controlled movement.

exercises.name: Continued Aerobic Activity (Varied)
exercises.instructions: Maintain regular aerobic activity, diversifying options like swimming, brisk walking, cycling, or light hiking. Focus on sustained effort within comfort limits and proper pacing. Incorporate gentle warm-up and cool-down.
exercises.dosage: 30-45 minutes, 3-5 times per week, adjusting intensity and duration based on daily symptoms.
exercises.image_description: Person swimming in a pool with a calm expression, demonstrating a low-impact aerobic activity.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment includes detailed history (pain characteristics, fatigue, sleep disturbances, cognitive function, mood), review of systems to rule out other conditions, Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) or Widespread Pain Index (WPI) and Symptom Severity Scale (SSS). Physical examination focuses on gentle palpation of tender points (not aggressive), range of motion, and muscle strength, noting signs of allodynia or hyperalgesia. Diagnosis typically aligns with ACR criteria.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy should be performed with extreme caution and gentleness. Techniques may include gentle soft tissue mobilization, skin rolling, myofascial release, and grade I/II joint mobilizations to improve local tissue mobility and reduce muscle hypertonicity. Focus on reducing protective guarding and promoting relaxation, rather than aggressive stretching or deep tissue work which can exacerbate symptoms. Techniques for pain modulation and relaxation are prioritized.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid overexertion and post-exertional malaise. Educate patients on pacing activities, energy conservation techniques, and symptom monitoring. Emphasize gradual progression and 'start low, go slow'. Respect pain limits and adjust intensity/duration based on daily fluctuations. Encourage hydration, good sleep hygiene, and stress management. Be aware of potential for symptom flare-ups and teach strategies for self-management during these times. Close communication and patient-centered goal setting are paramount.

scientific_reference: Consensus guidelines from the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and current evidence-based practices in physical therapy for chronic pain conditions and fibromyalgia, emphasizing multidisciplinary approaches including exercise and patient education.

clinical_presentation.definition: A meniscus tear is an injury to one of the C-shaped cartilage discs (menisci) in the knee, located between the tibia and femur. These discs act as shock absorbers and help stabilize the knee joint. Tears can occur acutely due to sudden twisting or pivoting motions, or degeneratively over time, especially in older individuals. Symptoms often include knee pain (especially with twisting or squatting), swelling, stiffness, tenderness along the joint line, and sometimes clicking, catching, or locking of the knee.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Anatomical illustration of the knee joint with an arrow pointing to a torn meniscus, showing the medial and lateral menisci between the femur and tibia. Alternatively, a stock photo of a person holding their knee in pain, indicating knee discomfort.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 80-120 Hz (high frequency); Pulse duration: 50-100 µs; Intensity: Sensory level (strong but comfortable tingling); Treatment time: 20-30 minutes as needed.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed around the painful area of the joint line, typically medial or lateral to the patella, ensuring the pain site is between the electrodes.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain modulation and relief during acute and sub-acute phases.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing electrode placement for TENS around the knee joint line for meniscus pain relief.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 35-50 Hz; Pulse duration: 200-400 µs; Intensity: To elicit a strong visible muscle contraction; On/Off time: 10s On / 30-50s Off; Ramp time: 2-3s; Treatment time: 15-20 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: One electrode over the motor point of the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) and the other over the rectus femoris or proximal quadriceps, to facilitate quadriceps strengthening.
electrotherapy.goal: Prevent muscle atrophy, facilitate quadriceps activation, especially post-surgery or during initial immobilization, and improve strength.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing electrode placement for NMES on the quadriceps muscle of the thigh.

phase_1.name: Acute/Protection Phase (Weeks 0-4)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and swelling, protect the healing meniscus, restore initial range of motion, and initiate quadriceps activation.

exercises.name: Quadriceps Setting
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knee extended or slightly bent. Contract your thigh muscle (quadriceps) by pushing the back of your knee into the surface. Hold the contraction.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, hold for 5-10 seconds, 3-4 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, contracting the quadriceps with the knee slightly bent or extended, with a rolled towel under the knee.

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps
exercises.instructions: Lie or sit comfortably. Point your toes up towards your head, then point them down away from your head. Perform rhythmically.
exercises.dosage: 20-30 repetitions, 3-4 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, performing ankle dorsiflexion and plantarflexion.

exercises.name: Heel Slides (Supine)
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knees straight. Slowly slide your heel towards your buttock, bending your knee as far as comfortable without pain. Then, slowly slide your heel back to the starting position.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day, within pain-free range.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine, sliding heel towards buttocks to bend the knee.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raises (SLR) - Supine
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with the uninjured knee bent and foot flat. Keep the injured leg straight and slowly lift it about 6-12 inches off the ground, keeping the knee straight. Hold briefly and slowly lower.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day, ensuring no knee pain.
exercises.image_description: Person lying supine with one knee bent, lifting the straight leg off the ground.

phase_2.name: Intermediate/Strength Phase (Weeks 4-12)
phase_2.goal: Restore full pain-free range of motion, improve quadriceps and hamstring strength, enhance proprioception and neuromuscular control, and prepare for higher-level activities.

exercises.name: Mini-Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding onto a stable support if needed. Slowly bend your knees, lowering your hips as if sitting in a chair, only going about 30-45 degrees. Keep your heels on the ground and knees behind toes. Return to standing.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a shallow squat, holding onto a chair or wall for balance.

exercises.name: Wall Slides
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart and about 6 inches from the wall. Slowly slide down the wall, bending your knees to about 45-60 degrees, keeping your back flat against the wall. Hold briefly, then slide back up.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a wall slide with their back against a wall, knees bent.

exercises.name: Hamstring Curls (Prone or Standing with band)
exercises.instructions: Lie face down or stand upright with a resistance band around your ankle. Slowly bend your knee, bringing your heel towards your buttock. Control the movement as you lower your leg back down.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Person lying prone, bending knee to bring heel towards buttocks, or standing with a resistance band.

exercises.name: Calf Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Slowly raise up onto the balls of your feet, lifting your heels off the ground. Hold briefly, then slowly lower your heels.
exercises.dosage: 15-20 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
