exercises.image_description: Person standing, rising up onto the balls of their feet for calf raise.

exercises.name: Single Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on your injured leg. Focus on a point in front of you and try to maintain your balance. Progress by closing eyes or standing on an unstable surface.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 30-60 seconds, 3-5 repetitions per day.
exercises.image_description: Person standing on one leg, balancing.

phase_3.name: Advanced/Return to Function Phase (Weeks 12+)
phase_3.goal: Achieve full strength, power, agility, and endurance; return to sport-specific activities or high-level functional tasks, ensuring optimal knee stability and function.

exercises.name: Step-Ups/Step-Downs
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a sturdy step. Step up with the injured leg, then bring the other leg up. Step down leading with the uninjured leg. Reverse for step-downs.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions per leg, 2-3 sets per day. Increase step height as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Person performing step-ups onto a low box or stair.

exercises.name: Lunges (Forward/Lateral)
exercises.instructions: Stand tall. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at approximately a 90-degree angle. Ensure your front knee is over your ankle and your back knee hovers above the ground. Push back to the starting position. Repeat laterally.
exercises.dosage: 10-12 repetitions per leg, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Person performing a forward lunge, showing correct knee alignment.

exercises.name: Plyometric Drills (e.g., Box Jumps, Single Leg Hops)
exercises.instructions: Start with low-impact drills like two-foot hops, progressing to single-leg hops or low box jumps. Land softly, absorbing the impact through the knees and hips.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per week, with adequate rest between sessions. Introduce gradually.
exercises.image_description: Athlete performing a low box jump or single-leg hop, demonstrating proper landing mechanics.

exercises.name: Agility Drills (e.g., Shuttle Runs, Cone Drills)
exercises.instructions: Set up cones and practice change-of-direction movements, short sprints, and cutting drills. Focus on controlled, quick movements.
exercises.dosage: Perform for 15-20 minutes, 2-3 times per week, gradually increasing intensity and complexity.
exercises.image_description: Athlete performing cone drills on a sports field, demonstrating agility.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis of a meniscus tear typically involves a thorough clinical examination, including palpation of the joint line, assessment of range of motion, and special tests such as McMurray's test, Apley's grind test, and Thessaly test. Imaging, particularly Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), is often used to confirm the diagnosis, determine the type and location of the tear, and rule out other knee pathologies.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques may include gentle knee joint mobilizations (e.g., grades I/II distraction or oscillation) to reduce pain and improve joint nutrition, patellar mobilizations to maintain patellofemoral mobility, and soft tissue mobilization/massage to surrounding musculature (quadriceps, hamstrings, gastrocnemius) to address muscle guarding, reduce tension, and improve flexibility. Specific meniscal mobilization techniques might be cautiously used by experienced therapists to improve meniscal motion or reduce impingement, but care must be taken to respect tissue healing and avoid aggravating the tear.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid deep squatting, twisting, pivoting, and high-impact activities during the initial healing phases, especially for repaired tears, as these can re-injure the meniscus. Respect pain as a guide; activities causing sharp pain, clicking, or locking should be avoided or modified. Monitor for increased swelling or instability. Progress exercises gradually, ensuring adequate rest and recovery. For surgically repaired menisci, strict adherence to weight-bearing restrictions and range of motion limitations imposed by the surgeon is critical. Degenerative tears may require longer rehabilitation or focus more on symptom management and compensatory strategies.

scientific_reference: Evidence-based guidelines for rehabilitation after meniscal injury and repair, published in reputable orthopedic or physical therapy journals (e.g., J Orthop Sports Phys Ther, Am J Sports Med).

clinical_presentation.definition: ACL reconstruction is a surgical procedure to replace a torn anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) with a graft, typically from the patellar tendon, hamstring tendon, or quadriceps tendon. Post-operatively, patients typically present with knee pain, swelling, quadriceps inhibition, limited range of motion (especially flexion), and often require crutches and a knee brace for initial protection and support.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A patient sitting on an examination plinth with their knee elevated, wearing a post-operative knee brace. They are applying an ice pack to their knee, with crutches resting nearby.

electrotherapy.parameters: Waveform: Biphasic pulsed current. Frequency: 50-75 Hz. Pulse Duration: 200-400 µs. Ramp Up/Down: 2-3 seconds. On/Off Time: 10 seconds On / 30-50 seconds Off. Treatment Duration: 15-20 minutes, 1-2 times/day.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Two large electrodes placed over the quadriceps muscle belly, typically with one electrode over the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO) and the other proximally over the rectus femoris/quadriceps bulk. Ensure electrodes do not cross the joint line.
electrotherapy.goal: To facilitate quadriceps muscle activation, combat post-operative arthrogenic inhibition, improve muscle strength, and reduce atrophy. The patient should achieve a strong, visible, and palpable contraction.
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram showing the placement of two large square electrodes over the quadriceps muscle of a patient's post-operative knee, just proximal to the patella.

phase_1.name: Protection & Early Motion (Weeks 0-4)
phase_1.goal: Control pain and swelling, achieve full passive knee extension, restore quadriceps activation, protect the graft, and establish controlled weight-bearing.

exercises.name: Quadriceps Sets
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with the knee extended. Press the back of your knee into the bed or plinth, tightening your thigh muscle. Hold the contraction.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 5-10 second hold, 3-4 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine, contracting the quadriceps muscle on the involved leg with the knee fully extended.

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back or sit with legs extended. Actively move your foot up and down at the ankle (dorsiflexion and plantarflexion).
exercises.dosage: 15-20 repetitions, 3-4 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Close-up of a patient's foot performing rhythmic dorsiflexion and plantarflexion movements.

exercises.name: Heel Slides (Assisted or Active)
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back. Slowly slide your heel towards your buttocks, bending your knee. Use your hands or a strap if needed for assistance. Return to starting position.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 3-4 sets per day, progressing knee flexion as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine, sliding their heel along the bed towards their buttocks to achieve knee flexion.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise (SLR) - Supine
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, keeping the knee of the involved leg straight and quadriceps contracted. Lift the leg slowly to about 45 degrees, then slowly lower it. Ensure no lag at the knee.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine, lifting their involved leg straight up with the knee extended, about 45 degrees off the surface.

exercises.name: Patellar Mobilizations
exercises.instructions: Gently move the patella superiorly, inferiorly, medially, and laterally with your fingertips. Ensure the quadriceps are relaxed.
exercises.dosage: 5 minutes per direction, 3-4 times per day.
exercises.image_description: A physical therapist's hands gently mobilizing the patella on a patient's knee.

phase_2.name: Strength & Neuromuscular Control (Weeks 4-12)
phase_2.goal: Restore full knee range of motion, improve lower extremity strength and endurance, enhance proprioception and neuromuscular control, and normalize gait.

exercises.name: Mini Squats (Closed Chain)
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Slowly squat down to approximately 0-45 degrees of knee flexion, keeping weight through your heels. Return to standing.
exercises.dosage: 15-20 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing a shallow squat, maintaining an upright trunk and knees behind toes.

exercises.name: Wall Slides / Wall Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall. Slide down slowly into a squat position (45-60 degrees knee flexion), hold briefly, then slide back up. Keep core engaged.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 5-10 second hold, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient with their back against a wall, sliding down into a partial squat position.

exercises.name: Prone Hamstring Curls (Light Resistance)
exercises.instructions: Lie face down with legs extended. Slowly bend the knee of the involved leg, bringing your heel towards your buttocks. Use light ankle weights or a resistance band.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying prone, performing a hamstring curl with a light ankle weight.

exercises.name: Calf Raises (Double or Single Leg)
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet flat. Slowly raise up onto the balls of your feet, hold briefly at the top, and lower slowly. Progress to single leg.
exercises.dosage: 15-20 repetitions (double leg), 10-15 repetitions (single leg), 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing, raising up onto their toes for a calf raise.

exercises.name: Single Leg Stance / Balance Exercises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the involved leg, maintaining balance. Progress by closing eyes, standing on an unstable surface (e.g., foam pad), or adding arm movements.
exercises.dosage: 30-60 second hold, 3-5 repetitions per leg, 2-3 sets per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing on one leg, maintaining balance, with eyes open.

exercises.name: Stationary Cycling
exercises.instructions: Use a stationary bike with light to moderate resistance, focusing on smooth, pain-free pedaling. Start with higher seat to reduce knee flexion, gradually lower.
exercises.dosage: 15-30 minutes, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient cycling on a stationary bike in a rehabilitation gym.

phase_3.name: Return to Sport & Advanced Training (Weeks 12-24+ based on criteria)
phase_3.goal: Maximize strength, power, agility, and endurance; develop sport-specific skills; and meet objective criteria for safe return to sport activities.

exercises.name: Plyometric Jumps (Box Jumps/Forward Hops)
exercises.instructions: Jump onto a low box or hop forward, focusing on soft landings and controlled deceleration. Progress height/distance and complexity.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Athlete performing a box jump onto a low plyometric box.

exercises.name: Agility Drills (Cone Drills/Shuttle Runs)
exercises.instructions: Perform various drills involving cutting, weaving, and directional changes around cones or between markers. Start with controlled movements, progress to higher speed and intensity.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 sets of various patterns, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Athlete performing a cone drill, rapidly changing direction.

exercises.name: Single Leg Hops for Distance/Time
exercises.instructions: Hop on the involved leg for maximal distance or for a set time, focusing on control, stability, and equal performance compared to the uninvolved leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 5-10 hops for distance, or 30-60 second holds for time, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Athlete performing a single leg hop across a gym floor.

exercises.name: Sport-Specific Drills
exercises.instructions: Incorporate drills that mimic the movements, demands, and conditions of the patient's specific sport (e.g., throwing, dribbling, swinging, jumping, running patterns).
exercises.dosage: Progressive increase in intensity, volume, and complexity based on sport demands and tolerance.
exercises.image_description: Basketball player performing a dribbling and shooting drill on a court.

exercises.name: Advanced Strength Training (e.g., Squats, Lunges, Deadlifts)
exercises.instructions: Perform multi-joint exercises with increasing resistance, emphasizing proper form, symmetrical loading, and progressive overload to build maximal strength and power.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing a barbell back squat with good form in a gym.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Post-surgical diagnosis of ACL reconstruction. Key assessments include goniometric measurement of knee range of motion (full extension is paramount), circumferential measurements for swelling, Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, manual muscle testing (MMT) and dynamometry for quadriceps and hamstring strength, gait analysis, balance tests (e.g., BESS, Star Excursion Balance Test), and functional hop tests (e.g., single hop for distance, triple hop for distance, crossover hop for distance) in later phases. Graft integrity is assumed post-surgically, but any clinical signs of instability or persistent locking/clicking warrant immediate medical consultation.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Aggressive patellar mobilizations (superior, inferior, medial, lateral) are crucial from early post-op to prevent arthrofibrosis and restore patellar mobility, which is essential for achieving full knee flexion and extension. Soft tissue mobilization to the quadriceps, hamstrings, gastrocnemius, and surrounding musculature to address muscle guarding, reduce adhesions, and improve tissue extensibility. Gentle joint mobilizations (e.g., posterior glide of tibia on femur, anterior glide of femur on tibia) can be introduced cautiously in later phases to restore accessory motion as tolerated, always respecting graft healing and patient symptoms.
clinical_notes.precautions: 1. **Graft Protection**: Avoid open-chain terminal knee extension (0-30 degrees) with resistance in early to mid-phases, especially if a hamstring or patellar tendon graft was used, due to high anterior shear forces on the healing graft. Quadriceps graft may tolerate it sooner but caution is still advised. 2. **Weight-Bearing**: Strict adherence to the surgeon's prescribed weight-bearing protocol is critical in the initial weeks. 3. **Range of Motion**: Early achievement of full passive knee extension is paramount. Avoid forceful or aggressive knee flexion beyond comfort in early phases to prevent overstretching or damaging the healing graft. 4. **Pain & Swelling**: Monitor and manage pain and swelling diligently. Persistent or increasing pain/swelling should prompt a re-evaluation of the exercise program or referral back to the surgeon. Exercises should not cause pain greater than 3/10. 5. **Return to Sport**: Return to high-impact or pivoting sports should be based on objective criteria (e.g., strength >90% contralateral limb, passing functional hop tests, psychological readiness) rather than solely on time post-op (typically a minimum of 9-12 months). The risk of re-injury is highest within the first year.

scientific_reference: Wright, R. W., Magnussen, R. A., & Dunn, W. R. (2015). ACL Reconstruction Rehabilitation: A Systematic Review of Current Evidence and Clinical Implications. Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy, 45(10), 738-750.

clinical_presentation.definition: Piriformis syndrome is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by deep gluteal pain, often radiating down the posterior thigh, mimicking sciatica. It occurs when the piriformis muscle, located deep in the buttock, irritates or compresses the sciatic nerve due to spasm, hypertrophy, or inflammation. It is often exacerbated by activities such as prolonged sitting, walking, or running.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Patient pointing to the deep buttock region, indicating pain, with a potential referral pattern down the back of the leg. The image should convey discomfort and illustrate the common pain location for piriformis syndrome.

electrotherapy.parameters: High Frequency (Conventional TENS): Frequency 50-100 Hz, Pulse Duration 50-100 µs. Intensity: Sensory level (strong but comfortable tingling). Duration: 20-30 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Two electrodes placed directly over the piriformis muscle (typically midway between the greater trochanter and the sacrum), or one electrode superior and one inferior to the piriformis muscle belly.
electrotherapy.goal: Acute pain modulation, reduction of muscle spasm, and improved patient comfort.
electrotherapy.image_description: TENS electrode placement over the right piriformis muscle, showing two electrodes placed to encompass the muscle belly.

electrotherapy.parameters: Carrier Frequency: 4000 Hz. Beat Frequency: 80-150 Hz (for pain modulation). Intensity: Strong sensory or mild motor twitch. Duration: 15-20 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Four electrodes arranged in a criss-cross pattern surrounding the piriformis muscle to create an interference field deep within the tissue.
electrotherapy.goal: Deeper pain relief, reduction of muscle spasm, and improved local circulation.
electrotherapy.image_description: IFC electrode placement in a criss-cross pattern over the deep gluteal region, targeting the piriformis muscle with the intersection of the currents.

phase_1.name: Acute/Subacute Phase: Pain Modulation & Gentle Mobility
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain, decrease muscle spasm, gently improve piriformis and hip external rotator flexibility, and initiate core stability.

exercises.name: Supine Piriformis Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Place the ankle of the affected leg on the opposite knee (Figure-4 position). Gently pull the unaffected knee towards your chest until a stretch is felt in the gluteal region of the affected leg.
exercises.dosage: Hold 30 seconds, 3-5 repetitions, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine, performing a Figure-4 stretch by pulling the non-affected knee towards the chest, stretching the piriformis of the affected leg.

exercises.name: Seated Piriformis Stretch
exercises.instructions: Sit upright in a chair. Place the ankle of the affected leg on the opposite knee. Lean forward with a straight back, gently pressing down on the knee of the affected leg, until a stretch is felt in the buttock.
exercises.dosage: Hold 30 seconds, 3-5 repetitions, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient seated in a chair, performing a Figure-4 stretch, leaning forward with good posture, stretching the piriformis.

exercises.name: Gentle Gluteal Isometrics
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Gently tighten your gluteal muscles as if trying to bring your buttocks together, without moving your hips or back. Hold the contraction.
exercises.dosage: Hold 5-10 seconds, 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine with knees bent, demonstrating a subtle gluteal contraction without visible movement, focusing on isometric activation.

phase_2.name: Recovery Phase: Strengthening & Stability
phase_2.goal: To improve strength of hip abductors, external rotators, and core stabilizers; further increase flexibility; and prepare for functional activities.

exercises.name: Clamshells
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with knees bent at 90 degrees and hips bent at 45 degrees, feet together. Keep your heels touching and slowly lift your top knee towards the ceiling, without letting your pelvis roll backward. Lower slowly.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day (can add resistance band).
exercises.image_description: Patient lying on their side, performing a clamshell exercise with knees bent, lifting the top knee while keeping feet together.

exercises.name: Glute Bridges
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat, hip-width apart. Engage your glutes and lift your hips off the floor until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. Hold briefly, then lower slowly.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine, performing a glute bridge, with hips lifted off the ground, forming a straight line from shoulders to knees.

exercises.name: Side-Lying Hip Abduction
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with the affected leg on top, both legs straight. Keep your top leg straight and lift it towards the ceiling, maintaining a neutral pelvis. Lower slowly.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying on their side, performing a straight leg raise (hip abduction), lifting the top leg towards the ceiling.

exercises.name: Bird-Dog
exercises.instructions: Start on all fours with hands directly under shoulders and knees under hips. Keep your core engaged and back flat. Slowly extend one arm forward and the opposite leg straight back, maintaining balance. Return to start and alternate sides.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions per side, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient on all fours, demonstrating the bird-dog exercise with the right arm extended forward and the left leg extended backward, maintaining a neutral spine.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration Phase: Dynamic Stability & Return to Activity
phase_3.goal: To restore full functional capacity, improve dynamic control and neuromuscular coordination, prevent recurrence, and safely return to sport/activity.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, maintaining balance. Progress by closing eyes, performing on an unstable surface (e.g., pillow), or performing dynamic movements with the unsupported leg.
exercises.dosage: Hold 30-60 seconds, 3-5 repetitions per leg, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing on one leg, maintaining balance, with the other leg slightly lifted and bent at the knee.

exercises.name: Lateral Band Walks
exercises.instructions: Place a resistance band around your ankles or just above your knees. Stand with knees slightly bent and feet hip-width apart. Take small, controlled steps sideways, maintaining tension on the band. Alternate directions.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 steps in each direction, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing lateral band walks, with a resistance band around their ankles, taking small steps sideways.

exercises.name: Lunges (Forward/Lateral/Curtsy)
exercises.instructions: Perform various lunge patterns (forward, lateral, curtsy) with good form, ensuring knee tracks over toes and maintaining core stability. Progress by adding weights.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions per leg/direction, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient demonstrating a forward lunge, with one leg stepping forward and both knees bent at 90 degrees.

exercises.name: Step-Ups/Downs
exercises.instructions: Using a step or box, step up with one leg, pushing through the heel, bringing the other leg up. Step down slowly and controlled. Alternate leading leg. Progress to higher steps or plyometric step-ups.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions per leg, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing a step-up onto a low box, engaging glutes and quadriceps.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on patient history, palpation, and specific provocative tests. Key findings include: deep gluteal pain, tenderness over the piriformis muscle, pain with resisted hip external rotation/abduction, positive Piriformis Stretch Test (e.g., FAIR test - Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation), and ruling out lumbar radiculopathy (negative straight leg raise, normal neurological screen for motor/sensory deficits, absence of specific dermatomal/myotomal patterns typical of disc herniation). Differential diagnoses include sacroiliac joint dysfunction, hamstring pathology, and lumbar spine conditions.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization techniques (e.g., deep tissue massage, myofascial release, trigger point release) targeting the piriformis muscle and surrounding gluteal musculature (gluteus medius, minimus, obturator internus, gemelli). Strain-counterstrain or Muscle Energy Techniques (MET) may be used to relax the piriformis and improve hip mobility. Sacroiliac joint mobilization or manipulation may be indicated if concurrent SIJ hypomobility or dysfunction is identified.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate symptoms, especially prolonged sitting on hard surfaces or sustained hip external rotation. Gradual progression of exercises, respecting pain levels (pain should not exceed 3/10 during or after exercises). Monitor for any worsening neurological symptoms (e.g., increased numbness, weakness, foot drop), which may indicate a more severe sciatic nerve compression or a different underlying pathology. Patient education on proper posture, body mechanics, and avoiding positions that compress the piriformis is crucial for prevention of recurrence.

scientific_reference: Journal of Orthopaedic & Sports Physical Therapy (JOSPT) for evidence-based practice in musculoskeletal rehabilitation.

clinical_presentation.definition: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS) is a complex condition characterized by compression of the neurovascular structures (brachial plexus, subclavian artery, and/or subclavian vein) in the thoracic outlet, the space between the clavicle and first rib. Symptoms vary depending on the structures compressed but commonly include pain, numbness, tingling, weakness, discoloration, or swelling in the neck, shoulder, arm, and hand. Compression can be neurogenic (most common), arterial, or venous.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Anatomical diagram illustrating the thoracic outlet space with the clavicle, first rib, anterior and middle scalene muscles, and pectoralis minor muscle, showing the brachial plexus, subclavian artery, and subclavian vein passing through, highlighting potential compression points.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: High frequency (80-120 Hz), short pulse duration (50-100 µs), sensory level intensity (strong but comfortable without muscle contraction), continuous mode, 30-60 minutes, 1-3 times daily as needed for pain.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over the most painful areas in the supraclavicular fossa, cervical paraspinals, or along the course of radiating pain into the arm. For specific muscle spasm, electrodes can be placed over the involved muscle belly (e.g., scalenes, upper trapezius).
electrotherapy.goal: Pain modulation and symptomatic relief by stimulating large afferent nerve fibers, activating descending inhibitory pathways, or promoting endorphin release.
electrotherapy.image_description: Illustration of TENS electrode placement for neck and shoulder pain, showing electrodes positioned over the supraclavicular area or cervical paraspinal muscles.

phase_1.name: Phase 1: Acute/Subacute - Pain Management & Postural Awareness
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, alleviate neural/vascular compression, improve awareness of optimal posture, initiate gentle mobility without symptom provocation.

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent. Place one hand on your chest and the other on your abdomen. Breathe deeply, allowing your abdomen to rise while your chest remains relatively still. Focus on slow, controlled breaths, exhaling fully.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 3-5 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying supine, demonstrating diaphragmatic breathing with one hand on chest and one on abdomen, showing abdominal rise with inspiration.

exercises.name: Gentle Cervical Retractions (Chin Tucks)
exercises.instructions: Sit or stand tall. Gently pull your chin straight back, as if making a 'double chin,' keeping your head level. Avoid tilting your head up or down. Hold for 3-5 seconds and relax. Perform slowly and smoothly.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient sitting upright, demonstrating a chin tuck exercise, pulling the head straight back horizontally.

exercises.name: Scapular Depressions and Retractions (Gentle)
exercises.instructions: Sit or stand with good posture. Gently depress your shoulder blades downwards and then retract them together towards your spine, as if trying to pinch a pencil between them. Avoid shrugging the shoulders. Hold for 3-5 seconds and relax.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing, demonstrating gentle scapular depression and retraction, with shoulders down and back, chest open.

exercises.name: Pectoralis Minor Stretch (Corner/Doorway)
exercises.instructions: Stand in a corner or doorway with forearms on the wall/frame, elbows slightly below shoulder height. Step forward gently until a stretch is felt across the chest. Keep shoulders relaxed and avoid hyperextending your neck. Hold for 20-30 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 repetitions, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing in a doorway, performing a pectoralis minor stretch with forearms on the doorframe, leaning gently forward.

phase_2.name: Phase 2: Intermediate - Strengthening & Mobility Restoration
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and endurance of scapular stabilizers, lengthen shortened muscles (scalenes, pectoralis minor), improve neural mobility, and normalize posture during functional activities.

exercises.name: Scalene Muscle Stretch
exercises.instructions: Sit upright. To stretch the right scalenes, gently tilt your head to the left and rotate your chin towards your left armpit. You can use your left hand to gently increase the stretch. Avoid shrugging. Hold for 20-30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 repetitions per side, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient sitting, demonstrating a scalene stretch by tilting head to one side and rotating chin towards the armpit on the same side as the tilt.

exercises.name: Nerve Glides (Median Nerve)
exercises.instructions: Stand with arm abducted 90 degrees, elbow extended, wrist dorsiflexed, and fingers extended (like pushing a wall away). Gently tilt your head away from your hand while simultaneously extending your wrist and fingers. Then, reverse by tilting head towards hand and flexing wrist. Perform slowly and rhythmically within a pain-free range.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing, demonstrating median nerve glide, showing arm abduction, elbow extension, wrist dorsiflexion, and head tilt away from the outstretched hand.

exercises.name: Seated Rows with Resistance Band
exercises.instructions: Sit with legs extended, resistance band looped around feet. Hold ends of band. Keep back straight, shoulder blades depressed and retracted. Pull elbows back towards your body, squeezing shoulder blades together. Control the return to the starting position.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient seated on the floor, performing rows with a resistance band looped around feet, demonstrating scapular retraction and good upright posture.

exercises.name: Wall Angels
exercises.instructions: Stand with back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart, knees slightly bent. Press lower back, head, and forearms (palms facing wall) against the wall. Slowly slide arms up the wall as high as possible while maintaining contact, then slide back down. Focus on keeping shoulder blades down and back throughout the movement.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing against a wall, performing wall angels, with arms sliding up and down the wall while maintaining contact of head, back, and forearms.

phase_3.name: Phase 3: Advanced - Functional Integration & Endurance Training
phase_3.goal: Improve muscular endurance for sustained postural control, progressively strengthen the upper quarter for functional and occupational demands, return to full activity, and educate on long-term prevention strategies.

exercises.name: Overhead Press (Light Weights)
exercises.instructions: Stand or sit with light dumbbells. Press weights overhead with good posture, keeping core engaged and shoulder blades stable. Control the lowering phase slowly. Start with low weight and focus on perfect form, avoiding shrugging.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing, performing an overhead press with light dumbbells, demonstrating controlled movement and good posture, shoulders down and back.

exercises.name: Farmer's Carry
exercises.instructions: Hold a moderately heavy dumbbell or kettlebell in one or both hands. Walk a set distance maintaining good upright posture, with shoulders depressed and retracted, avoiding shrugging or leaning. Gradually increase distance or weight as tolerated.
exercises.dosage: Walk for 30-60 seconds, 3-5 repetitions, 2-3 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient walking, demonstrating a farmer's carry with a kettlebell in each hand, maintaining upright posture and stable shoulders.

exercises.name: Postural Endurance Exercises (e.g., Supported Plank Variations)
exercises.instructions: Perform plank variations focusing on maintaining a neutral spine and stable shoulder girdle. Start with knee planks, progressing to full planks, holding for extended periods. Focus on core and scapular stability, avoiding sagging or hiking hips.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 30-60 seconds, 3-5 repetitions, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing a full plank exercise, demonstrating a straight line from head to heels, with engaged core and stable shoulders.

exercises.name: Ergonomic Assessment and Modification
exercises.instructions: Review and modify workstation setup, daily habits (e.g., carrying heavy bags, sleeping posture, prolonged overhead activities), and recreational activities to minimize positions that compress the thoracic outlet. Focus on maintaining optimal posture and taking frequent movement breaks.
exercises.dosage: Ongoing education and self-management, daily integration.
exercises.image_description: Illustration of an ergonomically correct workstation setup, showing proper chair height, monitor placement, keyboard/mouse position, and a person sitting with good posture.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis of TOS is primarily clinical, based on patient history (symptoms provoked by overhead activities, sustained postures, or carrying heavy objects) and a thorough physical examination. Key diagnostic tests include provocative maneuvers such as Adson's test, Roos test (elevated arm stress test), Wright's test, and costoclavicular maneuver, which aim to reproduce or exacerbate symptoms. Palpation of supraclavicular fossa for tenderness, muscle hypertrophy (e.g., scalenes), or palpable supraclavicular mass is important. Differential diagnosis includes cervical radiculopathy, carpal tunnel syndrome, cubital tunnel syndrome, and rotator cuff pathology. Electrophysiological studies (nerve conduction velocity, EMG) and vascular studies (Doppler ultrasound, angiography) may be used to confirm neurovascular involvement or rule out other conditions.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques play a crucial role in TOS rehabilitation. This includes soft tissue mobilization and myofascial release for tight muscles in the neck, shoulder, and chest, such as the scalenes, sternocleidomastoid, pectoralis minor, and upper trapezius. Trigger point release may also be indicated. Joint mobilization/manipulation (Grade I-V) may be performed on the cervical and thoracic spine, first rib, and sternoclavicular/acromioclavicular joints to improve segmental mobility and reduce mechanical compression. Neural mobilization techniques (nerve gliding/flossing) are essential to improve the mobility of the brachial plexus and reduce neural tension. Proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) techniques can also be incorporated to improve motor control and muscle activation patterns. Postural correction and education are integrated throughout the treatment plan.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities, positions, and exercises that significantly provoke or worsen symptoms, especially those involving sustained overhead arm positions, repetitive arm movements, or heavy lifting. Monitor closely for signs of worsening neurological (e.g., increased numbness, weakness, paresthesia, loss of fine motor control) or vascular (e.g., skin discoloration, swelling, coldness, claudication, loss of pulse) compromise. Patient education is vital regarding appropriate pacing, symptom monitoring, and avoiding overexertion. Ensure all exercises are performed within a pain-free range. Refer back to the physician if symptoms escalate, new red flag symptoms emerge (e.g., acute vascular changes, signs of infection, unexplained weight loss), or if conservative management fails to provide adequate relief.
clinical_notes.scientific_reference: Watson, L. A., & Pizzari, T. (2018). Thoracic Outlet Syndrome: A 2018 Update. Physical Therapy in Sport, 30, 48-55.

clinical_presentation.definition: De Quervain's tenosynovitis is a painful condition affecting the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist. It involves inflammation and swelling of the synovial sheath surrounding the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons, located in the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. This inflammation can cause pain and tenderness at the base of the thumb and along the radial side of the wrist, especially with gripping, pinching, or making a fist.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Close-up of a patient's wrist showing mild swelling and tenderness at the radial styloid process, with the thumb held in adduction. The patient may be performing a Finkelstein's test.

electrotherapy.parameters: Pulsed mode, 1 MHz frequency, 1.0-1.5 W/cm² intensity, 1:4 or 1:5 duty cycle (20% pulsed), 5-7 minutes duration.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Directly over the radial styloid process, targeting the first dorsal compartment where the APL and EPB tendons are located. Apply ultrasound gel generously.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce inflammation, decrease pain, promote tissue healing, and improve local circulation.
electrotherapy.image_description: Physical therapist applying ultrasound gel and then moving an ultrasound transducer in small, circular motions over the radial side of a patient's wrist near the base of the thumb.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional (high frequency) TENS: Frequency 80-120 Hz, pulse duration 50-100 µs, intensity to strong sensory but comfortable level (no motor response), 20-30 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed proximally and distally to the painful area over the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. Avoid direct placement over bony prominences.
electrotherapy.goal: Provide symptomatic pain relief by activating the gate control theory of pain and potentially stimulating endogenous opioid release.
electrotherapy.image_description: Patient with two small square electrodes affixed to the skin along the radial aspect of their wrist, connected by wires to a portable TENS unit.

phase_1.name: Acute/Subacute Phase: Pain & Inflammation Management, Gentle Mobilization
phase_1.goal: Decrease pain and inflammation, protect the injured tendons, maintain gentle, pain-free range of motion, and prevent stiffness.

exercises.name: Gentle Wrist and Thumb Range of Motion (ROM)
exercises.instructions: Passively and actively move the wrist and thumb through pain-free ranges. This includes wrist flexion/extension, ulnar/radial deviation, and thumb opposition, flexion, and extension of the MCP and IP joints. Avoid any movements that reproduce pain, especially extreme ulnar deviation with thumb adduction.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 3-5 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient gently moving their wrist in flexion and extension, then gently moving their thumb into opposition towards the little finger, demonstrating controlled, pain-free movements.

exercises.name: Tendon Glides (Thumb)
exercises.instructions: Slowly and gently move your thumb through various positions, such as making a fist with the thumb outside, then moving the thumb to touch the base of your index finger, then your little finger. Focus on smooth, pain-free movement to encourage gliding of the tendons within their sheath.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per position, 2-3 sets, 2-3 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Close-up of a hand performing a thumb tendon glide sequence, showing the thumb moving from an extended position to touching the base of different fingers.

exercises.name: Cryotherapy Application
exercises.instructions: Apply an ice pack or cold compress (wrapped in a thin towel) directly over the painful area on the radial side of the wrist for 15-20 minutes.
exercises.dosage: 15-20 minutes, 3-4 times per day, especially after activity or if pain increases.
exercises.image_description: Person applying an ice pack, wrapped in a thin blue towel, to the radial side of their wrist near the thumb base.

phase_2.name: Intermediate Phase: Progressive Strengthening & Functional Recovery
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and endurance of wrist and thumb musculature, enhance functional use of the hand, and gradually increase load tolerance.

exercises.name: Isometric Thumb Abduction/Extension
exercises.instructions: Place your opposite hand over your thumb and gently resist as you attempt to abduct (move away from palm) or extend your thumb. Hold the contraction without movement for 5-7 seconds. Ensure no pain is provoked.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times per day.
exercises.image_description: Patient using their non-affected hand to provide gentle resistance against their affected thumb, which is attempting to move away from the palm (abduction).

exercises.name: TheraBand Wrist Exercises (Radial/Ulnar Deviation, Flexion/Extension)
exercises.instructions: Using a light resistance band, perform controlled wrist radial deviation, ulnar deviation, flexion, and extension. Secure one end of the band under your foot or a stable object, and hold the other end with your affected hand. Maintain a neutral forearm position.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day, gradually increasing resistance as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing wrist radial deviation with a light yellow resistance band, with the forearm stabilized on a table.

exercises.name: Grip and Pinch Strengthening (Soft Ball/Putty)
exercises.instructions: Gently squeeze a soft stress ball or therapy putty for 3-5 seconds, then slowly release. For pinch strengthening, pinch a small piece of putty between your thumb and index finger, or thumb and other fingers.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day.
exercises.image_description: Hand gently squeezing a soft blue stress ball, then demonstrating a key pinch with therapy putty.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase: Functional Integration & Return to Activity
phase_3.goal: Optimize strength, endurance, and coordination for activity-specific demands, gradually return to full functional activities, and implement strategies for recurrence prevention.

exercises.name: Progressive Resistance Training for Thumb & Wrist
exercises.instructions: Advance previous strengthening exercises by gradually increasing resistance using heavier weights, stronger resistance bands, or more challenging putty. Incorporate functional movements that mimic daily tasks, such as lifting light objects with a palmar pinch or carrying items.
exercises.dosage: 8-12 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1 time per day, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: Patient using a small dumbbell (1-2 lbs) for wrist strengthening exercises (e.g., wrist curls, radial deviation) while seated with forearm supported.

exercises.name: Fine Motor Dexterity Drills
exercises.instructions: Practice tasks requiring fine motor control and precision grip, such as picking up small objects (coins, beads), manipulating buttons, turning keys, or writing. Gradually increase the complexity and duration of these tasks.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 minutes, 1-2 times per day, as tolerated.
exercises.image_description: Close-up of a hand carefully picking up small scattered coins from a table surface.

exercises.name: Ergonomic Assessment and Activity Modification
exercises.instructions: Identify and modify aggravating activities at work, home, or hobbies that involve repetitive thumb abduction with ulnar deviation or sustained gripping/pinching. Educate on proper wrist and thumb posture during tasks, recommending neutral wrist positions and utilizing adaptive equipment (e.g., larger grip handles, ergonomic tools) as needed.
exercises.dosage: Ongoing education and implementation in daily life.
exercises.image_description: Person demonstrating proper ergonomic posture at a computer workstation, with wrists in a neutral position while typing, and an emphasis on minimizing repetitive thumb movements.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis typically involves a thorough history and physical examination. Key findings often include localized pain and tenderness over the radial styloid process, particularly over the first dorsal compartment. A positive Finkelstein's test (pain provoked by grasping the thumb into the palm and then ulnarly deviating the wrist) is a hallmark sign. Differential diagnoses include carpometacarpal (CMC) joint osteoarthritis, intersection syndrome, scaphoid fracture, and radial nerve irritation. Imaging studies like X-rays (to rule out bony pathology) or ultrasound (to visualize tendon swelling) may be used.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Once acute inflammation is under control, manual therapy can include gentle soft tissue mobilization or cross-friction massage to the APL and EPB tendons to improve tissue mobility and reduce adhesions. Joint mobilizations to the radio-carpal, mid-carpal, and carpometacarpal (CMC) joints of the thumb may be performed to improve accessory motion and reduce compensatory stresses on the affected tendons. Neural gliding techniques for the superficial radial nerve may also be considered if nerve irritation is suspected.
clinical_notes.precautions: Strict avoidance of activities that exacerbate pain is crucial, especially repetitive thumb abduction with ulnar deviation, forceful gripping, or pinching. Patients should be educated on proper body mechanics and activity modification. Splinting (e.g., a thumb spica splint or brace that immobilizes the thumb and wrist) may be used in the acute phase to provide rest and support for the tendons. Monitor for signs of increased inflammation, persistent pain, or any symptoms suggestive of nerve irritation. Gradual progression of exercises is essential to prevent re-aggravation.

scientific_reference: Kisner, C., & Colby, L. A. (2017). Therapeutic Exercise: Foundations and Techniques (7th ed.). F.A. Davis Company.

clinical_presentation.definition: Temporomandibular Joint Dysfunction (TMJD) refers to a collection of conditions causing pain and dysfunction in the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and the muscles of mastication. Symptoms often include jaw pain, headaches, clicking or popping sounds in the jaw, limited jaw opening, difficulty chewing, earaches, and facial pain. It can arise from various factors including trauma, bruxism (teeth grinding), clenching, arthritis, poor posture, stress, and malocclusion.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A person gently touching their jaw area, indicating pain or discomfort in the temporomandibular joint, possibly with a slightly open mouth or a look of mild distress. Close-up on the jaw and lower face.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: Frequency 80-120 Hz, Pulse Width 50-100 µs, Intensity to a strong but comfortable tingling sensation. Duration: 20-30 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Two electrodes placed over the affected masseter muscle and two over the temporalis muscle, or one over the preauricular area of the TMJ and one over the masseter muscle. Ensure electrodes do not overlap.
electrotherapy.goal: Pain modulation, reduction of muscle spasm, and improved tolerance for therapeutic exercises.
electrotherapy.image_description: A close-up of a person's face with small TENS electrodes placed over the masseter and temporalis muscles near the TMJ.

electrotherapy.parameters: Pulsed Ultrasound: 1 MHz for deeper structures, 3 MHz for superficial. Duty Cycle: 20-50%. Intensity: 0.5-1.5 W/cm². Duration: 5-8 minutes.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply coupling gel and move the ultrasound transducer in small, overlapping circles over the painful area of the TMJ or affected masticatory muscles (e.g., masseter, temporalis).
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce inflammation, accelerate tissue healing, decrease muscle spasm, and improve tissue extensibility prior to stretching.
electrotherapy.image_description: A physical therapist applying therapeutic ultrasound with a transducer head to the preauricular area of a patient's jaw.

phase_1.name: Acute Pain Management and Gentle Mobilization
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote muscle relaxation, establish controlled jaw movement, and improve initial range of motion.

exercises.name: Tongue Up/Controlled Jaw Opening
exercises.instructions: Place your tongue flat on the roof of your mouth, directly behind your front teeth. Keeping your tongue in this position, slowly and gently open and close your mouth, only as far as you can without pain or clicking. Focus on a smooth, controlled movement.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 3-5 times a day.
exercises.image_description: A person demonstrating the tongue-up position with their mouth slightly open, showing controlled jaw movement.

exercises.name: Jaw Relaxation Exercises
exercises.instructions: Close your lips gently, but keep your teeth slightly apart, without touching. Relax your jaw muscles completely, allowing your lower jaw to hang loosely. Focus on releasing any tension in the jaw, face, and neck.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 10-15 seconds, repeat 5-10 times throughout the day, especially during stressful periods.
exercises.image_description: A person with a relaxed, neutral facial expression, with lips gently closed but teeth slightly apart.

exercises.name: Chin Tucks (Cervical Retraction)
exercises.instructions: Sit or stand tall. Gently draw your chin straight back, as if making a double chin, keeping your eyes level. You should feel a stretch at the back of your neck. Avoid tilting your head up or down.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 3-5 seconds, 10-15 repetitions, 3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: A person sitting upright, demonstrating a chin tuck exercise with their head retracted.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Strengthening and Coordination
phase_2.goal: Improve jaw muscle strength, enhance coordination, restore full pain-free range of motion, and address postural contributions.

exercises.name: Isometric Jaw Opening Resistance
exercises.instructions: Place your fist gently under your chin. Slowly try to open your mouth while providing light, constant resistance with your fist. Hold the contraction, but do not allow your jaw to actually open.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 5-8 seconds, 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: A person with their fist under their chin, gently resisting jaw opening.

exercises.name: Lateral Jaw Deviation Resistance
exercises.instructions: Place your hand flat against the side of your jaw. Gently try to move your jaw to that side while providing light, constant resistance with your hand. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: Hold for 5-8 seconds, 10-15 repetitions per side, 2-3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: A person with their hand placed on the side of their jaw, resisting lateral jaw movement.

exercises.name: Rhythmic Stabilization (Dynamic Isometric)
exercises.instructions: In a controlled jaw opening position, the therapist (or patient's hand) applies light, alternating resistance in various directions (opening, closing, lateral). The patient is instructed to 'hold, don't let me move you' while maintaining the jaw position against the resistance.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 seconds per direction, 3-5 cycles, 2-3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: A physical therapist gently applying multi-directional resistance to a patient's jaw as the patient maintains a specific jaw position.

phase_3.name: Functional Integration and Prevention
phase_3.goal: Optimize jaw function for daily activities, prevent recurrence, and integrate self-management strategies.

exercises.name: Resisted Jaw Opening with Theraband
exercises.instructions: Loop a light resistance band under your chin and anchor it with your hands or feet. Slowly open your mouth against the resistance of the band, maintaining control. Slowly close.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets, 1-2 times a day.
exercises.image_description: A person using a light resistance band looped under their chin, performing resisted jaw opening.

exercises.name: Chewing Practice (Soft to Progressively Firmer Foods)
exercises.instructions: Start with soft, easy-to-chew foods (e.g., cooked vegetables, soft fruits). Progress gradually to firmer foods as tolerance allows. Focus on bilateral chewing and slow, controlled movements. Avoid excessively hard or sticky foods.
exercises.dosage: Integrate into daily meals, mindful of pain and clicking. Gradually increase challenge over weeks.
exercises.image_description: A person slowly and mindfully chewing a piece of food, demonstrating controlled jaw movement.

exercises.name: Posture Correction and Awareness
exercises.instructions: Maintain good upright posture with ears aligned over shoulders and chin slightly tucked. Be mindful of jaw position throughout the day (teeth apart, tongue on roof of mouth). Use postural cues and regular checks.
exercises.dosage: Constant awareness throughout the day. Perform 1-minute posture checks hourly.
exercises.image_description: A person sitting with excellent ergonomic posture, demonstrating proper head and neck alignment.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment includes detailed history (pain characteristics, clicking, locking, bruxism, stress), physical examination (palpation of masticatory muscles and TMJ, TMJ auscultation for clicks/crepitus, measurement of active and passive jaw range of motion including opening, protrusion, retrusion, and lateral excursion), evaluation of cervical spine posture and mobility, and occlusal assessment if indicated. Diagnosis is clinical, sometimes supported by imaging (MRI for disc displacement, X-ray/CT for degenerative changes).
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization techniques for the masseter, temporalis, medial and lateral pterygoid muscles (extra-oral and intra-oral). Gentle joint mobilizations or mobilizations with movement (MWM) to improve accessory and physiological joint play of the TMJ, particularly targeting capsular restrictions and improving condylar translation. Cervical spine mobilization and manipulation to address associated neck pain and postural dysfunction.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid wide jaw opening, clenching, grinding, hard/chewy/sticky foods. Maintain good oral hygiene. Educate on stress management and posture. Ensure patient compliance with home exercise program. Monitor for worsening symptoms or new neurological signs. Collaboration with dentists/oral surgeons for splints or occlusal adjustments if necessary.

scientific_reference: Okeson, J. P. (2019). Management of Temporomandibular Disorders and Occlusion (8th ed.). Elsevier Mosby. (This is a foundational text in TMJ management and rehabilitation).

clinical_presentation.definition: Parkinson's Disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms including bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity (stiffness), tremor at rest, and postural instability. Non-motor symptoms such as cognitive impairment, depression, sleep disorders, and autonomic dysfunction are also common. Physical therapy aims to mitigate motor symptoms, improve functional independence, reduce fall risk, and enhance quality of life.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An elderly person exhibiting a resting tremor in one hand, with a stooped posture and a masked facial expression, potentially demonstrating gait initiation difficulties or a shuffling gait.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 35-50 Hz; Pulse Duration: 200-300 µs; Intensity: To strong but tolerable contraction (Motor level); On/Off Ratio: 1:3 to 1:5; Treatment Duration: 15-20 minutes, 3-5 times/week.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over quadriceps femoris or tibialis anterior muscles to improve strength for sit-to-stand and gait mechanics (e.g., foot clearance). Can also be used for dysphagia by placing electrodes on suprahyoid muscles.
electrotherapy.goal: To improve muscle strength, facilitate motor unit recruitment, reduce bradykinesia, and improve functional tasks like sit-to-stand, gait, or swallowing function.
electrotherapy.image_description: Physical therapist applying electrodes to a patient's quadriceps muscle for NMES, demonstrating proper placement during a strengthening exercise.

electrotherapy.parameters: Conventional TENS: Frequency: 80-120 Hz; Pulse Duration: 50-100 µs; Intensity: Sensory level (strong tingling without muscle contraction); Treatment Duration: 30-60 minutes as needed for pain relief.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed over areas of musculoskeletal pain, commonly the cervical spine, shoulders, or lower back, often associated with rigidity and poor posture.
electrotherapy.goal: To alleviate musculoskeletal pain, reduce stiffness, and improve comfort, thereby facilitating participation in therapeutic exercises and daily activities.
electrotherapy.image_description: Physical therapist applying TENS electrodes to a patient's upper back or shoulder area, targeting an area of reported stiffness or pain associated with Parkinson's.

phase_1.name: Early Mobilization, Flexibility, and Balance Initiation
phase_1.goal: To maintain joint range of motion, reduce rigidity, improve posture, and initiate balance reactions in stable environments. Focus on 'BIG' movements.

exercises.name: Seated Trunk Rotations (BIG movements)
exercises.instructions: Sit tall with feet flat. Slowly rotate your trunk as far as possible to one side, reaching with your arms in a wide arc, then return to center and repeat to the other side. Focus on large, exaggerated movements.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient seated, performing large, exaggerated trunk rotations with outstretched arms.

exercises.name: Wall Angels with Deep Breathing
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart, and head, shoulders, and hips touching the wall. Slowly slide your arms up and down the wall like making a snow angel, keeping elbows and wrists against the wall as much as possible. Coordinate with deep diaphragmatic breaths.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, focusing on breath, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing against a wall, performing 'wall angels' with good posture.

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps and Circles
exercises.instructions: While seated or lying, actively pump your ankles up and down, then perform large circles in both directions. Focus on full, deliberate range of motion to combat rigidity and prepare for gait.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 15-20 repetitions or 10 circles each direction, 2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient lying down, demonstrating full ankle dorsiflexion and plantarflexion.

phase_2.name: Functional Integration, Amplitude Training, and Dynamic Balance
phase_2.goal: To improve gait parameters (stride length, arm swing), enhance dynamic balance reactions, reduce bradykinesia through large amplitude movements (LSVT BIG principles), and address functional task difficulties.

exercises.name: Exaggerated Stepping and Heel-Toe Gait
exercises.instructions: Focus on taking BIG steps, lifting knees higher, swinging arms widely, and making deliberate heel-to-toe contact. Practice turning with multiple small steps rather than pivoting. Walk in different directions (forward, sideways, backward) with attention to amplitude.
exercises.dosage: Walk for 10-15 minutes, 3-4 times daily, focusing on exaggerated movements. Practice 5-10 turns.
exercises.image_description: Patient walking with exaggerated arm swing and large strides, looking ahead, on a clear path.

exercises.name: Tall Sit-to-Stand with Arm Push
exercises.instructions: From a seated position, lean forward significantly, push through your heels and STAND UP TALL with a BIG reach upwards. Pause in full extension, then slowly sit back down with control. Focus on standing up as tall and fast as possible.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions, 2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient performing a sit-to-stand, demonstrating an upright posture and strong push-off, with arms reaching forward or upward.

exercises.name: Dynamic Weight Shifting and Reaching
exercises.instructions: Stand with a wide base of support. Slowly shift your weight from side to side and front to back. Progress to reaching for objects placed outside your base of support in various directions, focusing on maintaining balance and making BIG reaches. Use visual targets for increased focus.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions per direction, 1-2 times daily.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing, reaching forward and to the side to touch targets, demonstrating controlled weight shifts with therapist supervision.

phase_3.name: Advanced Functional Independence, Dual-Tasking, and Fall Prevention
phase_3.goal: To optimize compensatory strategies, maintain high-level functional independence, reduce fall risk through complex balance and gait tasks, and integrate dual-tasking to simulate real-life demands.

exercises.name: Challenging Gait and Cognitive Tasks
exercises.instructions: Navigate an obstacle course (e.g., cones, steps, uneven surfaces) while simultaneously performing a cognitive task (e.g., counting backward by 7s, naming animals, carrying a tray). Focus on maintaining gait quality and safety, employing BIG movements throughout.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 minutes, 1-2 times daily, gradually increasing complexity and speed.
exercises.image_description: Patient walking through a simple obstacle course while performing a verbal cognitive task, supervised by a therapist in a gym setting.

exercises.name: Balance on Unstable Surfaces
exercises.instructions: Stand on a foam pad or BOSU ball (flat side down initially). Progress to single-leg stance, weight shifts, and gentle throwing/catching activities while maintaining balance. Focus on core stability and rapid postural reactions with a wide range of motion.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 sets of 30-60 seconds, 1 time daily, with appropriate supervision.
exercises.image_description: Patient standing on a BOSU ball, eyes focused, maintaining balance while holding onto a support bar for safety.

exercises.name: Initiation and Freezing Mitigation Drills
exercises.instructions: Practice initiating movement from various positions (sitting, standing, turning) using external cues like counting aloud, stepping over an imaginary line, or a rhythmic beat to overcome freezing episodes. Practice stopping abruptly, changing direction quickly, and performing sequential movements.
exercises.dosage: Practice 10-15 instances of initiation/stopping/turning, 2 times daily, focusing on deliberate and large movements.
exercises.image_description: Patient practicing initiating a walk by stepping over a line, with a therapist providing verbal and visual cues.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Initial assessment should include a thorough history (onset, progression, medications, non-motor symptoms) and physical examination focusing on motor symptoms (e.g., using UPDRS-III), comprehensive gait analysis (stride length, speed, arm swing, cadence, freezing), balance assessment (e.g., Berg Balance Scale, Tinetti, MiniBESTest, Functional Reach), posture, range of motion, strength, and coordination. Cognitive screening (e.g., MoCA) and assessment of fear of falling (e.g., FES-I) are crucial. Differential diagnosis with other forms of parkinsonism should be considered, and medication timing (on/off periods) significantly impacts assessment and intervention planning.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy can be beneficial for addressing secondary musculoskeletal issues resulting from rigidity, poor posture, and altered movement patterns. Techniques include gentle joint mobilizations for spine and peripheral joints (e.g., shoulder, hips), soft tissue mobilization, myofascial release, and passive stretching to reduce stiffness, improve flexibility, and alleviate pain in the neck, shoulders, and trunk. PNF stretching can be incorporated to facilitate larger, rotational movements. It is not a primary treatment for PD itself but plays a vital supportive role in symptom management and increasing comfort for exercise participation.
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor vital signs, especially for orthostatic hypotension, which is common. Be aware of medication timing ('on'/'off' periods) and schedule therapy during 'on' periods for optimal patient performance and safety. Watch for fatigue, dyskinesias, and dystonia, adjusting intensity and duration accordingly. Ensure a safe environment to prevent falls, especially during balance and gait training; use assistive devices as needed. Educate on 'freezing of gait' and external cueing strategies. Educate patients and caregivers on fall prevention, home modifications, and energy conservation techniques. Avoid exercises that significantly increase fall risk without adequate supervision or assistive devices. Consider cognitive status when providing instructions, using clear, concise language and demonstrations.

scientific_reference: Keus, S. H. J., Bloem, B. R., Hendriks, E. J. M., Bredero-Cohen, A. B., & Munneke, M. (2014). European Physiotherapy Guideline for Parkinson's Disease. KNGF guidelines for physical therapy in patients with Parkinson's disease. Amersfoort: Royal Dutch Society for Physical Therapy.

clinical_presentation.definition: Cerebral Palsy (Spastic) is a permanent, non-progressive neurological condition resulting from a lesion or anomaly in the developing brain, characterized primarily by increased muscle tone (hypertonia) due to damage to the motor cortex or pyramidal tracts. This leads to exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, clonus, and sustained muscle contractions, significantly impacting posture, movement, and functional ability. Spasticity can manifest as hemiplegia (one side of the body), diplegia (predominantly lower limbs), or quadriplegia (all four limbs), often accompanied by secondary musculoskeletal deformities like contractures and scoliosis. Functional limitations vary widely based on the severity and distribution of spasticity.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A child with spastic diplegia, standing with scissoring gait, knees adducted and internally rotated, ankles in plantarflexion, demonstrating toe walking. Upper limbs might show mild flexor posturing.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 30-50 Hz (for muscle strengthening/re-education). Pulse Duration: 200-300 µs. Intensity: To achieve a comfortable, yet visible motor contraction without causing pain or significant spasticity exacerbation. Ramp Up/Down: 1-2 seconds. On/Off Cycle: 1:3 to 1:5 ratio (e.g., 5-10 sec ON, 15-50 sec OFF). Treatment Duration: 15-20 minutes, 3-5 times per week.
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the muscle belly and distal tendon of weak antagonist muscles (e.g., tibialis anterior for ankle dorsiflexion to counteract plantarflexor spasticity, triceps for elbow extension against biceps spasticity) or on weak agonist muscles to facilitate activation and strengthening for functional tasks.
electrotherapy.goal: To strengthen weak antagonist muscles to improve motor control and reduce co-contraction from spastic agonists, facilitate motor learning, improve functional movement patterns (e.g., dorsiflexion during gait), and prevent disuse atrophy.
electrotherapy.image_description: Two electrodes are placed on the anterior aspect of a child's lower leg, specifically targeting the tibialis anterior muscle, with a clear motor response visible (dorsiflexion of the foot).

phase_1.name: Foundational Mobility & Tone Management (Early Intervention / Severe Involvement)
phase_1.goal: Promote early motor development, manage tone, prevent secondary deformities (contractures), improve body awareness, and facilitate basic functional movements.

exercises.name: Gentle Sustained Stretching & Range of Motion (ROM)
exercises.instructions: Slowly move affected joints through their available pain-free range, holding at end-range for 30-60 seconds. Focus on muscles commonly affected by spasticity: hip adductors, hamstrings, gastrocnemius-soleus, hip flexors, pectoralis major, biceps, wrist/finger flexors. Perform multiple repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions per muscle group, holding 30-60 seconds, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: A therapist gently holding a child's knee extended and ankle dorsiflexed to stretch the gastrocnemius, with a calm and reassuring expression.

exercises.name: Positioning for Tone Inhibition & Postural Control
exercises.instructions: Utilize various positions to inhibit abnormal tone and encourage normal movement. Examples include prone lying, side lying, ring sitting, tailor sitting, prone over a wedge. Use supportive devices (rolls, wedges, pillows) as needed to maintain alignment and reduce spasticity. Encourage midline activities and weight-bearing through appropriate joints.
exercises.dosage: Multiple short sessions throughout the day, aiming for a total of 2-4 hours in various positions.
exercises.image_description: A child positioned in side-lying with a pillow between their knees and behind their back, promoting hip abduction and trunk alignment, reaching for a toy.

exercises.name: Rolling & Bridging Facilitation
exercises.instructions: Assist the child in initiating and completing rolling (prone to supine, supine to prone) using tactile cues and gentle guiding. Facilitate bridging to activate gluteal and core muscles. Use toys to encourage head turning and reaching across the body to initiate rolls.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions of each, 2-3 times daily, focusing on quality of movement.
exercises.image_description: A therapist providing gentle support at the hip and shoulder to guide a child through a segmental rolling motion from supine to side-lying.

phase_2.name: Functional Skill Acquisition & Strengthening (Moderate Involvement)
phase_2.goal: Improve functional strength, balance, coordination, and independent mobility (e.g., sitting, crawling, standing, walking) through targeted exercises and task-specific training.

exercises.name: Weight-Bearing Activities & Transitions
exercises.instructions: Facilitate weight-bearing in developmental positions: quadruped, kneeling, half-kneeling, modified plantigrade, and standing with support (e.g., standing frame, parallel bars, therapist assist). Practice transitions between these positions (e.g., sit-to-stand, floor-to-stand).
exercises.dosage: 5-10 repetitions of transitions; 15-30 minutes in standing frame/supported standing, 2-3 times daily.
exercises.image_description: A child in a standing frame with pelvic and trunk support, reaching for a toy on a tray, demonstrating active engagement and weight-bearing through the legs.

exercises.name: Targeted Strengthening (Antagonist Muscles)
exercises.instructions: Incorporate playful exercises to strengthen weak muscles, particularly antagonists to spastic muscles. Examples: kicking a ball (hip flexors), pulling resistance bands (shoulder retractors), 'animal walks' (quadruped crawling for hip/shoulder stability), resisted dorsiflexion with therapeutic putty or bands.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 8-12 repetitions or sustained holds during play, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A child lying supine, pushing a lightweight ball away with their feet to strengthen hip flexors and quadriceps.

exercises.name: Balance Training (Static & Dynamic)
exercises.instructions: Progress from static balance (e.g., unsupported sitting, kneeling, standing with minimal support) to dynamic balance (e.g., reaching outside base of support, walking on varied surfaces, tandem stance with assist, single-leg stance with hand-holding). Use balance boards, wobble cushions, and games.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 minutes, 3-5 times per week, incorporated into play.
exercises.image_description: A child standing on a soft, unstable surface (e.g., foam mat or wobble board) with a therapist providing light hand assistance, maintaining balance while reaching for a toy.

phase_3.name: Advanced Motor Control & Community Participation (Mild Involvement / Older Children)
phase_3.goal: Refine motor skills, improve endurance, promote independence in daily activities, and facilitate participation in age-appropriate recreational and community activities.

exercises.name: Gait Training & Locomotion Refinement
exercises.instructions: Focus on improving gait parameters: step length, cadence, velocity, symmetry. Incorporate obstacle courses, walking on uneven terrain, stair climbing (with or without railing), and treadmill training (with body weight support if needed). Practice dual-tasking during ambulation.
exercises.dosage: 20-30 minutes, 3-5 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A child walking independently on a slightly uneven outdoor path, demonstrating good step length and arm swing, supervised by a therapist.

exercises.name: Endurance Training
exercises.instructions: Engage in activities that improve cardiovascular fitness and muscular endurance: cycling (stationary bike or adapted bike), swimming, prolonged walking, active sports participation. Monitor fatigue and adjust intensity.
exercises.dosage: 20-30 minutes of moderate intensity, 3-4 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A child happily riding an adapted stationary bicycle, demonstrating controlled leg movements and sustained effort.

exercises.name: Sport-Specific & Recreational Skill Development
exercises.instructions: Tailor exercises to specific interests, such as adapted sports (e.g., boccia, swimming, seated volleyball), throwing/catching games, agility drills, jumping activities (if appropriate), or participation in community programs. Emphasize functional and social participation.
exercises.dosage: Regular participation as per child's interest, aiming for at least 30-60 minutes, 3-5 times per week.
exercises.image_description: A group of children, one with mild CP, participating in a modified team ball game in a gymnasium, demonstrating active and joyful engagement.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment includes: detailed history (birth, developmental milestones), Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS), Manual Ability Classification System (MACS), Communication Function Classification System (CFCS), Modified Ashworth Scale for spasticity, Range of Motion (ROM), muscle strength testing, postural control assessment (sitting, standing balance), gait analysis (observational or instrumental), functional mobility assessment (e.g., Pediatric Evaluation of Disability Inventory - PEDI), assessment of pain, fatigue, and orthotic/assistive device needs. Collaborate with multidisciplinary team (pediatrician, neurologist, orthopedist, occupational therapist, speech pathologist).
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Gentle, sustained stretches to address muscle shortening and contractures. Neurodevelopmental Treatment (NDT) handling techniques to facilitate normal movement patterns, inhibit abnormal tone, and promote postural control. Joint mobilization may be indicated for specific joint hypomobility not directly due to spasticity. Soft tissue mobilization for myofascial tightness. Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation (PNF) patterns can be adapted to improve motor control and strength.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid rapid, ballistic stretching as it can exacerbate the stretch reflex and increase spasticity. Monitor for signs of pain, discomfort, or fatigue. Consider respiratory status and potential for autonomic dysregulation in severe cases. Be aware of seizure disorders and implement appropriate precautions. Ensure proper fit and use of orthoses to prevent skin breakdown. Tailor intensity and duration of exercises to the child's tolerance and developmental stage. Watch for signs of over-exertion or heat intolerance. Always prioritize child safety and comfort.

scientific_reference: Kisner, C., & Colby, L. A. (2017). Therapeutic Exercise: Foundations and Techniques (7th ed.). F.A. Davis Company. (Chapter on Neuromuscular Disorders/Pediatrics)

clinical_presentation.definition: A spinal cord injury that results in the loss of motor and sensory function in the lower half of the body, typically below the level of the injury
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the spinal cord and the level of injury

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Duration: 30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the quadriceps and hamstring muscles
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength and function
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of FES electrodes on the leg

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Duration: 30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the lower back and legs
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and spasticity
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of TENS electrodes on the back and legs

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-6 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Prevent complications and promote healing

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM)
exercises.instructions: Gently move the joints through a range of motion without resistance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
