exercises.image_description: A picture of a therapist performing PROM on a patient

exercises.name: Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Deep breathing exercises to improve lung function
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing deep breathing exercises

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase (6-12 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and function

exercises.name: Active Assisted Range of Motion (AAROM)
exercises.instructions: Assist the patient in moving their joints through a range of motion
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a therapist assisting a patient with AAROM

exercises.name: Isometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Contract and hold muscles without moving the joints
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing isometric exercises

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (beyond 12 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Maintain and improve function

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to strengthen muscles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient using resistance bands

exercises.name: Functional Activities
exercises.instructions: Practice daily activities such as transfers and mobility
exercises.dosage: As needed, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing functional activities

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Complete or incomplete spinal cord injury, depending on the level and severity of the injury
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: May include joint mobilization, soft tissue mobilization, and massage to promote relaxation and reduce spasticity
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of autonomic dysreflexia, such as hypertension and bradycardia, and take precautions to prevent pressure sores and deep vein thrombosis

scientific_reference: American Spinal Injury Association (ASIA) guidelines for the management of spinal cord injuries

clinical_presentation.definition: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness due to the absence of dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A child with DMD may have difficulty walking, climbing stairs, and getting up from the floor, with noticeable muscle wasting in the lower limbs.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Pulse duration: 200-400 μs
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the quadriceps and hamstring muscles
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength and function in the lower limbs
electrotherapy.image_description: A child with DMD receiving FES treatment on their lower limbs

phase_1.name: Maintenance of Range of Motion (ROM)
phase_1.goal: Prevent contractures and maintain joint mobility

exercises.name: Passive knee extension
exercises.instructions: Gently move the child's knee through a full range of motion, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A therapist performing passive knee extension on a child with DMD

phase_2.name: Strengthening Exercises
phase_2.goal: Improve muscle strength and function

exercises.name: Quadriceps setting
exercises.instructions: Have the child tighten their quadriceps muscle, holding for 5 seconds, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A child with DMD performing quadriceps setting exercise

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve functional abilities and independence

exercises.name: Standing with support
exercises.instructions: Have the child stand with support, holding for 10 seconds, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A child with DMD standing with support

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment including medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests (e.g., genetic testing, muscle biopsy)
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue techniques to improve range of motion and reduce muscle spasms
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid overexertion, falls, and injuries, and monitor for respiratory and cardiac complications

scientific_reference: American Academy of Pediatrics, Physical Therapy Association, and other reputable sources

clinical_presentation.definition: A congenital defect of the spine where the spinal cord and its meninges are exposed through a gap in the backbone
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the spinal cord and meninges exposed through a gap in the backbone

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Duration: 30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the affected muscle groups, such as the quadriceps and hamstrings
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength and function in the lower limbs
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a child with Spina Bifida using FES with electrodes on their legs

phase_1.name: Initial Mobility and Strengthening
phase_1.goal: Improve range of motion, strength, and mobility in the lower limbs

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM) Exercises
exercises.instructions: Gently move the child's legs through a range of motion, including flexion, extension, and rotation
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a therapist performing PROM exercises on a child with Spina Bifida

exercises.name: Bridging Exercises
exercises.instructions: Have the child lie on their back and lift their hips off the table, squeezing their gluteal muscles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a child with Spina Bifida performing bridging exercises

phase_2.name: Progressive Strengthening and Mobility
phase_2.goal: Progressively increase strength and mobility in the lower limbs

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to strengthen the muscles in the lower limbs, such as the quadriceps and hamstrings
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a child with Spina Bifida using resistance bands

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve functional abilities, such as walking and balance

exercises.name: Gait Training
exercises.instructions: Use assistive devices, such as walkers or canes, to improve walking ability
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 minutes, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a child with Spina Bifida using a walker during gait training

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A comprehensive assessment, including physical examination, medical history, and diagnostic imaging, to determine the severity of the Spina Bifida and develop an individualized treatment plan
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: May include techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization to improve range of motion and reduce muscle spasm
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that may exacerbate the condition, such as heavy lifting or bending, and take regular breaks to rest and stretch

scientific_reference: The American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) guidelines for the treatment of Spina Bifida, as well as research studies published in the Journal of Pediatric Physical Therapy and the Journal of Spinal Cord Medicine

clinical_presentation.definition: Torticollis is a condition characterized by a twisted neck, where the head is tilted to one side and the chin is turned to the other side. It can be congenital or acquired, and is often seen in infants and young children.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A photograph of an infant with torticollis, showing the head tilted to one side and the chin turned to the other side.

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 660nm, Intensity: 10mW/cm², Duration: 10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply the laser probe to the affected sternocleidomastoid muscle, 1-2cm from the mastoid process.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce muscle spasm and promote relaxation of the affected muscle.
electrotherapy.image_description: An illustration of a low-level laser therapy probe being applied to the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

phase_1.name: Initial Stretching and Strengthening
phase_1.goal: To improve range of motion and reduce muscle spasm in the affected sternocleidomastoid muscle.

exercises.name: Chin Tucks
exercises.instructions: Gently tuck the chin towards the chest, holding for 10 seconds and repeating for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of an infant performing a chin tuck exercise.

exercises.name: Head Turns
exercises.instructions: Gently turn the head to the left and right, holding for 10 seconds and repeating for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of an infant performing a head turn exercise.

phase_2.name: Progressive Strengthening
phase_2.goal: To improve strength and endurance of the affected sternocleidomastoid muscle.

exercises.name: Resisted Head Turns
exercises.instructions: Gently apply resistance to the head as the infant turns it to the left and right, holding for 10 seconds and repeating for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of an infant performing a resisted head turn exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: To improve functional abilities and promote normal movement patterns.

exercises.name: Play-based Activities
exercises.instructions: Engage the infant in play-based activities that promote active movement and exploration, such as reaching for toys and playing with mirrors.
exercises.dosage: As tolerated, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of an infant engaging in play-based activities.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including observation, palpation, and range of motion testing, is necessary to diagnose torticollis and develop an effective treatment plan.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to promote relaxation and improve range of motion in the affected muscle.
clinical_notes.precautions: Precautions should be taken to avoid over-stretching or over-exertion, which can exacerbate the condition.

scientific_reference: The treatment protocol is based on current scientific evidence and clinical guidelines, including the American Academy of Pediatrics and the Physical Therapy Association.

clinical_presentation.definition: Osgood-Schlatter disease is a common cause of knee pain in adolescents, characterized by inflammation of the patellar tendon at its insertion on the tibial tubercle.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the location of the tibial tubercle and the patellar tendon, with an illustration of the inflammation

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2, 5-10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the affected area, with the tibial tubercle as the central point
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an ultrasound machine being used to treat the knee

electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the knee, with the tibial tubercle as the central point
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of IFC electrodes on the knee

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, maintain range of motion

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly straighten the knee, holding for 5 seconds, then slowly lower
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing knee extension exercise

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, holding for 5 seconds, then slowly straighten
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing knee flexion exercise

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Proprioception
phase_2.goal: Strengthen the quadriceps and hamstring muscles, improve proprioception

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the straight leg 6-8 inches off the ground, holding for 5 seconds, then slowly lower
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing straight leg raise exercise

exercises.name: Wall Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with back against the wall, slowly slide down into a squat, holding for 5 seconds, then slowly stand up
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing wall squats exercise

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Agility
phase_3.goal: Improve strength, power, and agility

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Step out with one foot, lowering the body down into a lunge, holding for 5 seconds, then slowly stand up
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing lunges exercise

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform drills such as zig-zag running, shuttle runs, and cone drills
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week, 20-30 minutes per session
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing agility drills

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, including pain and swelling over the tibial tubercle, and radiographic findings
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: May include soft tissue mobilization, joint mobilization, and patellar mobilization
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as jumping and running

scientific_reference: American Academy of Pediatrics, American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, and National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

clinical_presentation.definition: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a progressive lung disease characterized by long-term breathing problems and poor airflow. The most common symptoms are shortness of breath, cough, and sputum production.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram of the lungs showing the airways constricted and inflamed, with a caption describing the symptoms of COPD.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the upper back and chest area to target the respiratory muscles
electrotherapy.goal: Relaxation of respiratory muscles, reduction of pain and discomfort
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a person receiving IFC therapy with electrodes placed on their upper back and chest area.

phase_1.name: Breathing and Relaxation Exercises
phase_1.goal: Improve lung function, increase oxygenation, and reduce shortness of breath

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, place one hand on your stomach and the other on your chest, inhale deeply through your nose, allowing your stomach to rise while your chest remains still
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the correct placement of hands on the stomach and chest, with an arrow indicating the movement of the diaphragm.

phase_2.name: Aerobic and Strengthening Exercises
phase_2.goal: Improve cardiovascular endurance, increase muscle strength, and enhance overall physical function

exercises.name: Brisk Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk at a brisk pace for 10-15 minutes, rest for 5 minutes, and repeat for a total of 30 minutes
exercises.dosage: 3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person walking outdoors with a caption describing the benefits of brisk walking.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Conditioning Exercises
phase_3.goal: Improve muscle strength, endurance, and overall physical function, and enhance quality of life

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to perform exercises such as bicep curls, tricep extensions, and shoulder presses
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person using resistance bands to perform exercises, with a caption describing the benefits of resistance band training.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: COPD diagnosis is based on a combination of medical history, physical examination, lung function tests, and imaging studies
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy such as chest physiotherapy and massage may be used to help loosen and clear mucus from the airways
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid exposure to pollutants, dust, and smoke, and get vaccinated against flu and pneumonia to prevent exacerbations

scientific_reference: Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease. (2020). Global Strategy for the Diagnosis, Management, and Prevention of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease.

clinical_presentation.definition: Myocardial infarction, commonly known as a heart attack, occurs when blood flow to the heart is severely blocked, causing damage to the heart muscle. Post-operative rehabilitation focuses on improving cardiovascular function, reducing symptoms, and enhancing overall quality of life.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the heart with a blocked coronary artery

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Pulse width: 100-200 μs
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the chest, avoiding the area directly over the heart
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and discomfort
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the chest

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks post-op)
phase_1.goal: Improve cardiovascular function, reduce symptoms, and enhance mobility

exercises.name: Deep Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Inhale deeply through the nose, hold for 5 seconds, and exhale slowly through the mouth
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing deep breathing exercises

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion Exercises
exercises.instructions: Gently move the arms and legs through a range of motion, without resistance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person performing passive range of motion exercises

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase (2-6 weeks post-op)
phase_2.goal: Progress cardiovascular function, increase mobility, and introduce strengthening exercises

exercises.name: Brisk Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk at a brisk pace, aiming for 30 minutes per session
exercises.dosage: 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: An image of a person walking outdoors

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to perform exercises such as bicep curls, tricep extensions, and shoulder rotations
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person using resistance bands

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (beyond 6 weeks post-op)
phase_3.goal: Maintain cardiovascular function, promote long-term mobility, and enhance overall fitness

exercises.name: Aerobic Exercise
exercises.instructions: Engage in aerobic activities such as cycling, swimming, or jogging, aiming for 30-40 minutes per session
exercises.dosage: 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: An image of a person cycling outdoors

exercises.name: Strengthening Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform exercises such as squats, lunges, and leg press to strengthen the lower limbs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person performing squats

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess cardiovascular function, respiratory status, and overall mobility. Diagnose any underlying conditions that may impact rehabilitation.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization to promote relaxation, reduce pain, and enhance mobility.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or strenuous activities that may exacerbate the condition. Monitor for signs of cardiac complications, such as chest pain or shortness of breath.

scientific_reference: American Heart Association. (2017). Guidelines for the Management of Patients with Acute Myocardial Infarction. Circulation, 136(10), e146-e548.

clinical_presentation.definition: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, causing persistent lung infections and progressive lung damage.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the effects of cystic fibrosis on the lungs, including thick mucus buildup and bronchiectasis.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 10-20 Hz, Amplitude: 5-10 cm
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the vest around the patient's chest, ensuring proper fit and seal
electrotherapy.goal: To mobilize secretions and improve lung function
electrotherapy.image_description: A patient wearing a HFCWO vest, with a healthcare professional adjusting the settings.

phase_1.name: Airway Clearance Exercises
phase_1.goal: To improve lung function and mobilize secretions

exercises.name: Huffing and Coughing
exercises.instructions: Inhale deeply, then exhale forcefully through the mouth, repeating for 5-10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient performing huffing and coughing exercises, with a healthcare professional providing guidance.

phase_2.name: Breathing and Strengthening Exercises
phase_2.goal: To improve lung function and increase muscle strength

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Inhale deeply through the nose, allowing the diaphragm to drop, then exhale slowly through the mouth
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient practicing diaphragmatic breathing, with a healthcare professional providing feedback.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Conditioning Exercises
phase_3.goal: To improve overall physical fitness and increase endurance

exercises.name: Aerobic Exercise
exercises.instructions: Engage in moderate-intensity aerobic activities, such as walking or cycling, for 20-30 minutes
exercises.dosage: 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: A patient participating in aerobic exercise, with a healthcare professional providing supervision.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess lung function, oxygen saturation, and overall physical condition to determine the best course of treatment
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual techniques, such as percussion and vibration, to help mobilize secretions and improve lung function
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid overexertion, and monitor for signs of respiratory distress or fatigue

scientific_reference: Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. (2020). Clinical Practice Guidelines for the Care of Individuals with Cystic Fibrosis.

clinical_presentation.definition: Lymphedema is a chronic condition characterized by the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial tissue, leading to swelling of one or more extremities.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the lymphatic system and the affected areas in lymphedema

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the affected area, avoiding bony prominences
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce swelling and pain
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of IFC therapy equipment and electrode placement

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce swelling and promote lymphatic drainage

exercises.name: Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Deep breathing exercises, 10 repetitions, 3 sets
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing proper breathing technique

exercises.name: Shoulder Mobilization
exercises.instructions: Gentle shoulder rolls, 10 repetitions, 3 sets
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing shoulder rolls

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve range of motion and strength

exercises.name: Arm Elevation
exercises.instructions: Elevate the affected arm above the level of the heart, 10 repetitions, 3 sets
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person elevating their arm

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase
phase_3.goal: Maintain lymphatic drainage and prevent exacerbation

exercises.name: Lymphatic Drainage Exercises
exercises.instructions: Gentle, light strokes on the affected area, 10 repetitions, 3 sets
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing lymphatic drainage techniques

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Complete decongestive therapy (CDT) is the gold standard for lymphedema management
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) is a key component of CDT
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or strenuous activities that may exacerbate the condition

scientific_reference: International Society of Lymphology (2013). The diagnosis and treatment of lymphedema.

clinical_presentation.definition: A burn injury is damage to the skin or other tissues caused by heat, cold, electricity, chemicals, or radiation. The severity of the injury depends on the depth and extent of the burn.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a burn injury with erythema, edema, and blistering

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 27.12 MHz, Pulse duration: 400 us, Pulse repetition frequency: 100 Hz
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the applicator 1-2 cm from the burn wound, avoiding direct contact with the wound
electrotherapy.goal: Promote wound healing, reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a pulsed shortwave diathermy applicator being used on a burn wound

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 632.8 nm, Power density: 10 mW/cm^2, Treatment duration: 10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the laser probe 1-2 cm from the burn wound, avoiding direct contact with the wound
electrotherapy.goal: Enhance wound healing, reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a low-level laser therapy probe being used on a burn wound

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Promote wound healing, maintain range of motion, and prevent contractures

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion
exercises.instructions: Gently move the affected joint through a range of motion, avoiding pain and discomfort
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a therapist performing passive range of motion on a patient with a burn injury

exercises.name: Isometric Contractions
exercises.instructions: Contract the affected muscles without moving the joint, holding for 5-10 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing isometric contractions with a burn injury

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve range of motion, strength, and function

exercises.name: Active Range of Motion
exercises.instructions: Move the affected joint through a range of motion, using the affected muscles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing active range of motion with a burn injury

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to strengthen the affected muscles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing resistance band exercises with a burn injury

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (6 weeks and beyond)
phase_3.goal: Maintain range of motion, strength, and function, and promote return to functional activities

exercises.name: Functional Activities
exercises.instructions: Perform daily activities, such as dressing, grooming, and bathing, using the affected limb
exercises.dosage: As tolerated, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing functional activities with a burn injury

exercises.name: Strengthening Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform strengthening exercises, such as weightlifting or bodyweight exercises, to maintain muscle strength
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing strengthening exercises with a burn injury

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the burn wound for depth, size, and location, and diagnose any associated conditions, such as infection or contractures
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques, such as massage and joint mobilization, to promote wound healing and maintain range of motion
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid using heat or cold therapy on the burn wound, and avoid using electrical stimulation on areas with metal implants

scientific_reference: American Burn Association. (2019). Burn Care Guidelines. Journal of Burn Care & Research, 40(5), 537-546.

clinical_presentation.definition: A pressure ulcer, also known as a pressure sore or bedsore, is a localized damage to the skin and/or underlying tissue that usually occur over a bony prominence as a result of pressure, or pressure in combination with shear and/or friction.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a pressure ulcer on the heel of a patient, showing the damaged skin and tissue.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz, 0.1-1.0 W/cm^2, 3-5 minutes, 3 times a week
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The ultrasound head should be placed directly over the pressure ulcer, with a thin layer of coupling gel to ensure good contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To enhance wound healing by increasing blood flow, reducing inflammation, and promoting tissue repair.
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a low frequency ultrasound device being used to treat a pressure ulcer.

electrotherapy.parameters: 10-20 mA, 10-20 Hz, 15-30 minutes, 3 times a week
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The electrodes should be placed around the pressure ulcer, with the positive electrode placed over the ulcer and the negative electrode placed on the surrounding skin.
electrotherapy.goal: To enhance wound healing by increasing blood flow, reducing inflammation, and promoting tissue repair.
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of electrical stimulation being used to treat a pressure ulcer.

phase_1.name: Pressure Ulcer Prevention and Management
phase_1.goal: To prevent further tissue damage and promote wound healing.

exercises.name: Position Changes
exercises.instructions: Change position every 2 hours to reduce pressure on the affected area.
exercises.dosage: As needed, but at least every 2 hours.
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient being turned and repositioned in bed to reduce pressure on the affected area.

exercises.name: Range of Motion Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform range of motion exercises to maintain joint mobility and prevent contractures.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing range of motion exercises for the shoulders, elbows, and hips.

phase_2.name: Wound Healing and Tissue Repair
phase_2.goal: To promote wound healing and tissue repair.

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps
exercises.instructions: Pump ankles up and down to promote blood flow and prevent swelling.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient pumping their ankles up and down.

phase_3.name: Return to Function
phase_3.goal: To return to normal functional activities.

exercises.name: Transfer Training
exercises.instructions: Practice transferring from bed to chair or wheelchair to promote independence and mobility.
exercises.dosage: As needed, but at least 3 times a day.
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient transferring from bed to chair with assistance.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: The patient is at high risk for developing pressure ulcers due to immobility and limited mobility.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to promote wound healing and tissue repair.
clinical_notes.precautions: The patient should avoid putting pressure on the affected area and should use a pressure-redistributing mattress or cushion to reduce pressure.

scientific_reference: National Pressure Injury Advisory Panel (NPIAP) and European Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel (EPUAP) (2019). Prevention and Treatment of Pressure Ulcers/Injuries: Clinical Practice Guideline.

clinical_presentation.definition: Shin splints, also known as medial tibial stress syndrome, is a common overuse injury that affects the lower leg, typically causing pain and inflammation in the front or sides of the lower leg, usually after repetitive running, jumping, or other high-impact activities.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a person pointing to their shin area with a painful expression, with a red circle around the affected area.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation, Treatment time: 15-20 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the affected shin area, approximately 2-3 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote healing
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a person with electrodes placed on their shin area, connected to an IFC machine.

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 630-1000 nm, Intensity: 10-100 mW, Treatment time: 10-15 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Hold the laser probe 1-2 inches away from the affected shin area, moving it slowly back and forth.
electrotherapy.goal: Enhance tissue repair, reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a person holding a LLLT probe near their shin area, with a red light emitted.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote healing

exercises.name: Ankle Mobilization
exercises.instructions: Gently move the ankle through its range of motion, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person moving their ankle in a circular motion.

exercises.name: Toe Raises
exercises.instructions: Slowly raise up onto the toes, then lower back down, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing on their toes, then lowering back down.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and flexibility, progress to functional activities

exercises.name: Calf Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the edge of a step or curb, raise up onto the toes, then lower back down, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing on the edge of a step, raising up onto their toes.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, 10-30 seconds, 3 sets per leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing on one leg, with the other foot lifted.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (6 weeks and beyond)
phase_3.goal: Return to full functional activities, maintain strength and flexibility

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform zig-zag running, shuttle runs, or other agility drills, 10-20 minutes, 2-3 times a week.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing agility drills on a field or court.

exercises.name: Plyometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform jump squats, box jumps, or other plyometric exercises, 10-20 minutes, 2-3 times a week.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing jump squats or box jumps.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess for pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the affected leg. Diagnose based on clinical presentation and radiographic findings.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization to promote healing and reduce pain and inflammation.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid high-impact activities, excessive running or jumping, and inadequate footwear or training surfaces.

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine. (2018). ACSM's Sports Medicine: A Comprehensive Review. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer.

clinical_presentation.definition: A groin strain is a common injury that occurs when the muscles in the groin area are stretched or torn, typically due to sudden stops, changes of direction, or kicking movements.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An image of the groin area with the affected muscles highlighted, including the adductor magnus, adductor longus, and adductor brevis.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the affected area, using a generous amount of gel to ensure good contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To promote tissue healing, reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion.
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of an ultrasound machine with the probe placed over the groin area.

electrotherapy.parameters: 50-100 Hz frequency, 10-20 mA intensity, 10-15 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the IFC electrodes on either side of the affected area, using a small amount of gel to ensure good contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of an IFC machine with the electrodes placed on either side of the groin area.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-3 days)
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.

exercises.name: Groin Stretch
exercises.instructions: Slowly bring the affected leg towards the midline of the body, holding for 15-30 seconds. Repeat 3-5 times.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person stretching their groin, with the affected leg brought towards the midline of the body.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the affected leg off the ground, keeping it straight, and holding for 5-10 seconds. Repeat 3-5 times.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person lifting their straight leg off the ground.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (4-7 days)
phase_2.goal: To improve range of motion, strength, and function.

exercises.name: Resisted Adduction
exercises.instructions: Use a resistance band or cable machine to perform adduction exercises, aiming for 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per week
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing resisted adduction exercises using a resistance band.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Perform walking lunges, keeping the back knee almost touching the ground, and aiming for 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions per leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per week
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing walking lunges.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (8+ days)
phase_3.goal: To improve power, speed, and agility.

exercises.name: Plyometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform jump squats, box jumps, or other plyometric exercises to improve power and speed.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per week
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing jump squats.

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform shuttle runs, cone drills, or other agility exercises to improve speed and agility.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per week
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing shuttle runs.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including history, physical examination, and imaging studies (if necessary), is essential to diagnose a groin strain.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization, can be used to promote tissue healing and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid activities that aggravate the condition.

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine. (2018). ACSM's Sports Medicine: A Comprehensive Review. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer.

clinical_presentation.definition: A hamstring strain is an injury to one or more of the muscles in the back of the thigh, which can range from a mild strain to a severe tear.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of the posterior thigh showing the hamstring muscles

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz, 1-2 W/cm^2, 5-10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Transducer placed over the affected area, with gel used for coupling
electrotherapy.goal: Promote tissue healing, reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of ultrasound transducer placement on the posterior thigh

electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on either side of the affected area
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote muscle relaxation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of IFC electrode placement on the posterior thigh

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-72 hours)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the leg, keeping the knee straight, and then lower it back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing knee extension exercise

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps
exercises.instructions: Slowly move the ankle through its range of motion, first dorsiflexion and then plantarflexion
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing ankle pumps exercise

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (72 hours-2 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve range of motion, strength and flexibility

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the leg, keeping the knee straight, and then lower it back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing straight leg raise exercise

exercises.name: Hamstring Stretching
exercises.instructions: Slowly lean forward, keeping the knee straight, and then return to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing hamstring stretching exercise

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Improve functional strength, power and agility

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Step forward with one foot and lower the body down, keeping the back knee almost touching the ground, and then push back up to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing lunges exercise

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform shuttle runs, zig-zag runs, or other agility drills to improve speed, agility and quickness
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing agility drills

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess for pain, swelling, bruising, and limited range of motion. Diagnose based on clinical presentation and imaging studies (e.g. MRI or ultrasound)
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use massage, joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization to promote tissue healing, reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending or twisting, and high-impact activities that may exacerbate the injury

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) guidelines for hamstring strain rehabilitation

clinical_presentation.definition: A Bankart repair is a surgical procedure to repair a Bankart lesion, which is an injury to the anterior (front) glenoid labrum of the shoulder joint. This injury often occurs due to anterior shoulder dislocation.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the shoulder joint showing the glenoid labrum and the Bankart lesion

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-3 MHz, Intensity: 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2, Duration: 5-10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The ultrasound probe is placed over the affected area, with the patient in a comfortable position to allow for optimal sound wave transmission
electrotherapy.goal: To promote tissue healing, reduce inflammation, and relieve pain
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a physiotherapist applying pulsed ultrasound to the shoulder joint

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 630-700 nm, Intensity: 10-50 mW/cm^2, Duration: 10-20 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The LLLT device is placed over the affected area, with the patient in a comfortable position to allow for optimal energy transmission
electrotherapy.goal: To promote tissue healing, reduce inflammation, and relieve pain
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a physiotherapist applying LLLT to the shoulder joint

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-6 weeks post-op)
phase_1.goal: To promote wound healing, reduce pain and inflammation, and maintain range of motion

exercises.name: Pendulum Exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) and perform small circular motions with the arm, first clockwise and then counterclockwise
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing the pendulum exercise

exercises.name: Passive Shoulder Flexion
exercises.instructions: Use the unaffected arm to gently lift the affected arm forward, keeping the elbow straight
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing passive shoulder flexion

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (6-12 weeks post-op)
phase_2.goal: To improve range of motion, strength, and function

exercises.name: Active Shoulder Flexion
exercises.instructions: Lift the arm forward, keeping the elbow straight, using the affected muscles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing active shoulder flexion

exercises.name: Resisted External Rotation
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) and rotate the arm outward, against resistance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing resisted external rotation

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (3-6 months post-op)
phase_3.goal: To improve strength, power, and function, and return to pre-injury activities

exercises.name: Resisted Shoulder Abduction
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) and lift the arm out to the side, against resistance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing resisted shoulder abduction

exercises.name: Plyometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform rapid, high-intensity movements, such as throwing or catching, to improve power and function
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing plyometric exercises

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including physical examination and imaging studies, is necessary to diagnose a Bankart lesion and determine the need for surgical repair
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, may be used to improve range of motion and reduce pain and inflammation
clinical_notes.precautions: The patient should avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and should avoid putting the arm in a position that may cause further injury to the shoulder joint

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2020). Bankart Repair. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/bankart-repair/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is a surgical procedure to replace the weight-bearing surfaces of the knee joint to relieve pain and disability
clinical_presentation.image_description: An X-ray image of a knee joint after total knee arthroplasty, showing the prosthetic components

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes around the knee joint, avoiding the incision site
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for IFC around the knee joint

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 10-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the knee joint
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for TENS on either side of the knee joint

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks post-op)
phase_1.goal: Improve range of motion, reduce pain and swelling

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, keeping the foot behind the body
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person bending their knee, with the foot behind the body

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly straighten the knee, keeping the foot in front of the body
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person straightening their knee, with the foot in front of the body

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks post-op)
phase_2.goal: Improve strength, proprioception and functional activities

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the leg straight up, keeping the knee straight
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person lifting their leg straight up, with the knee straight

exercises.name: Step-Ups
exercises.instructions: Step up onto a stair or step, then step back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person stepping up onto a stair, then stepping back down

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (6-12 weeks post-op)
phase_3.goal: Improve advanced strength, agility and functional activities

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, then bend the knees and lower the body down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person performing a squat, with the knees bent and the body lowered down

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet together, take a large step forward with one foot, then lower the body down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person performing a lunge, with the front knee bent and the body lowered down

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the patient's range of motion, strength, and functional abilities
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as joint mobilization and soft tissue massage to improve range of motion and reduce pain
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending or twisting, and avoid putting excessive stress on the knee joint

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) guidelines for total knee arthroplasty rehabilitation

clinical_presentation.definition: Total Hip Arthroplasty (THA) is a surgical procedure where the damaged hip joint is replaced with an artificial joint, consisting of a femoral component and an acetabular component, to alleviate pain and restore function.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An X-ray image of a hip joint with a prosthetic implant, showing the femoral head and acetabulum.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes around the hip joint, avoiding the incision site.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes around the hip joint for IFC treatment.

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 630-1000 nm, Intensity: 10-50 mW/cm²
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply the laser probe to the affected area, 1-2 cm from the skin.
electrotherapy.goal: Enhance tissue repair, reduce pain and inflammation.
electrotherapy.image_description: An illustration of a laser probe being applied to the hip joint.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-6 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Pain management, wound healing, and basic mobility.

exercises.name: Ankle Pumps
exercises.instructions: Slowly pump ankles up and down, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing ankle pumps in bed.

exercises.name: Knee Straightening
exercises.instructions: Slowly straighten the knee, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person straightening their knee while seated.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (6-12 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Progressive strengthening, range of motion, and functional activities.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the operated leg 6-8 inches off the bed, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing a person performing a straight leg raise.

exercises.name: Hip Abduction
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the operated leg away from the midline, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing hip abduction.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (3-6 months)
phase_3.goal: High-level strengthening, agility, and return to functional activities.

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Perform a squat, keeping the back straight and knees behind the toes, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a squat.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Perform a lunge, keeping the front knee behind the toes, 10-15 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a lunge.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the patient's range of motion, strength, and functional abilities to determine the appropriate treatment protocol.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, to promote tissue healing and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid crossing the operated leg past the midline.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2020). Total Hip Replacement. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/total-hip-replacement/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Inflammation of the biceps tendon, which connects the biceps muscle to the shoulder joint, causing pain and limited mobility in the shoulder and arm.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Illustration of the biceps tendon and surrounding anatomy, highlighting the area of inflammation.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Transducer placement over the affected biceps tendon, with gel or oil as a coupling agent
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce inflammation and promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of ultrasound transducer placement on the biceps tendon.

electrotherapy.parameters: 630-700 nm wavelength, 10-50 mW/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Probe placement over the affected biceps tendon, with direct contact
electrotherapy.goal: Enhance tissue repair and reduce pain
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of LLLT probe placement on the biceps tendon.

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and improve shoulder mobility

exercises.name: Pendulum Exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) and perform small circular motions with the arm, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing the pendulum exercise.

exercises.name: Wall Slide
exercises.instructions: Stand with the affected arm against a wall and slowly slide the arm up the wall, keeping the elbow straight.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing the wall slide exercise.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Proprioception
phase_2.goal: Improve shoulder strength and proprioception

exercises.name: Biceps Curl
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) and curl the arm up towards the shoulder, then lower it back down.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing the biceps curl exercise.

exercises.name: Shoulder Rotation
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) and rotate the shoulder in a circular motion, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing the shoulder rotation exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve shoulder strength and functional abilities

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercise
exercises.instructions: Use a resistance band to perform biceps curls, shoulder rotations, and other exercises that mimic daily activities.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing resistance band exercises.

exercises.name: Functional Activities
exercises.instructions: Perform daily activities such as carrying groceries, lifting objects, and reaching overhead.
exercises.dosage: As tolerated, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing functional activities.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Bicipital tendinitis diagnosed through physical examination, medical history, and imaging studies (e.g., ultrasound, MRI).
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization may be used to reduce pain and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, overhead activities, and repetitive motions that aggravate the condition.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2020). Biceps Tendinitis. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/biceps-tendinitis/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Spondylolisthesis is a condition where one of the vertebrae in the spine slips out of place, often onto the vertebra below it. This can cause pain and discomfort in the lower back, as well as numbness or tingling in the legs.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An X-ray image showing the slippage of a vertebra in the lumbar spine

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency, 100 Hz, 30 minutes, 3 times a day
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the spine, at the level of the slipped vertebra
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and discomfort in the lower back
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the lower back

electrotherapy.parameters: Medium frequency, 50 Hz, 20 minutes, 2 times a day
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the affected area, with one electrode on either side of the spine
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce inflammation and promote healing in the affected area
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of IFC electrodes on the lower back

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote healing

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Tilt your pelvis upwards and then back down again, repeating the motion for 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the pelvic tilt exercise

exercises.name: Knee to Chest Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back and bring one knee towards your chest. Hold for 30 seconds and then switch to the other knee
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the knee to chest stretch

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase
phase_2.goal: To improve flexibility and strength in the lower back

exercises.name: Cat-Cow Stretch
exercises.instructions: Start on your hands and knees. Arch your back and lift your tailbone towards the ceiling (like a cat). Then, round your back and tuck your chin towards your chest (like a cow). Repeat for 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the cat-cow stretch

exercises.name: Bridge Exercise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes and lower back muscles as you lift. Hold for 2 seconds and then lower back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the bridge exercise

phase_3.name: Strengthening Phase
phase_3.goal: To improve strength and stability in the lower back

exercises.name: Plank Exercise
exercises.instructions: Start in a push-up position, with your hands shoulder-width apart and your body in a straight line from head to heels. Hold for 30-60 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the plank exercise

exercises.name: Superman Exercise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your stomach with your arms extended in front of you. Lift your arms and legs off the ground, holding for 2 seconds. Lower back down and repeat for 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the superman exercise

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment and diagnosis of spondylolisthesis should include a medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies such as X-rays or MRI
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques such as spinal mobilization and massage can be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and promote healing
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients with spondylolisthesis should avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and should take regular breaks to stretch and move throughout the day

scientific_reference: The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) and the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) provide guidelines for the treatment and management of spondylolisthesis

clinical_presentation.definition: Lumbar stenosis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the spinal canal in the lower back, which can put pressure on the spinal cord and nerves, leading to pain, numbness, and weakness in the back and legs.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the narrowing of the spinal canal in the lumbar region

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the lumbar spine, 2-3 inches apart
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of IFC electrodes placed on the lumbar spine

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 10-200 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the lumbar spine, 1-2 inches apart
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and improve mobility
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of TENS electrodes placed on the lumbar spine

phase_1.name: Pain Relief and Mobility
phase_1.goal: Improve mobility and reduce pain

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, tilt your pelvis upwards and then back down again
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the pelvic tilt exercise

exercises.name: Knee to Chest Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back and bring one knee towards your chest, hold for 30 seconds and then switch sides
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the knee to chest stretch

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Stabilization
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and stability of the lumbar spine

exercises.name: Plank
exercises.instructions: Start in a push-up position, engage your core and hold for 30-60 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the plank exercise

exercises.name: Bridge
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, lift your hips up towards the ceiling
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the bridge exercise

phase_3.name: Functional Activities and Proprioception
phase_3.goal: Improve functional activities and proprioception

exercises.name: Lumbar Extensions
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, slowly lean back and then return to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the lumbar extension exercise

exercises.name: Balance Exercises
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, hold for 30 seconds and then switch sides
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the balance exercise

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Lumbar stenosis is typically diagnosed through a combination of medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies such as X-rays, CT scans, or MRI scans
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy such as spinal mobilization and massage can help improve mobility and reduce pain
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and take regular breaks to stretch and move around

scientific_reference: American College of Physicians. (2017). Noninvasive Treatments for Acute, Subacute, and Chronic Low Back Pain: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American College of Physicians. Annals of Internal Medicine, 166(7), 514-530.

clinical_presentation.definition: A whiplash injury is a non-life-threatening neck injury that occurs when the head is suddenly forced forward and then backward, or vice versa, causing strain on the neck muscles and ligaments.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the cervical spine with the neck muscles and ligaments highlighted to demonstrate the mechanism of whiplash injury.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 80-100 Hz, Pulse duration: 50-100 μs
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the cervical spine, avoiding the spine itself
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation in the affected area
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the neck for whiplash injury treatment

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 5-15 mA, Frequency: 4 kHz, Beat frequency: 10-100 Hz
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the affected area, using a quadripolar setup
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: An illustration of the quadripolar setup for IFC therapy on the neck

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-72 hours)
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote relaxation

exercises.name: Chin Tucks
exercises.instructions: Slowly tuck the chin towards the chest, holding for 10 seconds, and then release
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a chin tuck exercise

exercises.name: Shoulder Rolls
exercises.instructions: Roll the shoulders forward and backward in a circular motion
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing shoulder rolls

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase (3-14 days)
phase_2.goal: To improve range of motion and strength

exercises.name: Cervical Rotation
exercises.instructions: Slowly rotate the head to the right and left, holding for 10 seconds, and then release
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing cervical rotation

exercises.name: Scalene Stretching
exercises.instructions: Slowly tilt the head to the right, bringing the ear towards the right shoulder, and then release
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing scalene stretching

phase_3.name: Strengthening Phase (after 14 days)
phase_3.goal: To improve strength and endurance

exercises.name: Cervical Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the head off the ground, holding for 10 seconds, and then release
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing cervical extension

exercises.name: Shoulder Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Perform shoulder flexion, extension, and rotation exercises using light weights or resistance bands
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing shoulder strengthening exercises

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment of the patient's neck and shoulder region, including range of motion, strength, and pain levels, to determine the severity of the whiplash injury
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization, joint mobilization, and cervical traction may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and promote relaxation
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid driving or operating heavy machinery until symptoms have resolved

scientific_reference: The treatment protocol is based on the guidelines set forth by the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) and the Orthopaedic Section of the APTA, as well as the scientific literature on whiplash injury treatment

clinical_presentation.definition: A meniscal injury is a tear in the cartilage of the knee joint, which can cause pain, swelling, and limited mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram of the knee joint showing the meniscus and surrounding structures.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2, 5-10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the affected area, using a liberal amount of gel to ensure good contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an ultrasound machine being used to treat a meniscal injury.

electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the IFC electrodes on either side of the affected area, using a liberal amount of gel to ensure good contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an IFC machine being used to treat a meniscal injury.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the leg straight out in front of you, keeping the knee straight, and then lower it back down.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a knee extension exercise.

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, keeping the foot behind you, and then straighten it back out.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a knee flexion exercise.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: To improve range of motion, strength, and function.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the leg straight out in front of you, keeping the knee straight, and then lower it back down.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a straight leg raise exercise.

exercises.name: Wall Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall and slowly slide down into a squat, keeping your back against the wall, and then stand back up.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a wall squat exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (6-12 weeks)
phase_3.goal: To improve strength, power, and function.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Step out with one foot and lower your body down into a lunge, keeping your back knee almost touching the ground, and then stand back up.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a lunge exercise.

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform agility drills such as zig-zag running, shuttle runs, and figure-eight drills.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing agility drills.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment and diagnosis is necessary to determine the extent of the meniscal injury and to develop an effective treatment plan.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization may be used to improve range of motion and reduce pain and stiffness.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid putting excessive stress on the affected knee.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2019). Meniscal Tears. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/meniscal-tears/>

clinical_presentation.definition: A hamstring muscle strain is an injury to one or more of the muscles in the back of the thigh, which can occur in children and adolescents due to overuse, direct trauma, or sudden contraction of the muscle.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Illustration of the hamstring muscles in the back of the thigh

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the affected hamstring muscle
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of IFC therapy electrodes placed on the hamstring muscle

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-3 MHz, Intensity: 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply ultrasound gel to the affected area and move the transducer in a circular motion
electrotherapy.goal: Promote tissue healing and reduce inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of ultrasound therapy being applied to the hamstring muscle

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-72 hours)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing

exercises.name: Hamstring Stretching
exercises.instructions: Stand with the affected leg behind the unaffected leg, lean forward at the hips, and stretch the back of the thigh
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 30 seconds, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a child performing a hamstring stretch

exercises.name: Isometric Hamstring Contraction
exercises.instructions: Sit on the floor with the affected leg straight out in front, contract the hamstring muscle without moving the leg
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a child performing an isometric hamstring contraction

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (72 hours-2 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve range of motion, strength, and function

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, lift the affected leg straight up towards the ceiling
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a child performing a straight leg raise

exercises.name: Bent Knee Stretch
exercises.instructions: Sit on the floor with the affected leg bent behind you, lean back and stretch the front of the knee
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 30 seconds, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a child performing a bent knee stretch

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Improve strength, power, and functional ability

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with the affected leg in front, take a large step forward, and lower your body down until your back knee almost touches the ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a child performing a lunge

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform shuttle runs, zig-zag runs, or other agility drills to improve speed, agility, and quickness
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 30 seconds, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a child performing agility drills

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the child's range of motion, strength, and functional ability to determine the severity of the injury
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization to promote tissue healing and reduce pain and inflammation
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid activities that aggravate the condition
