scientific_reference: American Academy of Pediatrics, American College of Sports Medicine, National Athletic Trainers' Association

clinical_presentation.definition: A quadriceps muscle strain is an injury to the quadriceps muscle, which is located in the front of the thigh. It is commonly caused by overstretching or tearing of the muscle fibers, often as a result of sudden contraction or excessive force.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the quadriceps muscle and its location in the thigh, with a red mark indicating the area of strain.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the quadriceps muscle, approximately 2-3 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for IFC therapy on the quadriceps muscle.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the quadriceps muscle, approximately 2-3 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and discomfort
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for TENS therapy on the quadriceps muscle.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-72 hours)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote healing

exercises.name: Quadriceps Sets
exercises.instructions: Tighten the quadriceps muscle, holding for 5 seconds, then release. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing quadriceps sets, with a red arrow indicating the contraction of the muscle.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the affected leg straight up, keeping the knee straight, then lower it back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a straight leg raise, with a red arrow indicating the movement of the leg.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (72 hours-2 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve range of motion, strength, and function

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the affected leg, keeping the knee straight, then lower it back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing knee extension, with a red arrow indicating the movement of the leg.

exercises.name: Wall Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with your back against a wall, then slowly slide down into a squat, keeping your back against the wall. Hold for 10-15 seconds, then stand up. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing wall squats, with a red arrow indicating the movement of the body.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Improve strength, power, and functional ability

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, then take a large step forward with the affected leg. Lower your body down into a lunge, keeping your back knee almost touching the ground. Push back up to the starting position. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing lunges, with a red arrow indicating the movement of the body.

exercises.name: Leg Press
exercises.instructions: Sit in a leg press machine, then push the platform away from you with your affected leg. Lower the platform back down, then repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing leg press, with a red arrow indicating the movement of the leg.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a physical examination and medical history, is necessary to diagnose a quadriceps muscle strain.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to promote healing and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as heavy lifting, bending, or twisting. Use proper lifting techniques and avoid overexertion.

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine. (2018). ACSM's Sports Medicine: A Comprehensive Review. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer.

clinical_presentation.definition: Achilles tendinopathy is a common condition characterized by pain, swelling, and stiffness in the Achilles tendon, which connects the calf muscles to the heel bone. In geriatric populations, it is often related to degenerative changes, reduced physical activity, and age-related declines in tendon health.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the anatomy of the Achilles tendon and its connection to the calf muscles and heel bone.

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 630-1000nm, Intensity: 10-100mW/cm², Duration: 10-20 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The laser probe is placed directly over the affected Achilles tendon, with the patient in a prone position with the foot hanging off the end of the treatment table.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue repair, and enhance tendon healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: A photograph of a physiotherapist applying LLLT to a patient's Achilles tendon.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-3MHz, Intensity: 0.5-1.5W/cm², Duration: 10-15 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The ultrasound transducer is placed over the affected Achilles tendon, using a generous amount of coupling gel to ensure good contact.
electrotherapy.goal: To increase blood flow, reduce inflammation, and promote tissue repair.
electrotherapy.image_description: An illustration of the ultrasound transducer placement on the Achilles tendon.

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and maintain ankle range of motion.

exercises.name: Ankle Mobilization
exercises.instructions: Gently move the ankle through its range of motion, including dorsiflexion, plantarflexion, inversion, and eversion.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the different ankle movements.

exercises.name: Calf Stretching
exercises.instructions: Stand facing a wall with one hand on the wall for balance, step one foot back about a foot, and keep the heel on the ground. Slowly bend the front knee, keeping the back leg straight, until a stretch is felt in the calf.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30-second hold, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a patient performing a calf stretch.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Proprioception
phase_2.goal: To strengthen the calf muscles and improve proprioception.

exercises.name: Heel Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the edge of a stair or step with the heels hanging off, raise up onto the toes, and then lower back down.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the heel raise exercise.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, and hold for 10-30 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10-30 seconds, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a patient performing single-leg balance.

phase_3.name: Functional and Sports-Specific Training
phase_3.goal: To progress to functional and sports-specific activities.

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform agility drills such as zig-zag running, shuttle runs, and cone drills.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week, progressing to more complex drills
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing an example of an agility drill.

exercises.name: Plyometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform plyometric exercises such as jump squats and box jumps.
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week, progressing to more complex exercises
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a patient performing a plyometric exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic imaging (e.g., ultrasound or MRI), is necessary to diagnose Achilles tendinopathy.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization, may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue repair.
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients with Achilles tendinopathy should avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as running or jumping, and should wear proper footwear with adequate support.

scientific_reference: Alfredson H, Lorentzon R. Chronic Achilles tendinosis: recommendations for treatment and prevention. Sports Med. 2000;29(2):135-146.

clinical_presentation.definition: Patellar tendinopathy, also known as jumper's knee, is a condition characterized by pain and inflammation in the patellar tendon, which connects the kneecap to the shinbone. It is commonly seen in athletes who participate in sports that involve repetitive jumping and landing.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the location of the patellar tendon and the areas of pain associated with patellar tendinopathy.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The ultrasound probe is placed over the affected area, with a coupling medium (gel or oil) used to facilitate transmission of the ultrasound waves.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue repair, and improve function.
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of an ultrasound machine being used to treat the patellar tendon.

electrotherapy.parameters: 630-1000 nm wavelength, 10-100 mW/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The laser probe is placed over the affected area, with the treatment area being approximately 1-2 cm in diameter.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue repair, and improve function.
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of a low-level laser therapy device being used to treat the patellar tendon.

phase_1.name: Acute phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue repair, and maintain range of motion.

exercises.name: Straight leg raise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with the affected leg straight and the other leg bent. Slowly lift the straight leg about 6-8 inches off the ground, then lower it back down. Repeat for 3 sets of 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a straight leg raise exercise.

exercises.name: Knee extension
exercises.instructions: Sit on the floor with the affected leg straight and the other leg bent. Slowly lift the straight leg about 6-8 inches off the ground, then lower it back down. Repeat for 3 sets of 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a knee extension exercise.

phase_2.name: Subacute phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: To improve strength, flexibility, and function.

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Slowly lower your body down into a squat, keeping your back straight and your knees behind your toes. Push back up to the starting position. Repeat for 3 sets of 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a squat exercise.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet together. Take a large step forward with one foot and lower your body down into a lunge, keeping your back straight and your front knee behind your toes. Push back up to the starting position. Repeat on the other side. Repeat for 3 sets of 10 repetitions on each leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions on each leg, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a lunge exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced phase (6-12 weeks)
phase_3.goal: To improve power, speed, and agility.

exercises.name: Plyometric exercises
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Jump up onto a box or bench, then step back down to the starting position. Repeat for 3 sets of 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a plyometric exercise.

exercises.name: Agility drills
exercises.instructions: Set up a course with cones or markers. Weave through the course, changing direction quickly and using different speeds and movements. Repeat for 3 sets of 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing an agility drill.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a physical examination and review of medical history, is necessary to diagnose patellar tendinopathy. Imaging studies, such as X-rays or MRI, may be ordered to rule out other conditions.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients with patellar tendinopathy should avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as repetitive jumping and landing. They should also avoid heavy lifting, bending, and twisting.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2019). Patellar Tendinopathy (Jumper's Knee). Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/patellar-tendinopathy-jumpers-knee/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS) is a common overuse injury affecting the lower leg, characterized by pain and inflammation in the medial (inner) aspect of the tibia.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the medial aspect of the tibia with inflammation and pain

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable, Duration: 15-20 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the medial tibia, 2-3 inches apart
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of IFC electrodes placed on the medial tibia

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable, Duration: 15-20 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the medial tibia, 2-3 inches apart
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of TENS electrodes placed on the medial tibia

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation

exercises.name: Ankle Mobilization
exercises.instructions: Gently move the ankle through its range of motion, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of ankle mobilization

exercises.name: Toe Raises
exercises.instructions: Slowly raise up onto the toes, then lower back down, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of toe raises

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and flexibility

exercises.name: Calf Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the edge of a step or curb with the heels hanging off, raise up onto the toes, then lower back down, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of calf raises

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, 3 sets of 30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of single-leg balance

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase
phase_3.goal: Improve functional strength and agility

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform drills that mimic the demands of the sport, such as zig-zag running or shuttle runs, 3 sets of 30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of agility drills

exercises.name: Plyometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform exercises that involve jumping and landing, such as box jumps or depth jumps, 3 sets of 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of plyometric exercises

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies (if necessary), is necessary to diagnose MTSS
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage and joint mobilization, can be used to reduce pain and inflammation
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as running or jumping, and avoid overstretching or overstrengthening the affected area

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine. (2018). ACSM's Sports Medicine: A Comprehensive Review. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer

clinical_presentation.definition: Anterior shoulder instability is a condition where the shoulder joint is prone to dislocation or subluxation due to a disruption in the normal anatomical and physiological relationships between the humeral head and the glenoid cavity, often resulting from trauma, repetitive strain, or neurological conditions affecting the shoulder muscles.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the anterior aspect of the shoulder joint, highlighting the humeral head, glenoid cavity, and surrounding muscles and ligaments.

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency, 100 Hz, 30 minutes, 3 times a day
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the skin over the affected shoulder muscles, avoiding bony prominences and areas with reduced sensation.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and improve muscle function.
electrotherapy.image_description: A photograph showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the shoulder region.

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion in the shoulder joint.

exercises.name: Pendulum Exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected arm, and gently swing the arm in a small circle, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the pendulum exercise, with the arm swinging in a small circle.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Stabilization
phase_2.goal: To strengthen the shoulder muscles and improve joint stability.

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercise
exercises.instructions: Use a resistance band to perform shoulder rotations, keeping the arm at a 90-degree angle to the body.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A photograph showing the use of a resistance band for shoulder rotations.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: To advance strengthening exercises and incorporate functional activities to improve overall shoulder function.

exercises.name: Push-Up Exercise
exercises.instructions: Perform a push-up with the hands shoulder-width apart, keeping the body in a straight line from head to heels.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A photograph showing the proper form for a push-up exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment of the shoulder joint, including range of motion, strength, and stability, is necessary to diagnose anterior shoulder instability.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue massage, may be used to improve joint mobility and reduce muscle tension.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid activities that aggravate the condition.

scientific_reference: The American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) and the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) provide guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of anterior shoulder instability.

clinical_presentation.definition: Adductor tendinopathy, also known as groin strain, is a common injury in pediatric athletes, particularly those involved in sports that require rapid changes of direction, such as soccer, hockey, and football. It is characterized by pain and inflammation in the adductor muscles, which are located in the thigh.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the location of the adductor muscles in the thigh, with a red circle indicating the area of pain and inflammation.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The ultrasound probe is placed directly over the affected area, with a thin layer of gel to facilitate transmission.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing, and improve range of motion.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an ultrasound machine being used to treat the adductor muscles.

electrotherapy.parameters: 50-100 Hz frequency, 10-20 mA intensity, 10-15 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: The IFC electrodes are placed on either side of the affected area, with the current flowing through the tissue.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of IFC electrodes on the skin.

phase_1.name: Acute phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.

exercises.name: Adductor stretching
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet wide apart, then bend your knee and lean to one side, stretching the adductor muscles.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30 seconds, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the adductor stretch.

exercises.name: Straight leg raise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back and lift one leg straight up, keeping your knee straight.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the correct technique for the straight leg raise exercise.

phase_2.name: Sub-acute phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: To improve strength and flexibility, and promote functional movement.

exercises.name: Adductor strengthening
exercises.instructions: Sit on the floor with your legs straight out in front of you, then lift one leg out to the side, keeping your knee straight.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the adductor strengthening exercise.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet together, take a large step forward with one foot, and lower your body down into a lunge position.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the correct technique for the lunge exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced phase (6-12 weeks)
phase_3.goal: To improve power and agility, and promote return to sport.

exercises.name: Agility drills
exercises.instructions: Perform shuttle runs, cone drills, or other agility exercises to improve speed and quickness.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing agility drills.

exercises.name: Plyometric exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform jump squats, box jumps, or other plyometric exercises to improve power and explosiveness.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the correct technique for the jump squat exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including history, physical examination, and imaging studies (e.g. X-ray, MRI), is necessary to diagnose adductor tendinopathy.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to promote tissue healing and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as running or jumping, and use proper warm-up and cool-down techniques to prevent further injury.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Pediatrics, 'Pediatric Sports Medicine: A Comprehensive Guide' (2018); Journal of Pediatric Orthopedics, 'Adductor Tendinopathy in Pediatric Athletes' (2020)

clinical_presentation.definition: Inflammation of the plantar fascia, a band of tissue that supports the arch of the foot, leading to pain and stiffness in the heel and bottom of the foot.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram of the foot showing the plantar fascia and its location

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 630-700nm, Intensity: 10-100mW, Duration: 10-20 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply the laser probe to the affected area, 1-2cm from the skin
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue repair
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a low-level laser therapy device being applied to the foot

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100Hz, Intensity: 10-50mA, Duration: 15-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the affected area, 5-10cm apart
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve circulation
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for interferential current therapy

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Inflammation Management
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion

exercises.name: Toe Spreads
exercises.instructions: Sit on the floor with your affected leg straight out in front of you, loop a towel around the ball of your foot and gently pull your toes back toward your shin, holding for 15-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing toe spreads

exercises.name: Heel Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the edge of a stair or curb with your heels hanging off, raise up onto your tiptoes and then lower back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing heel raises

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Proprioception
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and proprioception in the foot and ankle

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, hold for 10-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing single-leg balance

phase_3.name: Functional Activities and Return to Sport
phase_3.goal: Improve functional activities and return to sport or activity

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform agility drills such as zig-zag running, shuttle runs, and cone drills
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week, as tolerated
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing agility drills

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess for pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the foot and ankle, diagnose plantar fasciitis based on clinical presentation and imaging studies
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization to reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as running or jumping, use orthotics or shoe inserts to reduce stress on the plantar fascia

scientific_reference: American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) guidelines for the treatment of plantar fasciitis

clinical_presentation.definition: A stress fracture is a small crack in a bone, often caused by overuse or repetitive stress. In the geriatric population, stress fractures can occur due to osteoporosis, poor balance, or decreased mobility. Post-immobilization refers to the period after the initial immobilization phase, where the goal is to gradually increase weight-bearing and mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: X-ray image of a stress fracture in the hip or lower extremity, with callus formation and bone remodeling visible.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable, sweep mode
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes around the affected area, avoiding bony prominences
electrotherapy.goal: Pain management and inflammation reduction
electrotherapy.image_description: Electrode placement diagram for IFC treatment

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-3 MHz, Intensity: 0.5-1.5 W/cm2, duty cycle: 20%
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply ultrasound gel to the affected area and use a gentle, sweeping motion
electrotherapy.goal: Promote bone healing and tissue repair
electrotherapy.image_description: Ultrasound treatment diagram, showing the affected area and transducer placement

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Pain management, inflammation reduction, and gentle mobilization

exercises.name: Ankle Mobility
exercises.instructions: Gently move the ankle through a range of motion, avoiding weight-bearing
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing ankle mobility exercises while seated

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, keeping the foot behind the body
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing knee flexion exercises while seated

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Progressive weight-bearing, strengthening, and proprioception

exercises.name: Weight-Bearing Heel Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on a flat surface, raise up onto the toes, and then lower back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing weight-bearing heel raises

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, keeping the other foot lifted off the ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30-second hold, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing single-leg balance exercises

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (6-12 weeks)
phase_3.goal: High-level strengthening, agility, and functional activities

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform figure-eight patterns around cones or small obstacles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30 seconds, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing agility drills

exercises.name: Stair Climbing
exercises.instructions: Climb up and down a set of stairs, using handrails for support if needed
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient climbing stairs

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment, including radiographs, to confirm stress fracture diagnosis and rule out other conditions
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Gentle joint mobilization and soft tissue techniques to promote relaxation and reduce pain
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid high-impact activities, excessive weight-bearing, or bending/twisting movements that may exacerbate the stress fracture

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) guidelines for stress fracture management, Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy (JOSPT) articles on geriatric rehabilitation

clinical_presentation.definition: Stroke rehabilitation is a program designed for patients who have experienced a stroke, with the goal of regaining lost abilities and skills, as well as adapting to any residual disabilities.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a patient undergoing physical therapy after a stroke, with a therapist assisting them in performing exercises to regain strength and mobility.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Pulse duration: 200-400 us
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on affected muscles, such as the quadriceps, hamstrings, and tibialis anterior
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength and function, enhance motor control and coordination
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a patient with electrodes placed on their leg, receiving FES therapy to stimulate muscle contractions.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-50 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Pulse duration: 50-100 us
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on affected areas, such as the shoulder, elbow, or knee
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion and mobility
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of a patient with electrodes placed on their shoulder, receiving TENS therapy to reduce pain and inflammation.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks post-stroke)
phase_1.goal: Improve range of motion, reduce pain and inflammation, and promote early mobilization

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM) exercises
exercises.instructions: Therapist-assisted movements of the affected joints, such as the shoulder, elbow, and knee
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a therapist assisting a patient in performing PROM exercises for the shoulder joint.

exercises.name: Bridging exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient lies on their back, lifts their hips off the bed, and holds for 5-10 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing bridging exercises to strengthen their hip and core muscles.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks post-stroke)
phase_2.goal: Improve muscle strength, endurance, and function, as well as promote mobility and balance

exercises.name: Resistance band exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient uses resistance bands to perform exercises such as shoulder rotations, elbow flexions, and knee extensions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient using resistance bands to perform exercises for the upper limb.

exercises.name: Balance exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient stands on a foam pad or BOSU ball, performs single-leg stance, and holds for 10-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing balance exercises on a foam pad to improve their balance and proprioception.

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (6 weeks or more post-stroke)
phase_3.goal: Improve functional abilities, such as walking, stair climbing, and activities of daily living

exercises.name: Gait training exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient practices walking on a treadmill or over ground, with or without assistance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 minutes, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient walking on a treadmill with assistance from a therapist.

exercises.name: Stair climbing exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient practices climbing stairs, with or without assistance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient climbing stairs with assistance from a therapist.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Patient presents with hemiparesis, decreased range of motion, and impaired balance and coordination
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Therapist uses techniques such as joint mobilization, soft tissue mobilization, and proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation to promote relaxation, reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion
clinical_notes.precautions: Patient has a history of falls, and therefore requires close supervision during exercises and activities

scientific_reference: American Heart Association. (2019). Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients with Acute Ischemic Stroke: 2019 Update to the 2018 Guidelines for the Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke.

clinical_presentation.definition: Parkinson’s Disease is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by tremors, stiffness, bradykinesia, and postural instability, affecting motor control and coordination.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a person with Parkinson’s Disease showing tremors and bradykinesia

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency, 100 Hz, 30 minutes, 3 times a week
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the affected muscles, such as the quadriceps and hamstrings
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce muscle spasms and improve motor control
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of TENS unit and electrode placement on the leg

phase_1.name: Initial Mobility and Balance
phase_1.goal: Improve balance, flexibility, and range of motion

exercises.name: Seated Marching
exercises.instructions: Sit on a chair with feet flat on the floor, lift one leg off the ground and march in place, alternating legs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person seated on a chair, marching in place

exercises.name: Standing Heel-To-Toe Walking
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet together, take small steps, placing the heel of one foot directly in front of the toes of the other foot
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 steps, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing, walking heel-to-toe

phase_2.name: Progressive Strengthening
phase_2.goal: Improve muscle strength and endurance

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, slowly lower body down into a squat, then stand up
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing, performing a squat

exercises.name: Step-Ups
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a stair or step, step up with one foot, then step back down with the same foot
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps (5 per leg), 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing, stepping up and down

phase_3.name: Advanced Balance and Coordination
phase_3.goal: Improve balance, coordination, and overall functional ability

exercises.name: Single-Leg Standing
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30 seconds (15 per leg), 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person standing on one leg

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform agility drills, such as zig-zag running or shuttle runs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30 seconds, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing agility drills

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment, including medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests (e.g. MRI, EMG)
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, to improve range of motion and reduce stiffness
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of fatigue, dizziness, or increased tremors, and adjust treatment protocol as needed

scientific_reference: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke. (2022). Parkinson’s Disease: Hope Through Research.

clinical_presentation.definition: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic and often disabling autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, causing a wide range of symptoms including vision loss, fatigue, numbness, weakness, tremors, and difficulty with coordination and balance.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the central nervous system with lesions on the brain and spinal cord, representing the damage caused by multiple sclerosis.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Duration: 15-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the affected muscles, such as the quadriceps or hamstrings, to stimulate muscle contractions and improve strength and function.
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength, reduce spasticity, and enhance functional abilities.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes on the quadriceps muscle for FES treatment.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-50 mA, Frequency: 10-100 Hz, Duration: 15-60 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the skin near the affected area, such as the lower back or legs, to relieve pain and reduce muscle spasms.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain, alleviate muscle spasms, and improve overall comfort.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a TENS unit with electrodes placed on the lower back.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Improve mobility, reduce fatigue, and enhance overall function.

exercises.name: Range of Motion Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform gentle, passive range of motion exercises for the upper and lower limbs, 2-3 times a day.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing range of motion exercises for the shoulder joint.

exercises.name: Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Practice deep, diaphragmatic breathing exercises to improve respiratory function and reduce fatigue.
exercises.dosage: 5-10 minutes, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the proper technique for diaphragmatic breathing.

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase
phase_2.goal: Progress mobility, strength, and endurance.

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform resistance band exercises for the upper and lower limbs, 2-3 times a week.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person using resistance bands to perform bicep curls.

exercises.name: Balance and Coordination Exercises
exercises.instructions: Practice balance and coordination exercises, such as single-leg standing or heel-to-toe walking, 2-3 times a week.
exercises.dosage: 3-5 sets, 30-60 seconds each
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing single-leg standing exercises.

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase
phase_3.goal: Maintain mobility, strength, and endurance, and promote overall wellness.

exercises.name: Aerobic Exercise
exercises.instructions: Engage in regular aerobic exercise, such as walking or cycling, for at least 30 minutes, 3-4 times a week.
exercises.dosage: 30-60 minutes, 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person walking on a treadmill.

exercises.name: Stretching and Foam Rolling
exercises.instructions: Perform regular stretching and foam rolling exercises to maintain flexibility and reduce muscle tension.
exercises.dosage: 10-15 minutes, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person using a foam roller to stretch the IT band.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A comprehensive assessment, including a thorough medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests, such as MRI or EMG, to confirm the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage or joint mobilization, may be used to reduce muscle spasms, improve range of motion, and enhance overall function.
clinical_notes.precautions: Precautions should be taken to avoid exacerbating symptoms, such as heat intolerance, and to prevent falls or injuries.

scientific_reference: National Multiple Sclerosis Society. (2020). Multiple Sclerosis: A Guide for Patients and Families. New York, NY: National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

clinical_presentation.definition: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) in pediatrics refers to a non-degenerative, non-congenital insult to the brain from an external mechanical force, which may lead to temporary or permanent cognitive, emotional, or physical impairments.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the brain with areas affected by traumatic brain injury

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 1-2 mA, Duration: 20-30 minutes, Frequency: 3-5 times a week
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Anode placement on the affected hemisphere, cathode on the contralateral hemisphere
electrotherapy.goal: Improve cognitive function, particularly attention and memory
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a tDCS device with electrode placement on the head

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Promote safety, reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM) Exercises
exercises.instructions: Gentle, pain-free movements of the joints to maintain range of motion
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a therapist performing PROM exercises on a pediatric patient

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve strength, balance, and coordination

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to strengthen muscles, starting with low resistance and progressing to higher levels
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a pediatric patient performing resistance band exercises

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase
phase_3.goal: Improve functional abilities, such as activities of daily living (ADLs) and community integration

exercises.name: Functional Activities
exercises.instructions: Practice ADLs, such as dressing, feeding, and grooming, with gradual increase in difficulty
exercises.dosage: As tolerated, with regular breaks and supervision
exercises.image_description: A picture of a pediatric patient performing functional activities with assistance

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment, including neurological examination, cognitive and behavioral evaluation, and imaging studies (e.g., CT or MRI) to diagnose TBI and guide treatment
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Gentle mobilization and manipulation techniques to improve range of motion, reduce pain and inflammation, and promote relaxation
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as headache, nausea, and vomiting, and adjust treatment accordingly

scientific_reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2020). Traumatic Brain Injury & Concussion. Retrieved from https://www.cdc.gov/traumaticbraininjury/index.html

clinical_presentation.definition: Incomplete spinal cord injuries occur when there is damage to the spinal cord, but some nerve fibers remain intact, allowing for some sensation and motor function below the level of injury.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the spinal cord with areas of damage and intact nerve fibers.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Pulse duration: 200-400 microseconds
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Electrodes placed on the skin over the affected muscles, with the cathode proximal to the anode
electrotherapy.goal: Improve respiratory muscle strength and endurance
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a patient with electrodes placed on their chest and abdomen, connected to an FES device.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Improve respiratory function and prevent complications

exercises.name: Deep Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Inhale deeply through the nose, hold for 2-3 seconds, and exhale slowly through the mouth
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing deep breathing exercises with a respiratory therapist.

exercises.name: Chest Expansion Exercises
exercises.instructions: Place hands on the chest and inhale deeply, feeling the chest expand
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing chest expansion exercises.

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve respiratory muscle strength and endurance

exercises.name: Resistive Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Inhale through a resistive device, such as a threshold inspiratory muscle trainer
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing resistive breathing exercises with a threshold inspiratory muscle trainer.

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (beyond 6 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Maintain respiratory function and overall fitness

exercises.name: Aerobic Exercise
exercises.instructions: Perform aerobic exercises, such as arm cycling or wheelchair propulsion, for 20-30 minutes, 2-3 times a week
exercises.dosage: 20-30 minutes, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing arm cycling exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess respiratory function, including lung volumes, capacities, and flow rates, to determine the extent of injury and guide treatment.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques, such as chest percussion and vibration, to help loosen secretions and improve lung expansion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of respiratory distress, such as shortness of breath, wheezing, or coughing, and adjust treatment accordingly.

scientific_reference: American Thoracic Society. (2019). Respiratory care of the patient with spinal cord injury. American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, 200(3), 361-371.

clinical_presentation.definition: Peripheral neuropathy refers to the damage or disease affecting peripheral nerves, which may impair sensation, movement, gland or organ function, or other aspects of health, depending on the type of nerve affected.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the peripheral nervous system, highlighting the areas commonly affected by peripheral neuropathy.

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency: 50-100 Hz, Low intensity: 10-20 mA, Treatment duration: 20-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the affected area, avoiding sensitive areas and wounds.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and improve sensation in the affected area.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a TENS unit with electrodes placed on the affected area.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA, Treatment duration: 15-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the affected area, using a quad-pole setup.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain, inflammation, and muscle spasms in the affected area.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the quad-pole setup for IFC therapy.

phase_1.name: Pain Management and Sensory Stimulation
phase_1.goal: To reduce pain and improve sensation in the affected area.

exercises.name: Ankle Mobilization
exercises.instructions: Gently move the ankle through its range of motion, 5-10 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing ankle mobilization exercises.

exercises.name: Toe Spreads
exercises.instructions: Spread the toes as far apart as possible, then bring them back together, 5-10 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing toe spread exercises.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Balance
phase_2.goal: To improve strength, balance, and proprioception in the affected area.

exercises.name: Heel Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the affected leg, raise up onto the toes, then lower back down, 5-10 repetitions, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing heel raise exercises.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on the affected leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, 5-10 seconds, 3 sets.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing single-leg balance exercises.

phase_3.name: Functional Activities and Proprioception
phase_3.goal: To improve functional activities and proprioception in the affected area.

exercises.name: Walking on Different Surfaces
exercises.instructions: Walk on different surfaces, such as carpet, tile, and grass, to challenge balance and proprioception.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person walking on different surfaces.

exercises.name: Stair Climbing
exercises.instructions: Climb stairs, using the handrail for support if needed, to challenge strength and balance.
exercises.dosage: 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person climbing stairs.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests, such as electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies (NCS), to diagnose peripheral neuropathy.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to reduce pain and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Precautions should be taken to avoid further injury or damage to the affected area, such as avoiding heavy lifting, bending, or twisting.

scientific_reference: American Physical Therapy Association. (2020). Physical Therapy Management of Peripheral Neuropathy. Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy, 50(5), 241-253.

clinical_presentation.definition: Cerebral Palsy (Spastic Diplegia) is a neurological disorder that affects movement, muscle tone, and coordination, primarily in the legs, due to brain damage before, during, or shortly after birth.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a child with Spastic Diplegia showing tight muscle tone in the legs

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Duration: 30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the quadriceps and hamstring muscles
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength and reduce spasticity in the legs
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of FES electrodes placed on the quadriceps and hamstring muscles

phase_1.name: Initial Mobility Phase
phase_1.goal: Improve range of motion and reduce muscle tone

exercises.name: Passive Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly extend the knee joint while the patient is in a supine position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a therapist performing passive knee extension on a patient

phase_2.name: Strengthening Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve muscle strength and endurance

exercises.name: Quadriceps Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Have the patient contract the quadriceps muscle while sitting with the leg straight
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing quadriceps strengthening exercise

phase_3.name: Advanced Mobility Phase
phase_3.goal: Improve functional mobility and balance

exercises.name: Single-Leg Standing
exercises.instructions: Have the patient stand on one leg while holding onto a stable object for support
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 30 seconds, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing single-leg standing exercise

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive physical therapy evaluation, including range of motion, strength, and functional mobility assessments
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization and joint mobilization to reduce muscle tone and improve joint mobility
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid overstretching or forcing the joints beyond a comfortable range, as this may cause injury or discomfort

scientific_reference: American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine. (2019). Care Pathways for the Management of Cerebral Palsy.

clinical_presentation.definition: Vestibular hypofunction refers to a condition where the vestibular system, responsible for balance and spatial orientation, is not functioning properly in children. This can lead to symptoms such as dizziness, imbalance, and difficulty with coordination.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram illustrating the vestibular system in the inner ear, highlighting its role in balance and spatial orientation.

electrotherapy.parameters: Customized exercises based on the child's specific needs and symptoms
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Exercises are performed in a clinical setting or at home under the guidance of a physiotherapist
electrotherapy.goal: Improve balance, reduce dizziness, and enhance overall vestibular function
electrotherapy.image_description: A child performing VRT exercises with a physiotherapist, using equipment such as a balance board or virtual reality technology.

phase_1.name: Balance and Coordination
phase_1.goal: Improve static and dynamic balance, as well as overall coordination

exercises.name: Single-Leg Stance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, for 10-15 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 5 repetitions on each leg, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A child standing on one leg, with the other foot lifted, demonstrating good balance and coordination.

exercises.name: Heel-To-Toe Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk along a straight line, placing the heel of one foot directly in front of the toes of the other foot
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 steps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A child walking along a straight line, demonstrating good balance and coordination.

phase_2.name: Advanced Balance and Coordination
phase_2.goal: Challenge the child's balance and coordination systems with more complex exercises

exercises.name: Balance Board Training
exercises.instructions: Stand on a balance board, performing various movements such as squats, lunges, and single-leg stance
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 5 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A child standing on a balance board, performing a squat and demonstrating good balance and coordination.

phase_3.name: Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve the child's ability to perform daily activities with good balance and coordination

exercises.name: Obstacle Course
exercises.instructions: Navigate an obstacle course, incorporating various challenges such as balance beams, cones, and steps
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A child navigating an obstacle course, demonstrating good balance, coordination, and overall functional ability.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A comprehensive assessment, including a thorough medical history, physical examination, and vestibular function tests, is necessary to diagnose vestibular hypofunction in children.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, may be used to improve mobility and reduce stiffness in the neck and upper back.
clinical_notes.precautions: Children with vestibular hypofunction should avoid activities that may exacerbate their symptoms, such as spinning or high-impact exercises.

scientific_reference: The Vestibular Rehabilitation Therapy (VRT) approach is based on the work of Dr. Susan Herdman and Dr. Richard Clendaniel, as outlined in their book 'Vestibular Rehabilitation' (2014).

clinical_presentation.definition: Post-COVID-19 rehabilitation for geriatric patients involves a comprehensive approach to address the physical, functional, and cognitive impairments resulting from COVID-19 infection, with a focus on restoring independence, mobility, and quality of life.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An elderly patient performing exercises with a physiotherapist

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Duration: 20-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the affected area, avoiding bony prominences and sensitive areas
electrotherapy.goal: Pain management and reduction of muscle spasms
electrotherapy.image_description: A TENS unit with electrodes placed on the patient's back

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: Improve respiratory function, reduce pain and inflammation, and promote early mobilization

exercises.name: Deep Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Inhale deeply through the nose, hold for 5 seconds, and exhale slowly through the mouth
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient performing deep breathing exercises with a physiotherapist

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion Exercises
exercises.instructions: Gentle movements of the joints, performed by the physiotherapist
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A physiotherapist performing passive range of motion exercises on a patient's shoulder

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Progressive mobilization, strengthening, and improvement of functional abilities

exercises.name: Active Range of Motion Exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient performs gentle movements of the joints, with assistance from the physiotherapist if needed
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient performing active range of motion exercises with a physiotherapist

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient uses resistance bands to perform strengthening exercises for the upper and lower limbs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient performing resistance band exercises with a physiotherapist

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (beyond 6 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Advanced strengthening, cardiovascular endurance, and functional training

exercises.name: High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT)
exercises.instructions: Patient performs short bursts of high-intensity exercise, followed by periods of rest
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient performing HIIT with a physiotherapist

exercises.name: Functional Training Exercises
exercises.instructions: Patient performs exercises that mimic daily activities, such as walking, climbing stairs, and balance training
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient performing functional training exercises with a physiotherapist

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive geriatric assessment, including medical history, physical examination, and functional evaluation
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization, joint mobilization, and massage therapy to promote relaxation and reduce pain
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of fatigue, shortness of breath, and pain, and adjust the treatment protocol accordingly

scientific_reference: WHO (2020). Clinical management of COVID-19: interim guidance, 27 May 2020

clinical_presentation.definition: Post-Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) is a surgical procedure used to treat coronary artery disease by bypassing blocked or partially blocked arteries with a healthy blood vessel, and the orthopedic management focuses on the musculoskeletal complications and rehabilitation after the surgery.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the CABG surgical procedure and the affected areas of the body.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Pulse duration: 50-100 microseconds
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the affected area, avoiding the sternum and any other sensitive areas.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and discomfort after the surgery.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the body.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks)
phase_1.goal: To improve range of motion, reduce pain and swelling, and promote wound healing.

exercises.name: Deep Breathing Exercises
exercises.instructions: Take slow, deep breaths in through the nose and out through the mouth, focusing on expanding the lungs and diaphragm.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3-4 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture showing a person performing deep breathing exercises.

exercises.name: Shoulder Rolls
exercises.instructions: Roll the shoulders forward and backward in a circular motion, relaxing the shoulder muscles.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3-4 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture showing a person performing shoulder rolls.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_2.goal: To improve strength, flexibility, and mobility, and to promote functional activities.

exercises.name: Arm Raises
exercises.instructions: Raise the arms overhead, keeping them straight, and then lower them back down to the sides.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3-4 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture showing a person performing arm raises.

exercises.name: Leg Lifts
exercises.instructions: Lift one leg off the bed or floor, keeping it straight, and then lower it back down. Alternate legs.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3-4 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture showing a person performing leg lifts.

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase (6 weeks and beyond)
phase_3.goal: To maintain and improve cardiovascular fitness, strength, and flexibility, and to promote long-term functional activities.

exercises.name: Brisk Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk at a brisk pace, either on a treadmill or outdoors, to improve cardiovascular fitness.
exercises.dosage: 30 minutes, 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture showing a person walking briskly outdoors.

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to perform exercises such as bicep curls, tricep extensions, and shoulder presses.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: A picture showing a person performing resistance band exercises.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the patient's range of motion, strength, and functional abilities, and diagnose any musculoskeletal complications or conditions.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization to promote relaxation, reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid any exercises or activities that may cause discomfort, pain, or stress on the sternum or any other sensitive areas.

scientific_reference: American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) guidelines for the management of patients with coronary artery disease, and the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) guidelines for the rehabilitation of patients after CABG surgery.

clinical_presentation.definition: Chronic heart failure is a condition where the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, resulting in symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs and feet.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the heart with a decreased ejection fraction, demonstrating the reduced pumping ability of the heart.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Pulse width: 200-400 microseconds
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on the skin over the area of pain or discomfort, avoiding the chest and heart area
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and improve exercise tolerance
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the skin

phase_1.name: Aerobic Exercise
phase_1.goal: To improve cardiovascular fitness and increase exercise tolerance

exercises.name: Brisk Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk at a brisk pace for 20-30 minutes, 3-4 times a week
exercises.dosage: 20-30 minutes, 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person walking briskly outdoors

exercises.name: Cycling
exercises.instructions: Cycle at a moderate intensity for 20-30 minutes, 3-4 times a week
exercises.dosage: 20-30 minutes, 3-4 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person cycling on a stationary bike

phase_2.name: Resistance Training
phase_2.goal: To improve muscle strength and endurance

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, then bend knees and lower body down until thighs are parallel to ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a squat

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet together, take a large step forward with one foot, and lower body down until back knee almost touches ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a lunge

phase_3.name: High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT)
phase_3.goal: To improve cardiovascular fitness and increase exercise tolerance

exercises.name: Sprints
exercises.instructions: Sprint at maximum effort for 30 seconds, followed by 30 seconds of rest
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person sprinting

exercises.name: Burpees
exercises.instructions: Start in a standing position, drop down into a squat position, kick feet back into a plank position, do a push-up, then quickly return to standing position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a week
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a burpee

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Patients with chronic heart failure should undergo a thorough assessment, including medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests such as echocardiogram and blood tests
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to improve range of motion and reduce pain and stiffness
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients with chronic heart failure should avoid heavy lifting, bending, and strenuous exercise, and should monitor their symptoms and report any changes to their healthcare provider

scientific_reference: American College of Sports Medicine. (2018). ACSM's Guidelines for Exercise Testing and Prescription. 10th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer.

clinical_presentation.definition: Pulmonary fibrosis is a condition in which the lungs become scarred, leading to breathing difficulties. In the context of neurology, it can be related to neurological conditions that affect the brain's ability to control breathing, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) or spinal cord injuries.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A chest X-ray or CT scan showing scarring in the lungs.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the chest wall, avoiding the lung fields
electrotherapy.goal: Relaxation of accessory respiratory muscles and improvement of lung function
electrotherapy.image_description: Electrodes placed on the chest wall with the IFC device in the background.

phase_1.name: Breathing Exercises
phase_1.goal: Improve lung function and increase oxygenation

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, place one hand on your stomach and the other on your chest, inhale deeply through your nose, allowing your stomach to rise while your chest remains still
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A person lying on their back with hands on their stomach and chest, demonstrating diaphragmatic breathing.

phase_2.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
phase_2.goal: Reduce anxiety and promote relaxation

exercises.name: Shoulder Rolls
exercises.instructions: Roll your shoulders forward and backward in a circular motion, repeat for 10 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A person rolling their shoulders in a circular motion.

phase_3.name: Aerobic Exercise
phase_3.goal: Improve cardiovascular fitness and increase endurance

exercises.name: Brisk Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk at a brisk pace for 30 minutes, 3 times a week
exercises.dosage: 30 minutes, 3 times a week
exercises.image_description: A person walking at a brisk pace outdoors.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) and chest imaging studies to assess lung function and rule out other conditions
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Chest physiotherapy, including percussion and vibration, to help loosen mucus and improve lung function
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid overexertion, which can worsen shortness of breath and fatigue.

scientific_reference: American Thoracic Society. (2020). Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: Diagnosis and Treatment.

clinical_presentation.definition: Developmental delay refers to a significant lag in a child's physical, cognitive, behavioral, emotional, or social development compared to what is typically expected for their age.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An image of a child with developmental delay, with a healthcare professional in the background, observing and taking notes.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 20-50 Hz, Pulse duration: 200-400 μs
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the affected muscle group, avoiding bony prominences and sensitive areas.
electrotherapy.goal: Improve muscle strength and function in children with developmental delay.
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of a child receiving NMES, with electrodes placed on their muscles and a healthcare professional adjusting the device.

phase_1.name: Initial Mobility and Strengthening
phase_1.goal: Improve range of motion, strength, and overall mobility in children with developmental delay.

exercises.name: Passive Range of Motion (PROM) Exercises
exercises.instructions: Gently move the child's joints through a range of motion, without resistance or weight-bearing.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a healthcare professional performing PROM exercises on a child with developmental delay.

exercises.name: Active Range of Motion (AROM) Exercises
exercises.instructions: Encourage the child to move their joints through a range of motion, using their own muscles.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a child with developmental delay performing AROM exercises with assistance from a healthcare professional.

phase_2.name: Progressive Strengthening and Mobility
phase_2.goal: Progressively increase strength, mobility, and function in children with developmental delay.

exercises.name: Resistance Band Exercises
exercises.instructions: Use resistance bands to provide gentle resistance, encouraging the child to strengthen their muscles.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a child with developmental delay using resistance bands with assistance from a healthcare professional.

phase_3.name: Advanced Functional Training
phase_3.goal: Improve functional abilities, such as walking, running, and playing, in children with developmental delay.

exercises.name: Gait Training
exercises.instructions: Use assistive devices, such as walkers or orthotics, to support the child's gait and improve walking abilities.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 minutes, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a child with developmental delay walking with assistance from a healthcare professional, using a walker or orthotics.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Comprehensive assessment, including physical examination, developmental screening, and diagnostic tests (e.g., MRI, EEG) to determine the underlying cause of developmental delay.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue massage, to improve range of motion, reduce muscle tone, and enhance overall mobility.
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of fatigue, pain, or discomfort, and adjust treatment protocols accordingly. Ensure proper positioning and support to prevent injury or complications.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Pediatrics. (2019). Developmental Delay. Pediatrics, 143(3), e20182530.

clinical_presentation.definition: A three-dimensional deformity of the spine, characterized by lateral curvature, rotation, and sagittal imbalance, affecting adolescents without a clear cause or underlying condition.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A radiograph of the spine showing a lateral curvature of more than 10 degrees, with associated vertebral rotation and sagittal imbalance.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 30-50% of maximum inspiratory pressure, Frequency: 10-15 breaths per minute, Duration: 10-15 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the device on the chest or abdomen to monitor and assist breathing
electrotherapy.goal: Improve inspiratory muscle strength and endurance
electrotherapy.image_description: A patient using an inspiratory muscle training device with a chest strap to monitor breathing

phase_1.name: Breathing and Posture
phase_1.goal: Improve lung function and spinal alignment

exercises.name: Diaphragmatic Breathing
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, place one hand on your stomach and the other on your chest, inhale deeply through your nose, allowing your stomach to rise while your chest remains still
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient lying on their back with hands on stomach and chest, demonstrating diaphragmatic breathing

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Flexibility
phase_2.goal: Improve spinal flexibility and strengthen core muscles

exercises.name: Cat-Cow Stretch
exercises.instructions: Start on your hands and knees, inhale and arch your back, lifting your tailbone and head towards the ceiling, then exhale and round your back, tucking your chin to your chest and your tailbone towards the floor
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient on hands and knees, demonstrating cat-cow stretch

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Conditioning
phase_3.goal: Improve overall physical fitness and spinal stability

exercises.name: Plank with Leg Lift
exercises.instructions: Start in a plank position with hands under shoulders and toes on the ground, lift one leg towards the ceiling, holding for a few seconds before lowering
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions on each leg, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A patient in a plank position, lifting one leg towards the ceiling
