clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough physical examination, including spinal radiographs and pulmonary function tests, to assess the degree of curvature and any associated cardiopulmonary compromise
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization and joint mobilization to improve spinal flexibility and reduce muscle tension
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid contact sports or activities that may exacerbate the condition

scientific_reference: The American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) and the Scoliosis Research Society (SRS) provide guidelines for the physical therapy management of adolescent idiopathic scoliosis.

clinical_presentation.definition: A condition characterized by a decrease in bone mass and density, leading to an increased risk of fractures
clinical_presentation.image_description: X-ray image of a osteoporotic spine with vertebral compression fractures

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the spine, avoiding the spine itself
electrotherapy.goal: Pain relief and improved mobility
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of IFC electrodes placed on a patient's back

phase_1.name: Pain Relief and Mobility
phase_1.goal: Improve mobility and reduce pain

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, tilt your pelvis upwards and then back down again
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing a pelvic tilt exercise

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Sit on the edge of a chair with your affected leg straight out in front of you, lift your leg up and then lower it back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing a knee extension exercise

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Balance
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and balance to reduce fall risk

exercises.name: Heel Slides
exercises.instructions: Sit on the edge of a chair with your feet flat on the floor, slowly slide your heels away from you and then back towards you
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing heel slides

exercises.name: Single Leg Standing
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, hold for 10 seconds and then switch legs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient standing on one leg

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve overall strength and ability to perform daily activities

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, slowly lower yourself down into a squat and then stand back up
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing a squat

exercises.name: Step-Ups
exercises.instructions: Stand in front of a stair or step, raise one foot up onto the step and then bring the other foot up to meet it, step back down to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a patient performing a step-up

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Osteoporosis diagnosed through DEXA scan and medical history
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Joint mobilization and soft tissue massage to improve mobility and reduce pain
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and use assistive devices as needed

scientific_reference: National Osteoporosis Foundation. (2020). Clinician's Guide to Prevention and Treatment of Osteoporosis

clinical_presentation.definition: Fall risk in older adults refers to the likelihood of an older person experiencing a fall, which can result in injuries, hospitalization, and even death. It is a major public health concern, with one in four older adults experiencing a fall each year.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An older adult holding onto a walker for support to prevent falls

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Duration: 30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the lower back or buttocks to stimulate muscle contractions and improve balance
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and improve mobility to decrease fall risk
electrotherapy.image_description: A TENS unit with electrodes placed on the lower back

phase_1.name: Balance and Strengthening
phase_1.goal: Improve balance, strength, and flexibility to reduce fall risk

exercises.name: Single-Leg Standing
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, for 10 seconds. Repeat on the other leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 5 repetitions on each leg
exercises.image_description: An older adult standing on one leg, with support from a chair if needed

exercises.name: Heel-To-Toe Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk along a straight line, placing the heel of one foot directly in front of the toes of the other foot
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 steps
exercises.image_description: An older adult walking along a straight line, with support from a chair if needed

phase_2.name: Advanced Balance and Strengthening
phase_2.goal: Continue to improve balance, strength, and flexibility to reduce fall risk

exercises.name: Tandem Walking
exercises.instructions: Walk along a straight line, with the feet together, one foot in front of the other
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 steps
exercises.image_description: An older adult walking along a straight line, with feet together

exercises.name: Step-Ups
exercises.instructions: Step up onto a low step or stair, and then step back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 5 repetitions on each leg
exercises.image_description: An older adult stepping up onto a low step

phase_3.name: Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve ability to perform daily activities safely and independently

exercises.name: Simulated Grocery Shopping
exercises.instructions: Practice walking while carrying a basket or bag, and navigating around obstacles
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 5 minutes
exercises.image_description: An older adult walking while carrying a basket

exercises.name: Stair Climbing
exercises.instructions: Practice climbing stairs, using handrails for support if needed
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 5 repetitions
exercises.image_description: An older adult climbing stairs

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Conduct a comprehensive fall risk assessment, including the Timed Up and Go test and the Berg Balance Scale
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, to improve range of motion and reduce pain
clinical_notes.precautions: Monitor for signs of dizziness, lightheadedness, or fatigue, and adjust exercises accordingly

scientific_reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2020). Preventing Falls Among Older Adults. Retrieved from https://www.cdc.gov/falls/index.html

clinical_presentation.definition: Total knee replacement is a surgical procedure where the diseased knee joint is replaced with artificial material. In the context of sports, TKR is often required for individuals who have suffered severe knee injuries or degenerative conditions that hinder their ability to participate in sports.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An X-ray image of a total knee replacement, showing the artificial components in place.

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency, 100 Hz, 30 minutes, 3 times a day
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes around the knee, avoiding the incision site
electrotherapy.goal: Pain management and reduction of inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes around the knee.

electrotherapy.parameters: Medium frequency, 4 kHz, 20 minutes, 2 times a day
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the knee, parallel to the joint line
electrotherapy.goal: Muscle strengthening and improvement of joint mobility
electrotherapy.image_description: An illustration of IFC electrode placement on the knee.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks post-op)
phase_1.goal: Pain management, swelling reduction, and initial range of motion

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, keeping the foot behind the body, and then straighten it again
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a patient performing knee flexion exercise with a straight back and proper alignment.

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly straighten the knee, keeping the quadriceps muscle engaged, and then bend it again
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a patient performing knee extension exercise with a focus on quadriceps contraction.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks post-op)
phase_2.goal: Progressive strengthening, range of motion, and functional activities

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the leg straight up, keeping the knee straight, and then lower it back down
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the proper technique for straight leg raise exercise.

exercises.name: Step-Ups
exercises.instructions: Step up onto a low step or stair, and then step back down to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a patient performing step-ups with proper foot placement and body alignment.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (6 weeks post-op and beyond)
phase_3.goal: High-level strengthening, agility drills, and return to sports-specific activities

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Perform a lunge, keeping the back knee almost touching the ground, and then push back up to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a patient performing a lunge with proper form and balance.

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform drills that mimic sports-specific movements, such as zig-zag running or shuttle runs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A video screenshot of a patient performing agility drills with proper technique and speed.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Post-operative total knee replacement patients often present with pain, swelling, and limited range of motion. A thorough assessment is necessary to identify any underlying conditions or complications.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques such as joint mobilization and soft tissue massage can be beneficial in improving range of motion and reducing pain and inflammation.
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients should avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and should use assistive devices such as crutches or a walker as needed.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2020). Total Knee Replacement. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/total-knee-replacement/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Supraspinatus tendinopathy is a condition characterized by inflammation and degeneration of the supraspinatus tendon, leading to pain and dysfunction in the shoulder joint.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram of the shoulder joint showing the supraspinatus tendon and its surrounding structures.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the affected supraspinatus tendon, using a generous amount of coupling gel.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing, and improve tendon function.
electrotherapy.image_description: A photograph of an ultrasound probe being applied to the shoulder region.

electrotherapy.parameters: 630-830 nm wavelength, 10-50 mW/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the LLLT probe over the affected supraspinatus tendon, using a contact or non-contact technique.
electrotherapy.goal: To reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing, and improve tendon function.
electrotherapy.image_description: A photograph of an LLLT probe being applied to the shoulder region.

phase_1.name: Pendulum exercises
phase_1.goal: To maintain range of motion and reduce stiffness in the shoulder joint.

exercises.name: Pendulum exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected arm and perform small circular motions, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram of a person performing a pendulum exercise with their arm.

phase_2.name: Strengthening exercises
phase_2.goal: To improve strength and function of the supraspinatus muscle and surrounding shoulder muscles.

exercises.name: Supraspinatus strengthening exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a resistance band or light weight in the affected arm and perform shoulder abduction, keeping the elbow straight.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram of a person performing a supraspinatus strengthening exercise with a resistance band.

phase_3.name: Advanced strengthening and functional exercises
phase_3.goal: To improve strength, function, and proprioception of the shoulder joint and surrounding muscles.

exercises.name: Wall slide exercise
exercises.instructions: Stand with the affected arm against a wall and slowly slide the arm up the wall, keeping the elbow straight.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram of a person performing a wall slide exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment of the shoulder joint, including range of motion, strength, and special tests (e.g. empty can test), is necessary to diagnose supraspinatus tendinopathy.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, may be used to improve range of motion and reduce pain and stiffness.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, throwing, or repetitive overhead activities that may exacerbate the condition.

scientific_reference: American Physical Therapy Association. (2019). Orthopedic Section. Supraspinatus tendinopathy. In APTA Orthopedic Section: Clinical Practice Guidelines (pp. 1-12).

clinical_presentation.definition: A partial rotator cuff tear is an injury to one or more of the tendons that surround the shoulder joint, causing pain and limited mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An MRI or ultrasound image showing a partial tear in one of the rotator cuff tendons.

electrotherapy.parameters: Wavelength: 810nm, Power density: 100mW/cm², Treatment duration: 10 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Apply the laser probe directly to the affected area, 1-2cm from the skin
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of the LLLT probe on the affected shoulder.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 100Hz, Pulse width: 200μs, Intensity: 10-20mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the electrodes on either side of the affected area, avoiding the spine and joints
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and discomfort
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the affected shoulder.

phase_1.name: Pendulum Exercises
phase_1.goal: Maintain range of motion and reduce stiffness

exercises.name: Pendulum Exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1lb) and perform small circles with the arm, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the pendulum exercise with a light weight.

phase_2.name: Isometric Strengthening
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and stability of the shoulder muscles

exercises.name: Isometric Shoulder External Rotation
exercises.instructions: Hold a light resistance band or cable and perform an external rotation of the shoulder, holding for 5 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the isometric shoulder external rotation exercise.

phase_3.name: Dynamic Strengthening
phase_3.goal: Improve functional strength and mobility of the shoulder

exercises.name: Dynamic Shoulder External Rotation
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight or resistance band and perform a dynamic external rotation of the shoulder, moving through a range of motion.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the dynamic shoulder external rotation exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment of the shoulder joint, including range of motion, strength, and special tests (e.g. Hawkins-Kennedy test), to diagnose a partial rotator cuff tear.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization and joint mobilization techniques to reduce pain and improve mobility.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or overhead activities that may exacerbate the injury.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2019). Rotator Cuff Tears. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/rotator-cuff-tears/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Subacromial impingement is a condition where the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the subacromial space, leading to pain and limited mobility in the shoulder joint.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the subacromial space and the rotator cuff tendons.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.1-0.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the subacromial space, with the patient's arm at their side.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an ultrasound machine and probe being applied to the shoulder.

electrotherapy.parameters: 630-800 nm wavelength, 10-50 mW/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the LLLT probe over the subacromial space, with the patient's arm at their side.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an LLLT machine and probe being applied to the shoulder.

phase_1.name: Pendulum Exercises
phase_1.goal: Maintain range of motion, reduce pain and stiffness

exercises.name: Pendulum Exercise
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected arm, and gently swing the arm in a small circle, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the pendulum exercise.

phase_2.name: Strengthening Exercises
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and function of the rotator cuff muscles

exercises.name: Resisted External Rotation
exercises.instructions: Hold a light resistance band or cable in the affected arm, and rotate the arm outward against the resistance.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the resisted external rotation exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening Exercises
phase_3.goal: Improve strength and function of the rotator cuff muscles, and prepare for return to sport or activity

exercises.name: Resisted Scaption
exercises.instructions: Hold a light resistance band or cable in the affected arm, and lift the arm out to the side, keeping the elbow straight.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the resisted scaption exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Subacromial impingement is typically diagnosed through a combination of patient history, physical examination, and imaging studies (e.g. X-ray, MRI).
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization may be used to improve range of motion and reduce pain and stiffness.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or overhead activities, which can exacerbate the condition.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2019). Subacromial Impingement. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/subacromial-impingement/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, is a condition characterized by pain and inflammation on the outside of the elbow, where the muscles and tendons of the forearm attach to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and the surrounding muscles and tendons.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the lateral epicondyle, with the probe moving in a circular motion
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an ultrasound probe being applied to the lateral epicondyle.

electrotherapy.parameters: 630-700 nm wavelength, 10-50 mW/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the LLLT probe over the lateral epicondyle, with the probe stationary
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of an LLLT probe being applied to the lateral epicondyle.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing

exercises.name: Wrist Extension Stretch
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected hand, with the palm facing down. Slowly tilt the wrist up, keeping the forearm still, and hold for 15-30 seconds. Repeat 3-5 times.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the wrist extension stretch.

exercises.name: Forearm Pronation Stretch
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected hand, with the palm facing down. Slowly turn the forearm so that the palm faces downwards, keeping the wrist still, and hold for 15-30 seconds. Repeat 3-5 times.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the forearm pronation stretch.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and flexibility, promote functional activities

exercises.name: Wrist Extension Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected hand, with the palm facing down. Slowly lift the weight up, keeping the forearm still, and hold for 1-2 seconds. Repeat 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the wrist extension strengthening exercise.

exercises.name: Forearm Supination Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Hold a light weight (less than 1 pound) in the affected hand, with the palm facing up. Slowly turn the forearm so that the palm faces upwards, keeping the wrist still, and hold for 1-2 seconds. Repeat 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the forearm supination strengthening exercise.

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase
phase_3.goal: Maintain strength and flexibility, prevent recurrence

exercises.name: Wrist Extension with Resistance Band
exercises.instructions: Hold a resistance band in the affected hand, with the palm facing down. Slowly lift the band up, keeping the forearm still, and hold for 1-2 seconds. Repeat 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the wrist extension with resistance band exercise.

exercises.name: Forearm Pronation with Resistance Band
exercises.instructions: Hold a resistance band in the affected hand, with the palm facing down. Slowly turn the forearm so that the palm faces downwards, keeping the wrist still, and hold for 1-2 seconds. Repeat 3 sets of 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3-5 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the forearm pronation with resistance band exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Lateral epicondylitis is typically diagnosed based on clinical presentation and physical examination. Imaging studies such as X-rays or MRI may be ordered to rule out other conditions.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as heavy lifting, bending, or twisting. Use proper lifting techniques and avoid repetitive motions.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2019). Tennis Elbow (Lateral Epicondylitis). Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/tennis-elbow-lateral-epicondylitis/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Medial epicondylitis, also known as golfer's elbow, is a condition characterized by pain and inflammation on the inner aspect of the elbow, where the tendons of the forearm muscles attach to the medial epicondyle of the humerus.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the medial epicondyle and the affected tendons

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm^2 intensity, 5-10 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the affected area, using a liberal amount of coupling gel
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing
electrotherapy.image_description: A photograph of an ultrasound machine and probe being applied to the medial elbow

electrotherapy.parameters: 50-100 Hz frequency, 10-20 mA intensity, 10-15 minutes duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the IFC electrodes on either side of the affected area, using a small amount of electrode gel
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of IFC electrodes on the medial elbow

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion

exercises.name: Elbow Flexion and Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend and straighten the elbow, avoiding any painful movements
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a person performing elbow flexion and extension exercises

exercises.name: Wrist Flexion and Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend and straighten the wrist, avoiding any painful movements
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a person performing wrist flexion and extension exercises

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Progression
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and function of the affected muscles

exercises.name: Wrist Flexion with Resistance
exercises.instructions: Use a light weight or resistance band to strengthen the wrist flexors
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a person performing wrist flexion with resistance exercises

exercises.name: Elbow Flexion with Resistance
exercises.instructions: Use a light weight or resistance band to strengthen the elbow flexors
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a person performing elbow flexion with resistance exercises

phase_3.name: Return to Function and Sport
phase_3.goal: Return to normal activities and sports, with full strength and function

exercises.name: Golf Swing Simulation
exercises.instructions: Practice a golf swing motion, using a light weight or resistance band
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A photograph of a person practicing a golf swing simulation exercise

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Medial epicondylitis is typically diagnosed through a combination of patient history, physical examination, and imaging studies (e.g. X-ray, MRI)
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques such as massage, joint mobilization, and soft tissue mobilization may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and improve range of motion
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, which can exacerbate the condition

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2019). Medial Epicondylitis (Golfer's Elbow). Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/medial-epicondylitis-golfers-elbow/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a medical condition that arises due to compression of the median nerve as it travels through the wrist at the carpal tunnel, leading to numbness, tingling, and pain in the hand and arm.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the carpal tunnel and the median nerve

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the wrist, avoiding the median nerve
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of IFC therapy electrodes placed on the wrist

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 10-200 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the palmar surface of the hand and forearm
electrotherapy.goal: Manage pain and discomfort
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing TENS electrode placement on the hand and forearm

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and improve wrist mobility

exercises.name: Wrist Extension Stretch
exercises.instructions: Hold arm straight out in front, palm down. Use other hand to gently pull hand back and up, stretching wrist.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10-15 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing wrist extension stretch

exercises.name: Wrist Flexion Stretch
exercises.instructions: Hold arm straight out in front, palm up. Use other hand to gently pull hand down, stretching wrist.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10-15 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing wrist flexion stretch

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Stabilization
phase_2.goal: Improve wrist strength and stability

exercises.name: Wrist Extension Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Hold light weight or resistance band in hand, palm down. Slowly lift hand up, keeping wrist straight, then lower back down.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10-15 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing wrist extension strengthening

phase_3.name: Functional Activities and Progression
phase_3.goal: Improve functional ability and progress to more challenging activities

exercises.name: Wrist Rotation with Light Weight
exercises.instructions: Hold light weight or resistance band in hand, palm down. Rotate wrist in circular motion, first clockwise and then counterclockwise.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10-15 repetitions, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing wrist rotation with light weight

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Carpal tunnel syndrome is diagnosed based on clinical presentation, including symptoms and physical examination findings, as well as electrodiagnostic tests such as nerve conduction studies and electromyography.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, including joint mobilization and soft tissue massage, can help to reduce pain and improve range of motion.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate symptoms, such as repetitive wrist flexion or extension, and take regular breaks to rest and stretch the hands and wrists.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2020). Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/carpal-tunnel-syndrome/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Cervical radiculopathy refers to a disorder of the roots of the spinal nerves as they exit the spinal canal in the cervical spine, often causing pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the neck and arm.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the cervical spine and the roots of the spinal nerves, highlighting the areas commonly affected by cervical radiculopathy.

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency (100 Hz), low intensity (10-20 mA), 30 minutes per session, 2-3 sessions per week
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the skin over the affected area, avoiding the spine and any metal implants
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and discomfort in the neck and arm
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a TENS unit with electrodes placed on the skin over the affected area.

electrotherapy.parameters: Medium frequency (4 kHz), moderate intensity (20-40 mA), 20 minutes per session, 2-3 sessions per week
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the skin over the affected area, using a cross-pattern to target the affected nerve roots
electrotherapy.goal: Improve pain relief and reduce inflammation in the affected area
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for IFC therapy in the treatment of cervical radiculopathy.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion

exercises.name: Chin Tucks
exercises.instructions: Stand or sit with good posture, look straight ahead, and slowly tuck your chin in towards your chest, holding for 15-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a chin tuck exercise.

exercises.name: Shoulder Rolls
exercises.instructions: Roll your shoulders forward and backward in a circular motion, repeating for 10-15 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the movement of the shoulders during a shoulder roll exercise.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and flexibility, promote functional activities

exercises.name: Neck Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Slowly tilt your head to the side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder, and then return to the starting position
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a neck strengthening exercise.

phase_3.name: Maintenance Phase
phase_3.goal: Maintain strength and flexibility, prevent recurrence

exercises.name: Yoga or Pilates
exercises.instructions: Participate in a yoga or Pilates class, focusing on exercises that promote good posture, strength, and flexibility
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times per week
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person participating in a yoga or Pilates class.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a physical examination and review of medical history, is necessary to diagnose cervical radiculopathy and rule out other potential causes of symptoms.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue massage, may be used to improve range of motion and reduce pain and stiffness.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and take regular breaks to stretch and move throughout the day.

scientific_reference: American Physical Therapy Association. (2019). Cervical Radiculopathy. In Guide to Physical Therapist Practice (4th ed.).

clinical_presentation.definition: Mechanical neck pain refers to pain and stiffness in the neck region, often resulting from poor posture, muscle strain, or joint dysfunction.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Illustration of the cervical spine with highlighted areas of pain and stiffness

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 50-100 Hz, Duration: 15-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the spine, 2-3 inches apart, at the level of the painful area
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram of TENS electrode placement on the neck

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 5-15 mA, Frequency: 80-120 Hz, Duration: 15-30 minutes
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes in a quadrupole arrangement, with two electrodes on either side of the spine, 2-3 inches apart, at the level of the painful area
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion
electrotherapy.image_description: Diagram of IFC electrode placement on the neck

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion

exercises.name: Chin Tucks
exercises.instructions: Stand or sit with good posture, look straight ahead, and tuck chin in towards chest, holding for 15-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing a chin tuck exercise

exercises.name: Shoulder Rolls
exercises.instructions: Roll shoulders forward and backward in a circular motion, holding for 15-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing shoulder rolls

phase_2.name: Subacute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and flexibility, reduce pain and inflammation

exercises.name: Neck Stretching
exercises.instructions: Slowly tilt head to the side, bringing ear towards shoulder, holding for 15-30 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing a neck stretch

exercises.name: Scapular Squeezes
exercises.instructions: Squeeze shoulder blades together, holding for 5-10 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing scapular squeezes

phase_3.name: Strengthening Phase
phase_3.goal: Improve strength and endurance, reduce pain and inflammation

exercises.name: Neck Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift head off the ground, holding for 5-10 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing a neck strengthening exercise

exercises.name: Shoulder Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Hold light weights or resistance bands, lifting arms out to the sides, holding for 5-10 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Illustration of a person performing shoulder strengthening exercises

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Mechanical neck pain is diagnosed through a combination of patient history, physical examination, and imaging studies (e.g. X-rays, MRI)
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Joint mobilization, soft tissue mobilization, and trigger point therapy may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, which can exacerbate the condition

scientific_reference: American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) guidelines for the management of mechanical neck pain

clinical_presentation.definition: A condition where the soft inner gel of the intervertebral disc leaks out through a tear in the outer layer, putting pressure on nearby nerves and causing pain, numbness, and weakness in the back and legs
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of a herniated lumbar disc compressing a spinal nerve root

electrotherapy.parameters: High frequency, 100 Hz, 30-60 minutes per session
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the spine, 2-3 inches apart, at the level of the herniated disc
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of TENS electrodes on the lower back

electrotherapy.parameters: Medium frequency, 4 kHz, 15-30 minutes per session
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the affected area, 2-3 inches apart, in a quadrupole arrangement
electrotherapy.goal: Improve circulation and reduce muscle spasms
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of IFC electrodes placed on the lower back in a quadrupole arrangement

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, improve range of motion

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, tilt your pelvis upwards and then back down again, repeat for 10-15 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a pelvic tilt exercise

exercises.name: Knee to Chest Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back and bring one knee towards your chest, hold for 30 seconds and then switch sides
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a knee to chest stretch

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and flexibility, promote proper movement patterns

exercises.name: Bridge
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, lift your hips up towards the ceiling and then back down again, repeat for 10-15 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a bridge exercise

exercises.name: Cat-Cow Stretch
exercises.instructions: Start on your hands and knees, arch your back and lift your tailbone towards the ceiling (like a cat), then round your back and tuck your chin towards your chest (like a cow), repeat for 10-15 repetitions
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a cat-cow stretch

phase_3.name: Chronic Phase
phase_3.goal: Maintain strength and flexibility, prevent future episodes

exercises.name: Plank
exercises.instructions: Start in a push-up position, engage your core muscles and hold for 30-60 seconds
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a plank exercise

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, take a large step forward with one foot and lower your body down until your back knee almost touches the ground, push back up to the starting position and repeat on the other side
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times per day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing a lunge exercise

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough physical examination, including a neurological examination and imaging studies (e.g. MRI or CT scan), to confirm the diagnosis of lumbar disc herniation
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Soft tissue mobilization, joint mobilization, and spinal manipulation to improve range of motion and reduce pain and inflammation
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid prolonged sitting or standing

scientific_reference: American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) guidelines for the treatment of lumbar disc herniation

clinical_presentation.definition: Lumbar spinal stenosis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the spinal canal in the lower back, which can put pressure on the spinal cord and nerves, leading to pain, numbness, and weakness in the back and legs.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the narrowing of the spinal canal in the lumbar region.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the lumbar spine, approximately 2-3 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation in the lumbar region.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of IFC electrodes placed on the lumbar spine.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 10-200 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the skin near the area of pain, approximately 1-2 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and discomfort in the lumbar region.
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of TENS electrodes placed on the skin near the lumbar spine.

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Flexibility
phase_1.goal: Improve flexibility and reduce pain in the lumbar region.

exercises.name: Knee to Chest Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, bring one knee towards your chest, and hold for 30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the knee to chest stretch.

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, tilt your pelvis upwards and then back down again, repeating the motion for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the pelvic tilt exercise.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Stabilization
phase_2.goal: Improve strength and stability in the lumbar region.

exercises.name: Bridge Exercise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, lift your hips towards the ceiling, and hold for 2-3 seconds. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the bridge exercise.

exercises.name: Plank Exercise
exercises.instructions: Start in a push-up position, engage your core muscles, and hold for 30-60 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the plank exercise.

phase_3.name: Functional Activities and Proprioception
phase_3.goal: Improve functional activities and proprioception in the lumbar region.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground, and hold for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the single-leg balance exercise.

exercises.name: Lumbar Rotation Exercise
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, rotate your torso to one side, and hold for 10-30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a person performing the lumbar rotation exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment and diagnosis of lumbar spinal stenosis should include a review of the patient's medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies such as X-rays or MRI.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques such as spinal mobilization and soft tissue massage may be used to improve flexibility and reduce pain in the lumbar region.
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients with lumbar spinal stenosis should avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and should take regular breaks to stretch and move throughout the day.

scientific_reference: American College of Physicians. (2017). Noninvasive Treatments for Acute, Subacute, and Chronic Low Back Pain: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American College of Physicians. Annals of Internal Medicine, 166(7), 514-530.

clinical_presentation.definition: Sacroiliac joint dysfunction refers to any condition that affects the sacroiliac joint, which is a joint in the pelvis that connects the sacrum and the ilium bones. This condition can cause pain, stiffness, and limited mobility in the lower back, hips, and legs.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An illustration of the sacroiliac joint, highlighting its location and structure.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the sacroiliac joint, approximately 2-3 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation in the sacroiliac joint.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for IFC therapy on the sacroiliac joint.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-200 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the sacroiliac joint, approximately 2-3 inches apart.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation in the sacroiliac joint.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for TENS therapy on the sacroiliac joint.

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Mobility
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and improve mobility in the sacroiliac joint.

exercises.name: Knee to Chest Stretch
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, bring one knee towards your chest, and hold for 30 seconds. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing the knee to chest stretch.

exercises.name: Pelvic Tilt
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, tilt your pelvis upwards and then back down again, repeating the motion for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing the pelvic tilt exercise.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Stabilization
phase_2.goal: Strengthen the muscles surrounding the sacroiliac joint and improve stability.

exercises.name: Gluteal Bridges
exercises.instructions: Lie on your back, lift your hips towards the ceiling, and hold for 2-3 seconds. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing the gluteal bridge exercise.

exercises.name: Core Strengthening
exercises.instructions: Perform planks, side planks, or other core strengthening exercises to improve stability and strength in the core muscles.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a plank exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve functional activities and advanced strengthening exercises to promote long-term stability and mobility.

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, lower your body down into a squat, and then stand back up. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a squat exercise.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet together, take a large step forward with one foot, and lower your body down into a lunge. Repeat on the other side.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing a lunge exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a physical examination and medical history, is necessary to diagnose sacroiliac joint dysfunction. Imaging studies, such as X-rays or MRI, may also be used to confirm the diagnosis.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization, can be used to improve mobility and reduce pain in the sacroiliac joint.
clinical_notes.precautions: Patients with sacroiliac joint dysfunction should avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and should take regular breaks to rest and stretch.

scientific_reference: The treatment protocol for sacroiliac joint dysfunction is based on current scientific evidence and clinical guidelines, including the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) and the Orthopedic Section of the APTA.

clinical_presentation.definition: Hip osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the hip joint, leading to pain, stiffness, and limited mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An X-ray image of a hip joint showing joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes around the hip joint, avoiding bony prominences
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of electrodes for IFC therapy around the hip joint.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 1-10 Gauss
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the PEMF device near the hip joint, avoiding direct contact with metal implants
electrotherapy.goal: Enhance bone healing and reduce pain
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of a PEMF device being used to treat hip osteoarthritis.

phase_1.name: Pain Management and Mobility
phase_1.goal: Improve range of motion and reduce pain

exercises.name: Hip Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the affected leg towards the chest, keeping the knee straight
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing hip flexion exercise.

exercises.name: Hip Abduction
exercises.instructions: Slowly lift the affected leg away from the midline of the body, keeping the knee straight
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing hip abduction exercise.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Proprioception
phase_2.goal: Improve muscle strength and proprioception

exercises.name: Clam Shell Exercise
exercises.instructions: Lie on the side with the affected leg on top, lift the top knee towards the ceiling while keeping the feet together
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing clam shell exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Strengthening and Functional Activities
phase_3.goal: Improve functional abilities and reduce disability

exercises.name: Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, slowly lower the body down into a squat, keeping the back straight and knees behind the toes
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An illustration of a person performing squats.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the patient's range of motion, strength, and functional abilities to diagnose hip osteoarthritis.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization to improve joint mobility and reduce pain.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and use assistive devices such as canes or walkers to reduce stress on the hip joint.

scientific_reference: American College of Rheumatology. (2019). 2019 American College of Rheumatology/Arthritis Foundation Guideline for the Management of Osteoarthritis of the Hand, Hip, and Knee.

clinical_presentation.definition: Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome (GTPS) is a condition characterized by pain and tenderness over the greater trochanter of the femur, often associated with hip abductor tendonitis or bursitis.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram showing the location of the greater trochanter and surrounding tissues.

electrotherapy.parameters: 1-3 MHz frequency, 0.5-1.5 W/cm2 intensity, 5-10 minute duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the ultrasound probe over the affected area, using a liberal amount of coupling gel.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of an ultrasound machine and probe placement on the greater trochanter.

electrotherapy.parameters: 50-100 Hz frequency, 10-20 mA intensity, 10-15 minute duration
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place the IFC electrodes on either side of the affected area, using a liberal amount of electrode gel.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing.
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of IFC electrodes on the greater trochanter.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote tissue healing.

exercises.name: Piriformis Stretch
exercises.instructions: Sit on the floor with the affected leg crossed over the unaffected leg. Place your hand on the knee of the affected leg and pull it toward your opposite shoulder. Hold for 30 seconds and repeat 3 times.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing the piriformis stretch.

exercises.name: Gluteal Sets
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with the affected leg on top. Tighten the gluteal muscles and hold for 5 seconds. Release and repeat for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the gluteal muscles and proper contraction.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase
phase_2.goal: Improve hip abductor strength and flexibility.

exercises.name: Clam Exercise
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with the affected leg on top. Bend your knees and feet, and lift the top knee away from the bottom knee. Hold for 5 seconds and repeat for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing the clam exercise.

exercises.name: Side-Lying Leg Lift
exercises.instructions: Lie on your side with the affected leg on top. Lift the top leg away from the bottom leg, keeping it straight. Hold for 5 seconds and repeat for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the proper form for the side-lying leg lift.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase
phase_3.goal: Improve hip function and reduce the risk of re-injury.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Squat
exercises.instructions: Stand on the affected leg, with the unaffected leg lifted off the ground. Slowly lower your body down into a squat, keeping your back straight and your core engaged. Hold for 5 seconds and repeat for 10 repetitions.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing a single-leg squat.

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Take a large step forward with the unaffected leg, and lower your body down into a lunge. Hold for 5 seconds and repeat for 10 repetitions on each leg.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the proper form for lunges.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: A thorough assessment, including a physical examination and review of medical history, is necessary to diagnose GTPS.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Manual therapy techniques, such as massage and joint mobilization, may be used to reduce pain and inflammation, and promote tissue healing.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid activities that aggravate the condition, such as running or jumping. Use proper lifting techniques to avoid putting excessive stress on the hip joint.

scientific_reference: Baker, K. L., et al. (2018). Greater trochanteric pain syndrome: a review of the literature. Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy, 48(5), 347-355.

clinical_presentation.definition: Knee osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the knee joint, leading to pain, stiffness, and limited mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: Image of a knee X-ray showing joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the knee joint, avoiding bony prominences.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation in the knee joint.
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of IFC therapy electrodes placed on the knee.

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 10-200 Hz, Intensity: 10-50 mA
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on the skin around the knee joint, avoiding bony prominences.
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and discomfort in the knee joint.
electrotherapy.image_description: Image of TENS electrodes placed on the knee.

phase_1.name: Pain Reduction and Range of Motion
phase_1.goal: Improve knee joint mobility and reduce pain.

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly straighten the knee, keeping the thigh still, and then bend it again.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing knee extension exercise.

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, keeping the thigh still, and then straighten it again.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing knee flexion exercise.

phase_2.name: Strengthening and Proprioception
phase_2.goal: Improve knee joint stability and strength.

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the straight leg 6-8 inches off the floor, holding for 2-3 seconds, and then lower it back down.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing straight leg raise exercise.

phase_3.name: Functional Activities and Balance
phase_3.goal: Improve knee joint function and balance.

exercises.name: Single-Leg Standing
exercises.instructions: Stand on one leg, keeping the other foot lifted off the ground, for 10-30 seconds.
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: Image of a person performing single-leg standing exercise.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Knee osteoarthritis diagnosed through patient history, physical examination, and imaging studies (X-ray, MRI).
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization to improve joint mobility and reduce pain.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, which can exacerbate knee osteoarthritis symptoms.

scientific_reference: American College of Rheumatology (ACR) guidelines for the management of knee osteoarthritis.

clinical_presentation.definition: A Grade I–II ankle sprain is a partial tear of the ligaments surrounding the ankle joint, resulting in pain, swelling, and limited mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: An image of a person sitting on a bench with their ankle wrapped in an ice pack, with a caption 'Ankle Sprain (Grade I–II)'

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the ankle, avoiding bony prominences
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of a person receiving IFC therapy on their ankle, with electrodes placed on either side

electrotherapy.parameters: Frequency: 1-100 Hz, Intensity: comfortable sensation
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the ankle, avoiding bony prominences
electrotherapy.goal: Reduce pain
electrotherapy.image_description: An image of a person receiving TENS therapy on their ankle, with electrodes placed on either side

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-72 hours)
phase_1.goal: Reduce pain and inflammation, promote ankle mobility

exercises.name: Ankle Alphabet
exercises.instructions: Draw the alphabet with the toes, starting from A and moving to Z
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person drawing the alphabet with their toes

exercises.name: Ankle Circles
exercises.instructions: Move the ankle in a circular motion, first clockwise and then counterclockwise
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person moving their ankle in a circular motion

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (72 hours-2 weeks)
phase_2.goal: Improve ankle strength and proprioception

exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance
exercises.instructions: Stand on the affected leg, with the other foot lifted off the ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 30 seconds, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person standing on one leg

exercises.name: Heel Raises
exercises.instructions: Stand on the edge of a stair or step, with the heels hanging off the edge
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person standing on the edge of a stair, raising their heels

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (2-6 weeks)
phase_3.goal: Improve ankle function and return to sports

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform agility drills, such as zig-zag running or shuttle runs
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing agility drills

exercises.name: Plyometric Exercises
exercises.instructions: Perform plyometric exercises, such as jump squats or box jumps
exercises.dosage: 3 sets, 10 repetitions, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: An image of a person performing plyometric exercises

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess the ankle for pain, swelling, and limited mobility. Diagnose a Grade I–II ankle sprain based on clinical presentation and radiographic findings.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques, such as joint mobilization and soft tissue massage, to promote ankle mobility and reduce pain.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy weight-bearing activities, such as running or jumping, until the ankle is pain-free and has full range of motion.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons. (2017). Ankle Sprains. Retrieved from <https://orthoinfo.org/en/staying-healthy/ankle-sprains/>

clinical_presentation.definition: Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) reconstruction rehabilitation is a comprehensive treatment program designed to help patients recover from ACL surgery, aiming to restore knee function, strength, and mobility.
clinical_presentation.image_description: A diagram of the knee joint showing the ACL and surrounding structures.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 10-20 mA, Frequency: 100 Hz, Pulse width: 200 μs
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes around the knee joint, avoiding the surgical site
electrotherapy.goal: Pain management and reduction of inflammation
electrotherapy.image_description: A picture of a TENS unit with electrodes placed around the knee.

electrotherapy.parameters: Intensity: 5-10 mA, Frequency: 4 kHz, Beat frequency: 10-100 Hz
electrotherapy.placement_guide: Place electrodes on either side of the knee joint
electrotherapy.goal: Pain relief and improvement of knee function
electrotherapy.image_description: A diagram showing the placement of IFC electrodes.

phase_1.name: Acute Phase (0-2 weeks post-op)
phase_1.goal: Pain management, swelling reduction, and knee mobility

exercises.name: Knee Flexion
exercises.instructions: Slowly bend the knee, keeping the foot behind the body, and then straighten it
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing knee flexion exercise.

exercises.name: Knee Extension
exercises.instructions: Slowly straighten the knee, keeping the foot in front of the body, and then bend it
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the knee extension exercise.

phase_2.name: Sub-Acute Phase (2-6 weeks post-op)
phase_2.goal: Strengthening of surrounding muscles and improvement of knee function

exercises.name: Straight Leg Raise
exercises.instructions: Lift the leg straight up, keeping the knee straight, and then lower it
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing straight leg raise exercise.

exercises.name: Wall Squats
exercises.instructions: Stand with the back against the wall and slowly slide down into a squat, keeping the back against the wall
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing the wall squat exercise.

phase_3.name: Advanced Phase (6-12 weeks post-op)
phase_3.goal: Advanced strengthening, agility, and functional training

exercises.name: Lunges
exercises.instructions: Step forward with one foot and lower the body down into a lunge, keeping the back knee almost touching the ground
exercises.dosage: 3 sets of 10 reps, 2-3 times a day
exercises.image_description: A picture of a patient performing lunge exercise.

exercises.name: Agility Drills
exercises.instructions: Perform zig-zag running, shuttle runs, or other agility drills to improve speed and quickness
exercises.dosage: 2-3 times a week, as tolerated
exercises.image_description: A diagram showing an example of an agility drill.

clinical_notes.assessment_diagnosis: Assess knee range of motion, strength, and function. Diagnose any potential complications or setbacks.
clinical_notes.manual_therapy: Use manual therapy techniques such as joint mobilization and soft tissue mobilization to improve knee mobility and reduce pain.
clinical_notes.precautions: Avoid heavy lifting, bending, or twisting, and avoid putting excessive stress on the knee joint.

scientific_reference: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) and American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) guidelines for ACL reconstruction rehabilitation.
